8. BLD rocks!
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 07 Jan 2006 18:47:25 -0000

Hey everyone,

I'm back from vacation, and seriously did use the whole time just to
practice BLD solving. I'm becoming an addict, it's so much fun!

I did break my 3x3 BLD record, but only by 2 seconds, and I
successfully did the 5x5 BLD. I came up with a new set of 24 nouns
that are very similar to my orginal set, but still with absolutely
no overlap. This way I can use both sets for the 4x4 so I can do
lots of consecutive solves without getting as much interference from
stories from previous solves, and I use the original 24set for my X
centers on the 5x5 and the new set for the +centers making my
centers memorization both with the story method (which I like).

I'm still focusing on the 4x4 mainly, but I want to get better at
the 5x5 too. My best memorization time for the 4x4 (not on a
successful solve, but I traced the mistake and had only undone two
setup moves in the wrong order) was 6:15. I think I can improve
this to sub-6 and my best sighted solve with my BLD method so far is
about 5:10 so I'm inching towards sub-10, which I still think is
possible.

Also I found the reason why I couldn't improve my 3x3 memorization.
When working out the cycles of both the corners and edges I count
the number of pieces in each cycle, but I was doing this such as to
give each piece in the cycle a number, which is useless since I
don't remember the number sequence. Now I'm working on just quickly
memorizing the shapes of the pieces and giving each group of 4-5
pieces a name to help me remember the shape. I refuse to believe
that my memory is not good enough, I'm trying to convince myself
that I was using a dumb method and need to work on a better way of
doing it.

Anyway this message is getting long, but I just wanted to say that
I'm back and have definitely found that I love BLD solving.

Alright, good to be back and happy cubing all!

Chris






9. Re: BLD rocks!
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>

Date: Sat, 07 Jan 2006 19:23:30 -0000

all I did was BLD solving. Heh heh mostly I was being a bum and
sleeping late heh heh.

Ok, just had to fix that since it sounded really rude to my relatives
to me and isn't what I meant at all.

Chris







10. First ever successful 3x3x3 BLD average
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 2006 02:42:39 -0000

Well.... I finally did it, and I've been trying off and on for several
months now.

(2:19.12) 2:23.84 2:43.00 4:08.59 3:00.71 3:57.41 3:09.52 (DNF)
3:31.78 4:10.22 4:25.01 8:19.51 = 3:58.96

I was so freaked out on the last solve because of the DNF that I
seriously tried to memorize and solve as if my life depended on it, I
didn't care at all about the time, I just wanted to finally get an
average.

I had such a hard time towards the end since I still remembered bits
and pieces of cycles and orientations from previous solves. Often I
had to sift through a cycle and think... no I've done that one
already... no that was 2 solves ago...

Man I don't know how you guys do this and still keep getting fast
times. After the first 3 solves I couldn't forget my earlier ones and
just switched to a slow gear and went more carefully. There was a lot
of "noise" for me of trying to find the real cycle this cube in my
hands had, how do you super BLDers handle this?

Glad to finally have done it, it felt so wonderful!

Chris






11. need help : (
From: "tehguardians" <tehguardians@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 2006 03:13:41 -0000

ok, i just joined this group tonight due to many failed attempts at
trying to learn to blindfold cube. i thought i could receive some help
in the regular cube group, which, no doubt did help a bit, but i still
cant get orientation of edges yet. i suppose what im asking for is an
in-depth explanation of how to tell if it is correctly oriented or
not.

thanks,
ryan






12. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] need help : (
From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 2006 02:57:43 -0800

If you can solve a particular edge, ignoring all other pieces, using
only U F D B moves, (no 90 degree R or L moves), then that piece is
oriented correctly. With practice, you'll figure out your own tricks
for recognizing these.

Leyan


tehguardians wrote:
> ok, i just joined this group tonight due to many failed attempts at
> trying to learn to blindfold cube. i thought i could receive some help
> in the regular cube group, which, no doubt did help a bit, but i still
> cant get orientation of edges yet. i suppose what im asking for is an
> in-depth explanation of how to tell if it is correctly oriented or
> not.
>
> thanks,
> ryan
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>

13. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] First ever successful 3x3x3 BLD average
From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 2006 04:20:18 -0800

Unless someone's holding a gun to your head demanding a blindfolded
average of 10, you shouldn't get too freaked out by the DNF. No one
expects you to get 12 solves in a row! When I practice, I just solve a
few times, or if time permitting, until I DNF which is usually by the
sixth or seventh try. Rarely, I make it past 12 because of fails or
because it takes too much time.

The problem with getting stressed out after the DNF is that when you
finally do make it to 12 solves, the average you get is not
representative of your actual average at all. It defeats the whole
purpose of "getting an average"!! Chris, the first 7 solves before the
DNF average to 3:06, which is almost a minute under what your final
average turned out to be.

And don't worry, I always slow down after the first solve of a set.
Something you could try is take a break in between BLD's and do a quick
speedsolve.

Have fun!

Leyan


cmhardw wrote:
> Well.... I finally did it, and I've been trying off and on for several
> months now.
>
> (2:19.12) 2:23.84 2:43.00 4:08.59 3:00.71 3:57.41 3:09.52 (DNF)
> 3:31.78 4:10.22 4:25.01 8:19.51 = 3:58.96
>
> I was so freaked out on the last solve because of the DNF that I
> seriously tried to memorize and solve as if my life depended on it, I
> didn't care at all about the time, I just wanted to finally get an
> average.
>
> I had such a hard time towards the end since I still remembered bits
> and pieces of cycles and orientations from previous solves. Often I
> had to sift through a cycle and think... no I've done that one
> already... no that was 2 solves ago...
>
> Man I don't know how you guys do this and still keep getting fast
> times. After the first 3 solves I couldn't forget my earlier ones and
> just switched to a slow gear and went more carefully. There was a lot
> of "noise" for me of trying to find the real cycle this cube in my
> hands had, how do you super BLDers handle this?
>
> Glad to finally have done it, it felt so wonderful!
>
> Chris

15. Re: First ever successful 3x3x3 BLD average
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 2006 15:45:00 -0000

Hey Leyan, I definitely see what you're saying, and in the future if I DNF an average I won't worry about it too much and will just try again another time. For me though if I try to go what I would consider my regular speed I might be able to get an actual average of 12 once in 100 solves, but I tend to get 2 or 3 DNFs for every 12 solves at least (yeah my accuracy sucks). I think for you superhumans it's possible to take an average of 12 and find out how fast you actually solve on average ;-) For me just getting an average of 12 is a feat in itself, though I hope to change that with more practice. But I do appreciate the tips though, I will definitely try to not freak out if I get a DNF and maybe solve just a bit slower to hope for a more representative average soon. 16. I hate waiting...
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 2006 17:06:10 -0000

I've been working on 4x4x4 pretty hard again, and I've come to the
conclusion that I really hate the period between solves where I try to
forget my last solve so that I can attempt another with a clean memory
slate.

Anyone have any tips to speed this up? I'd like to maximize my time
as best I can, and currently I'd rather spend 5 minutes not solving
and doing nothing than doing two solves right in a row and spending
that extra 5 minutes during recall to sort through my current solve
and the one just before it. I'd prefer to limit this down to less
than 5 minutes though.

How much time are we given in a competition between solves for the
bigger cubes? None basically? Do you go straight from one solve into
the next since the big cube categories take up so much time? Or is
the best idea to solve for 100% accuracy and not take your second
solve to save yourself for the other big cube? You would then only
use the 2nd solve for one cube just in case you don't solve it the
first time?

Just wondering, I'd rather train for competitions now and be used to
it when I get there than to be surprised.

Stupid short term memory being better than I expected. I wish I could
just repress the memory of my previous cube or forget it outright or
something so I can do lots of solves in a row. Sigh...

Chris







17. Re: I hate waiting...
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 2006 17:20:32 -0000

Wow this really is interesting to think about. Take memory experiments in general, they have you memorize a string of say 10 words, and then they have you count backwards by 3's or something for a while, something to really occupy your mind. Then afterward they tell you to repeat the words. The longer period of time you have to count backwards, the less likely you are to recall the information. Also, rehearsal of a piece of information is what lodges it into your memory. Each part of the cycle on your cube was rehearsed really hard during memorization, but also once again when you went through that part of the cycle. So you have to overcome a piece of information that is doubly rehearsed, plus you will have adrenaline during a competition which will help to rehearse it even further. So clearly the way to forget the information is to do something that is a lot of interference. Maybe you could multiply two 4 digit numbers in your head? Whether or not you get the answer right doesn't matter, what matters is that you do something very mentally taxing that is not cube related at all. Afterward you will have a lot of interference working against your doubly rehearsed last cube state. I think I'm going to try this after my next solve. I'll try multiplying two large numbers in my head, and try as best as I can to get the answer correct. After I'm done, if I feel I've forgotten my last cube I'll try another solve. If I haven't, I multiply two more numbers. Wow I think this might work for competitions too. Or you could try to factor a 4-5 digit number into it's prime factorization or something, just something to really occupy your mind while the judges are scrambling your next cube. Hmmm... This sounds interesting to me, any ideas from anybody? Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote: > > I've been working on 4x4x4 pretty hard again, and I've come to the > conclusion that I really hate the period between solves where I try to > forget my last solve so that I can attempt another with a clean memory > slate. > > Anyone have any tips to speed this up? I'd like to maximize my time > as best I can, and currently I'd rather spend 5 minutes not solving > and doing nothing than doing two solves right in a row and spending > that extra 5 minutes during recall to sort through my current solve > and the one just before it. I'd prefer to limit this down to less > than 5 minutes though. > > How much time are we given in a competition between solves for the > bigger cubes? None basically? Do you go straight from one solve into > the next since the big cube categories take up so much time? Or is > the best idea to solve for 100% accuracy and not take your second > solve to save yourself for the other big cube? You would then only > use the 2nd solve for one cube just in case you don't solve it the > first time? > > Just wondering, I'd rather train for competitions now and be used to > it when I get there than to be surprised. > > Stupid short term memory being better than I expected. I wish I could > just repress the memory of my previous cube or forget it outright or > something so I can do lots of solves in a row. Sigh... > > Chris >
18. Re: I hate waiting...
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 09 Jan 2006 17:24:45 -0000

I just thought of another way to try to create a lot of interference, you could rehearse a lot of fake cycles in your head for some pretend scramble. Don't actually try to memorize them, but track the motion of locations across the cube the same way you would memorize, only in an endless loop. Research shows that memorizing a LOT of items that are all very similar makes it very hard to remember them. So why not absolutely and completely overload your brain with edge cycles to the point that it has to much similar information that you won't remember any of what you just did, and hopefully you'll have created some major interference helping you to forget your last solve. Whoa gotta try this too.... Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote: > > Wow this really is interesting to think about. > > Take memory experiments in general, they have you memorize a string of > say 10 words, and then they have you count backwards by 3's or > something for a while, something to really occupy your mind. Then > afterward they tell you to repeat the words. The longer period of > time you have to count backwards, the less likely you are to recall > the information.

22. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: I hate waiting...
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 9 Jan 2006 19:19:22 -0800

It's well known that feeling a smell or hearing a sound can make
memories come back to you. They're more easily accessible from a
context.

I don't know anything about the science of memorization, but I wonder
if you could plug in to this mechanism in some useful way.

What if you were to create a context to your memorization by, for
example eating candy with a special taste? Solve 1 is vanilla, solve
2 is chocolate etc. I say candy because there is hard candy that you
can suck on for quite a while, to keep the context alive. There are
obviously many other possible markers than taste.

Hope that made sense. It's a bit of a weird theory to try to explain...

- - - - - - - - - - - -
"They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever
flipped it over?"

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com

Btw, why advertise it in the blindsolving group if there's not even a blindsolving section in it? Cheers! Stefan
24. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Rubiks Forum

25. faster method
From: "Thomas Kohn" <thomas.kohn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 2006 16:47:17 +0100 (MET)

hi guys,

i would like to improve my blindfold system, i hope you can help me. i think
you are using a similar method, but i don't know why you are faster. here's
my current method:
i always hold white on top and green in front. i thought this is the best
but now i was thinking if it is better first to look if there is a better
position to start from.
first i orient the corners. therefor i use 4 moves, which are basically the
same. it depends on the position of the corner, which one i use:
UFR-position (clockwise): RF'R'F RF'R'F , then i put the next one at UFR
position and do the same twice again (if also clockwise) or the invers for
counterclockwise.
if the corner is in the bottom layer i use: RU'R'U RU'R'U, which is easyer
to execute and twists DFR counterclockwise. if i have to twist clocksie, i
put the corner to DBR-position and do: R'URU' R'URU' (three times).
i think there is a faster move to turn 3 corners clockwise (or
counterclockwise) in the upper layer, but the move i use is easy and i dont
have to think.
edge-orieintation: (RE)4 is the basic move. with set-up-moves i put two
edges in the upper layer and do the move twice. i i have to switch 4 edges,
i put them in UR, FR, FL and BL position and do the move once.
cornerpermutation: when i memorize i look which peace in in UFR position, i
jump to the target position and look which peace is there and so on until i
end at position 1. this is called a cycle? with a set-up-move i put 3
corners in the upper layer and do a 3-cycle and undo the setupmove. so 2
corners get placed correctly and the third one ends up in UFR position. i go
on until everything is correct (if no parity).
edgeorientation: here the setupmoves seem to be easyer (i only use UDRL and
F2B2 moves). my 3-cycle does UB->UR->UL->UB or counterclockwise, but UF
stays where it is. thats why i start with UB position. if there is a parity
i use the T-permutation.

my best time with this method is 3:39 average about 5 minutes, but i only
solve 70%.
how can i get faster. i need 1:20 to memorize. (1:10 is my record).
are you only executing the moves faster or do you use another method? i know
the pochmann-system, but i'm sure that cycles are faster.

questions:
1) how many different moves do you use to orient/permute corners and edges
2) how long are your set-up-moves?
3) how many single moves are you doing during a solve?
4) are you alway holding the same color on top and in front?
5) how long do you memorize?
6) are you nervous before competitions? i only solved at chalmer's open in
19 minutes. since that i try to go faster but alway DNS
7) what is the difference between DNS and DNF?

i hope i didn't annoy you and you understand my bad english.

thanks, thomas

--

GMX DSL-Flatrate 1 Jahr kostenlos* http://www.gmx.net/de/go/dsl
26. Re: I hate waiting...
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 2006 16:00:10 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > > It's well known that feeling a smell or hearing a sound can make > memories come back to you. They're more easily accessible from a > context. > > I don't know anything about the science of memorization, but I wonder > if you could plug in to this mechanism in some useful way. > > What if you were to create a context to your memorization by, for > example eating candy with a special taste? Solve 1 is vanilla, solve > 2 is chocolate etc. I say candy because there is hard candy that you > can suck on for quite a while, to keep the context alive. There are > obviously many other possible markers than taste. > > Hope that made sense. It's a bit of a weird theory to try to explain... > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > "They say the grass is greener on the other side, but have you ever > flipped it over?" > > Lars Petrus - lars@l... http://lar5.com > Reminds me of synthesesia. http://www.google.co.uk/search?hl=en&q=synthesesia&btnG=Google+Search&meta= ~Thom
27. Re: faster method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 2006 18:33:12 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Thomas Kohn" <thomas.kohn@g...> wrote: > > i know > the pochmann-system, but i'm sure that cycles are faster. This is IMPOSSIBLE since my method IS a cycle-method. (will this never end?) Cheers! Stefan
28. Re: faster method
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 10 Jan 2006 18:37:29 -0000

Hey Thomas,

Answers to your questions are below,

> first i orient the corners. therefor i use 4 moves, which are
basically the
> same. it depends on the position of the corner, which one i use:
> UFR-position (clockwise): RF'R'F RF'R'F , then i put the next one at UFR
> position and do the same twice again (if also clockwise) or the
invers for
> counterclockwise.
> if the corner is in the bottom layer i use: RU'R'U RU'R'U, which is
easyer
> to execute and twists DFR counterclockwise. if i have to twist
clocksie, i
> put the corner to DBR-position and do: R'URU' R'URU' (three times).
> i think there is a faster move to turn 3 corners clockwise (or
> counterclockwise) in the upper layer, but the move i use is easy and
i dont
> have to think.

Wow I like your moves for flipping corners, I think I might start
using your moves to flip corners in the D layer. I've been using
Macky's way (or at least I learned it from Macky back at the US2004
competition). It twists three corners in either the L or R layer.

Clockwise would be U' (R U R' U' R U R') L U' (R U R' U' R U R') L U'
(R U R' U' R U R') L2

Counterclockwise is U' (R' U R U' R' U R) L U' (R' U R U' R' U R) L U'
(R' U R U' R' U R) L2

I also flip corners in groups too:

2 corners:
L' U2 L' U' L U' L' R' U2 R U R' U R

and the inverse is nice too
R' U' R U' R' U2 R L U L' U L U2 L

4 corners:
L' U2 L U L' U' L U L' U L2 U' L U L U L U' L' U' L2

and the inverse to flip the corners the other way (I prefer LU moves
so reflect for RU if you like RU better).

> edge-orieintation: (RE)4 is the basic move. with set-up-moves i put two
> edges in the upper layer and do the move twice. i i have to switch 4
edges,
> i put them in UR, FR, FL and BL position and do the move once.

For edges I also use the move you are using, and I would use it as
(RE)x4 if the edges were setup like that, but I prefer to do it as
(M'U)x4 since it can be executed so much faster.

Also I recommend using more algs too

6 flipper: (R B R' U)x5
8 flipper: (r R d D)x3
superflip: [(M'U)x4 z y]x3

> cornerpermutation: when i memorize i look which peace in in UFR
position, i
> jump to the target position and look which peace is there and so on
until i
> end at position 1. this is called a cycle? with a set-up-move i put 3
> corners in the upper layer and do a 3-cycle and undo the setupmove. so 2
> corners get placed correctly and the third one ends up in UFR
position. i go
> on until everything is correct (if no parity).

I do the same thing, I memorize via cycles (yes you are right, the
term is cycles) and I solve them like you do.

However, consider using cycles on the F or B or D face too. Also
don't neglect moves like U2 M' U2 M as well. Use commutators whenver
you see them, since they tend to be shorter (you do a move to cycle
them right there with no setup moves) . Do cycles on other faces than
just U to minimize your setup moves.

> questions:
> 1) how many different moves do you use to orient/permute corners and
edges

I just use the same 3 cycles on other faces, and maybe a few more
orientation algs than you do, but otherwise you are already on the
right track. Not sure what Macky and Leyan and Tyson and those guys
use though.

> 2) how long are your set-up-moves?

cycling: Max 2, Min 0 and I probably average about a little over 1
setup move per alg execution.

parity fix: I can get upwards of 7 moves or more, this is not my
strongest point and is usually where I lose the most time.

> 3) how many single moves are you doing during a solve?

I just did a sighted BLD solve and got 158 moves for all steps

> 4) are you alway holding the same color on top and in front?

yes, I tried starting with the best corner orientation and switching
centers, but probably not as much as I should have. I should look
into that again...

> 5) how long do you memorize?

About as long as you do 1:20, close to 1:10 on a really good solve. I
think once ever I got 58 or 59.

6) are you nervous before competitions? i only solved at chalmer's
open in 19 minutes. since that i try to go faster but alway DNS

No, competitive BLD solving doesn't make me nervous. If you are given
3 solves in the round you must solve with a roughly 78.5% accuracy
rate in order to have a 99% chance of getting at least 1 successful
solve in the round. If you have 2 solves, then you must solve with
exactly 90% accuracy rate to guarantee a 99% chance of getting at
least one successful solve. In competition I don't take many risks
and just try for 100% accuracy for my first solve, so I'm not very
fast but I never have DNF'd all the solves in a round. It depends on
what you want out of your competitive solving. I'll probably never
set a record this way, so maybe I should take more risks.

> 7) what is the difference between DNS and DNF?

DNS = did not solve
DNF = did not finish

>
> i hope i didn't annoy you and you understand my bad english.
>
> thanks, thomas
>

Hope this helps some,
Chris







29. 4x4x4 BLD again
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 2006 06:35:35 -0000

Hey everyone,

I'm very excited right now, I just set a new personal best for the
4x4x4 BLD, 12 minutes 4.64 seconds.

I've been trying lately to go very very very fast for both
memorization and solving. At first my solves were horrible, horrible
DNFs with stuff out of place all over the cube. Then as I got more
used to the speed my solves turned into close DNFs with one or two
traceable mistakes (one inner slice cleary one turn away from solved
and 8 centers out of place). Then I started getting solves with just
two corners left at the end (forgetting corner parity) or just two
edges swapped (forgetting to solve edge parity). Well I'm glad that
it finally paid off and I got a successful solve going full speed.

For this solve I memorized in 6:15.xx and solved in rougly 5:49. My
best ever correct memorization (I DNFd the solve but it was a
traceable mistake) was 4:50 and the 5:49 is my new best successful
solve time. Together they would have been a 10:39 so sub-10 does not
seem so far away anymore. I think I can memorize yet faster on
average and I know I can solve faster with more practice.

Many, many, many thanks to Dror for all the inspiration you give me,
and also for teaching me how to BLD the 3x3x3 back in 2003 and getting
me started in the first place ;-) I seriously doubt we've heard the
last of Dror on the 4x4x4 (and many others of you) but I'm glad to be
back on top for a short while :-D

Chris






30. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: faster method
From: "Thomas Kohn" <thomas.kohn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 2006 09:54:48 +0100 (MET)

hi everyone,

thanks chris, you helped me al lot.
here is an example how i solve a 3x3x3 BLD:

Scrambling (white on top, orange in front): D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2 F2 R B L'
B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2 F2 R U'

now hold white on top an green in front!

corner orientation:
upper layer: F&#8217;RFR&#8217; F&#8217;RFR&#8217; U2 RF&#8217;R&#8217;F
RF&#8217;R&#8217;FU2
bottom layer: D R&#8217;URU&#8217; R&#8217;URU&#8217; D R&#8217;URU&#8217;
R&#8217;URU&#8217; D R&#8217;URU&#8217; R&#8217;URU&#8217; D

edge orientation:
upper layer and middle layer: L y RERERERE y&#8217;L&#8217;
bottom layer: F2 B2 U&#8217; RERERERE U2 RERERERE U&#8217; F2B2

corner positions:
DR2 F&#8217;LF&#8217;R2FL&#8217;F&#8217;R2F2 R2D&#8217;
F&#8217;LF&#8217;R2FL&#8217;F&#8217;R2F2
B2 U&#8217; F&#8217;LF&#8217;R2FL&#8217;F&#8217;R2F2 UB2
(accidently i only have to cycle them clockwise)

edge positions:
D&#8217;L2 U2 R2U&#8217;R&#8217;U&#8217;RURURU&#8217;R U2L2D
R2L2U2 R2U&#8217;R&#8217;U&#8217;RURURU&#8217;R U2L2R2
D&#8217;R2L&#8217;U2 R2U&#8217;R&#8217;U&#8217;RURURU&#8217;R U2LR2D
U&#8217; z&#8217; U R2U&#8217;R&#8217;U&#8217;RURURU&#8217;R U&#8217;zU
U2 L R&#8217;UR&#8217;U&#8217;R&#8217;U&#8217;R&#8217;URUR2 L&#8217;U2

the set-up-moves could be easier but usually i start the edge-cycles with
UB-position and put the other two in UR and UL position, but here UB already
was solved so i started with UF and i always had to do U2. i can execute the
3-edge-cycle very fast when UF remains and the other 3 cycle.

if there is a parity i use the T-permutation. with R2 and L2-moves i first
put the two corners in the upper layer and then do T. so usually UF and UB
edges change places. then i do H (UF <->UB and UR<-> UL, so with the set-up
move i put the last two edges in UR and UL position). if both corners and
edges are already in the upper layer i use a standard PLL.


questions:
1) how would you solve this example?
2) what is a commutator?
3) do you first memorize the positions and then the orientation or both at
the same time?
4) how long are your delays between algorithms?
5) the night before the dutch cube day i invented the "hybrid system": i
start with cycles and if there is a problem i switch to pochmann-system.
each system has advantages and disadvantages and i want to use the best.
what do you think about that?

thanks, thomas

--
Telefonieren Sie schon oder sparen Sie noch?
NEU: GMX Phone_Flat http://www.gmx.net/de/go/telefonie
31. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: faster method
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 2006 10:30:26 -0300 (ART)

1) Well, I'd solve it this way (scrambling with yellow on top and blue on front):

CO: U' (D' R' D R D' R' D R) U2 (R' D' R D R' D' R D) U' [I know this is not the best way, sometimes I do z' and use R U moves...]
x2 (D' R' D R D' R' D R) U (D' R' D R D' R' D R) U (D' R' D R D' R' D R) U2 (44 moves)

EO: R' B' (M' U M' U M' U M' U') (M' U M' U M' U M' U') B R
L2 R2 U (M' U M' U M' U2) (M U M U M U2) U' L2 R2 [Here I'll probably do M' as rR' and M as lL'] (38 moves)

CP: D2 L2 (x' L' U L' D2 L U' L' D2 x) D2 [cancelling the last L2 of the alg with the L2 from the setup]
D' (R B' R' B)*3 D [this is veeeeeeery cool] (25 moves)

EP: U' F U' (R' U R' U' R' U' R' U R U R2) U F' U
R2 U' (R' U R' U' R' U' R' U R U R2) U R2
D L2 R2 (R2 U R U R' U' R' U' R' U R') R2 L2 D'
L2 U F' U (R' U R' U' R' U' R' U R U R2) U' F U' L2
B U B2 (R2 U' R' U' R U R U R U' R) B2 U' B' (77 moves)

and you're done!
Total: 184 moves [wow! : )]

2) I don't really know how to explain what's a comutator, but basically is something like:
A B A' B'. You some move sequence, then another move, then the inverse of the first sequence, then the inverse of the move. Your and my ways to do CO are both commutators. You flip one corner, bring another to UFR, flip that other, and move U back. That's a commutator.

3) I first memorise orientations, and then permutations, in this order: CO, EO, CP, EP.

4) Well, I'm not a BLD master, my best solve is 2:30.xx, so you shouldn't take me as a parameter. I really don't know my delays between algs. If I memorise well, I can solve very fast, almost without delays. But if I don't memorise properly, it takes some time to remember the cycles : )

5) I never gave Stefan's method a real chance, but I think it can be fast. If you can deal with both method, you're lucky. Just make use of that.

Just my 1 cent

Pedro


---------------------------------
Yahoo! doce lar. FaÂ¤a do Yahoo! sua homepage.
32. Re: faster method
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 2006 17:05:17 -0000

> Scrambling (white on top, orange in front): D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2
F2 R B L'
> B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2 F2 R U'

> 1) how would you solve this example?

Hey Thomas,

I actually did this solve as a BLD solve, and got 2:25.26 so my
explanation below is just a reconstruction of how I actually solve.

Memorization took 1:14.xx

Solving:
I solve edge orientation first and for that I did
y E' R E' R E' R2 E R E R E R2 y'

S' U S' U S' U S' U

corner orientation:
B L U2 L' U' L U' L' R' U2 R U R' U R B'

z U' (R U R' U' R U R') (L' U') (R U R' U' R U R') (L' U') (R U R' U'
R U R') L2 z'

corner permutation:
U2 x (R U' R' U) (R U' R' U) (R U' R' U) B2 (R U' R' U) (R U' R' U) (R
U' R' U) x'

x' M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2 U2 x

edge permutation:
U S' U2 S D' S' U2 S D U' (this is a commutator way to do an edge 3
cycle, more on that below)

B2 x2 L2 U' F' B L2 F B' U' L2 x2 B2

F2 L2 x' L' U L' U' L' U' L' U L U x F2

U B' L U' L U L U L U' L' U' L2 B U'

F R2 U' F B' R2 F' B U' R2 F'

> 2) what is a commutator?

A commutator is a permutation of the form X Y X' Y' My first
algorithm in the edge cycle was a commutator.

U S' U2 S D' S' U2 S D U'

Take away the U turns at the beginning and end, which are just a setup
moves, and you get:

S' U2 S D' S' U2 S D

X = S' U2 S
Y = D'

and put them together as X Y X' Y' to get (S' U2 S) (D') (S' U2 S) (D)

Also, looking back it would have been more efficient to have X=D Y=(M
U2 M') and in 2 less moves I would have had (D) (M U2 M') (D') (M U2
M') for the same cycle. Oh well, that's why I need to practice more I
guess.

> 3) do you first memorize the positions and then the orientation or
both at
> the same time?

No, Stefan's method does this which is why it's so fast, but I still
memorize the permutation and orientation separately. I memorize in
the order EP CP CO EO and solve in reverse.

> 4) how long are your delays between algorithms?

Not too long, for the solve above I must have delayed at most 3-4
seconds between my slowest algs. I tend to flow fairly nicely through
the execution at maybe 1.5-2 seconds between algs most times.

> 5) the night before the dutch cube day i invented the "hybrid system": i
> start with cycles and if there is a problem i switch to pochmann-system.
> each system has advantages and disadvantages and i want to use the best.
> what do you think about that?

I've thought about using Stefan's method for the corners, since I tend
to take a long time to execute the CO step. I think it sounds good,
but sadly I also have not tried Stefan's method as much as I should
have by now. I think I'll still give it a shot though, I really like
the idea of solving orientations and permutation together.

> thanks, thomas
>

Sure, hope this helps.
Chris

P.S. I tried your solve and it solved everything but left 4 of the
edges flipped in their correct places? Either way though I mean it
looks like a good strategy to me. Your solve felt like about the same
number of alg executions I use, but I mean I'm no expert compared to
the sub-2:00 guys. I think the solve looks ok personally.







33. Re: faster method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 2006 20:52:59 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Thomas Kohn" <thomas.kohn@g...> wrote: > > here is an example how i solve a 3x3x3 BLD: > > Scrambling (white on top, orange in front): D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2 F2 R B L' > B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2 F2 R U' How about... 52 moves for edges: (S D2 S') U (S D2 S') U' (M U' M') D2 (M U M') D2 R' (L' E' L) D2 (L' E L) D2 R E (L U2 L') E' (L U2 L') (R E2 R') U' (R E2 R') U 30 moves for corners: U2 (F L D2 L' F') U2 (F L D2 L' F') (B R B') L' (B R' B') L (D' R B2 R' D) (R D' B2 D R') Ok ok, 5 cubies are left with bad orientation but that's the fault of the scramble since I just don't like correctly placed but badly oriented pieces and there were three of them... > 1) how would you solve this example? Not like above :-) > 2) what is a commutator? Like above :-) Cheers! Stefan
34. Re: faster method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 2006 21:14:30 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote: > > > 3) do you first memorize the positions and then the orientation or > both at > > the same time? > > No, Stefan's method does this which is why it's so fast, [...] I disagree :-) Yes, I do think my method is somewhat fast but not because of memorization (in fact, I don't really consider memorization as part of "my method"). And only partly because I solve permutation and orientation at the same time. The real essential element is that I solve one piece at a time, making setup moves very easy, eliminating the need for thinking (which is the main reason my brain made me come up with the method, I think). Cheers! Stefan
35. Re: faster method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Jan 2006 21:34:13 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Thomas Kohn" > <thomas.kohn@g...> wrote: > > > > here is an example how i solve a 3x3x3 BLD: > > > > Scrambling (white on top, orange in front): D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2 > F2 R B L' > > B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2 F2 R U' > > How about... Mmh, that was wrong, actually it was 42 moves for edges, not 52. Here's now a complete solve with those damn five pieces oriented as well: 42 for edges: (S D2 S') U (S D2 S') U' (M U' M') D2 (M U M') D2 R' (L' E' L) D2 (L' E L) D2 R E (L U2 L') E' (L U2 L') (R E2 R') U' (R E2 R') U 12 for orienting edges: (R' U F' R U') S (U R' F U' R) S' 30 for corners: U2 (F L D2 L' F') U2 (F L D2 L' F') (B R B') L' (B R' B') L (D' R B2 R' D) (R D' B2 D R') 15 for orienting corners: (L2 U' L2 U L U' L U) (S2 L S L2 S' L S2) Total 99 moves... yaeh, sub100! Cheers! Stefan

From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>

Hey everyone,

like, but I would really like to make a 4x4x4 BLD video, including the
memorization. I figure anywhere from a high 12:xx to a high 14:xx
minute time for the video. How do I compress that to something that's
not ridiculously huge and manageable to put on a website (say
strangepuzzle?)

Thanks,
Chris

40. Re: I have a video now
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 06:58:28 -0000

What is your method for the 5x5x5 if I may ask? My centers are such a
mess, is there an easier execution?






41. Re: I have a video now
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 07:11:48 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@h...> wrote: > > What is your method for the 5x5x5 if I may ask? My centers are such a > mess, is there an easier execution? > Hey Marcus, I do the same as the 4x4 pretty much, I really just try to treat it as a 4x4x4 with +centers and central edges. I memorize as Xcenters +centers wing-edges central-edge-permutation CP CO EO and I solve in reverse. I handle parities as, 3x3x3 corner and central edge parity I save for the very, very end, after solving Xcenters. During the 3x3x3 solve I set them up for the T permutation and at the very end use the alg L' U' L U L F' L2 U L U L' U' L F f R U' B R' U f' b' U' R B' U R' b to solve the cube. I handle wing-edge parity by saving it until I have solved the plus centers. I then setup the wingedges to use this move to solve them: r2 B2 U2 l U2 r' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l' B2 r' l d2 l' r' U r l d2 l' r' U' This also swaps slU<->srU but I don't care since I've already solved them, and I'm swapping indistinct pieces of the same color. For centers I use a set of 24 nouns to memorize the Xcenters and make a story. For the +centers I use another set of 24 nouns to memorize them as a story that mimics my first set, but is completely non-overlapping. I really like the story method, and I like my nouns from the 4x4, so I just tried my best to come up with similar nouns that were still different enough to not let me switch stories during a solve. I use freestyle commutators to solve everything for the 5x5x5, except corners where I do my regular stuff from 3x3x3 supercube BLD. Not sure if that is helpful, but that's how I do it. I need to practice more, since I have only attempted the 5x5 4 times and got it successfully twice. It's very fun, but man oh man does 25 minutes seem like a long ways away for me right now. Hope that helps. Again not sure if my method even compares to whatever you're using, but I put a lot of thought into it before attempting a solve and I like doing it this way. I think I just need to practice more and get over my fear of trying to go fast during memorization. Chris

45. An idea for you naive orient-first guys
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 17:17:33 -0000

To those who orient corners first so that U/D stickers are all on U/D
faces: Why on earth do you do that?

Each corner *piece* and each corner *place* has a reference
sticker/side/direction/whateverYouWannaCallIt. A *piece* is called
"correctly oriented" iff its reference sticker is in the same
direction as that of the *place*. Now what you're doing is you define
the reference directions to be all on U and D.

What I suggest instead is to rotate all reference directions in the D
layer clockwise. That results in these rules for "correct
orientation":

- U corner in U layer must have U sticker on U face.
- D corner in D layer must have D sticker on D face.
- U corner in D layer must have U sticker clockwise from D face.
- D corner in U layer must have D sticker anticlockwise from U face.

The advantage of this is that any 3-cycle of corners that includes
both U and D layers (which is 75% of the time) is a simple 8-move
commutator.

Using the example Thomas posted...

Scramble:
D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2 F2 R B L' B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2
F2 R U'

Orient L-corners:
(U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L2

Orient R-corners:
(U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R

Permute corners:
(F' U' F) D' (F' U F) D
(R' D2 R) U2 (R' D2 R) U2
(R' D2 R) U (R' D2 R) U'

What do you think?

Cheers!
Stefan







46. Re: faster method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 17:20:06 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > CP: D2 L2 (x' L' U L' D2 L U' L' D2 x) D2 [cancelling the last L2 of the alg with the L2 from the setup] > D' (R B' R' B)*3 D [this is veeeeeeery cool] (25 moves) I hope not so cool anymore once you've seen my 24 moves solution :-) Cheers! Stefan

49. Re: An idea for you naive orient-first guys
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 17:41:13 -0000

Hey Stefan, Wow, I really like this idea. I also am starting to like using commutators much more often, and am starting to switch edges from U to D or vice versa via a commutator involving a S' U2 S or M U2 M' type move in it. Having said that I want to give your idea a try since it really won't take that much getting used to for memorizing corner orientation. The only thing I don't like is that now I can't use the (R' F R F')x3 move really anymore. Even though this move is long I've found that it lets me flow through the corner cycles very quickly (or at least it feels quickly to me, I'm still slower than the big names, so maybe that is my problem, using long moves). However, the plus side is that your way allows all the corner cycles to be easy commutators (which are all short!!). So I think I'll have an open mind and try a few blindfold solves your way, I think it definitely has potential, plus I just plain like commutators in general ;-) Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > To those who orient corners first so that U/D stickers are all on U/D > faces: Why on earth do you do that? > > Each corner *piece* and each corner *place* has a reference > sticker/side/direction/whateverYouWannaCallIt. A *piece* is called > "correctly oriented" iff its reference sticker is in the same > direction as that of the *place*. Now what you're doing is you define > the reference directions to be all on U and D. > > What I suggest instead is to rotate all reference directions in the D > layer clockwise. That results in these rules for "correct > orientation": > > - U corner in U layer must have U sticker on U face. > - D corner in D layer must have D sticker on D face. > - U corner in D layer must have U sticker clockwise from D face. > - D corner in U layer must have D sticker anticlockwise from U face. > > The advantage of this is that any 3-cycle of corners that includes > both U and D layers (which is 75% of the time) is a simple 8-move > commutator. > > Using the example Thomas posted... > > Scramble: > D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2 F2 R B L' B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2 > F2 R U' > > Orient L-corners: > (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L2 > > Orient R-corners: > (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R > > Permute corners: > (F' U' F) D' (F' U F) D > (R' D2 R) U2 (R' D2 R) U2 > (R' D2 R) U (R' D2 R) U' > > What do you think? > > Cheers! > Stefan >
50. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] An idea for you naive orient-first guys
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 15:22:30 -0300 (ART)

Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> escreveu: To those who orient corners first so that U/D stickers are all on U/D faces: Why on earth do you do that? >Well, I think I do that because that was the way >I learned from Macky's site...LOL...but, >seriously, I think that's because it's easier to >see the orientation pattern. I just search for >the brightest stickers on the corners, and >memorise the positions. Having U/D as reference >is good for this, since you don't have to check >if the corner is from U or D. How do you think >Tyson memorises everything in 50 seconds or >less?...hehe >But your idea sounds good, with some practice I >think it's worth...not sure...I need to practice >more BLD... >Pedro Each corner *piece* and each corner *place* has a reference sticker/side/direction/whateverYouWannaCallIt. A *piece* is called "correctly oriented" iff its reference sticker is in the same direction as that of the *place*. Now what you're doing is you define the reference directions to be all on U and D. What I suggest instead is to rotate all reference directions in the D layer clockwise. That results in these rules for "correct orientation": - U corner in U layer must have U sticker on U face. - D corner in D layer must have D sticker on D face. - U corner in D layer must have U sticker clockwise from D face. - D corner in U layer must have D sticker anticlockwise from U face. The advantage of this is that any 3-cycle of corners that includes both U and D layers (which is 75% of the time) is a simple 8-move commutator. Using the example Thomas posted... Scramble: D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2 F2 R B L' B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2 F2 R U' Orient L-corners: (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L2 Orient R-corners: (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R Permute corners: (F' U' F) D' (F' U F) D (R' D2 R) U2 (R' D2 R) U2 (R' D2 R) U (R' D2 R) U' What do you think? Cheers! Stefan SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 52. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: An idea for you naive orient-first guys
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 19:23:28 +0000 (GMT)

I think it's better now, right? Well, I think I do that because that was the way I learned from Macky's site...LOL...but, seriously, I think that's because it's easier to see the orientation pattern. I just search for the brightest stickers on the corners, and memorise the positions. Having U/D as reference is good for this, since you don't have to check if the corner is from U or D. How do you think Tyson memorises everything in 50 seconds or less?...hehe But your idea sounds good, with some practice I think it will be worth...not sure...I need to practice more BLD... Pedro Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> escreveu: Hi Pedro, please take a look at this: http://tinyurl.com/cgun2 Can we agree this is really really hard to read? Cheers! Stefan --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > > > Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@g...> escreveu: To those who orient corners first so that U/D stickers are all on U/D > faces: Why on earth do you do that? > > >Well, I think I do that because that was the way >I learned from Macky's site...LOL...but, >seriously, I think that's because it's easier to >see the orientation pattern. How do you think >Tyson memorises everything in 50 seconds or >less?...hehe > >But your idea sounds good, with some practice I >think it's worth...not sure...I need to practice >more BLD... > > >Pedro > > Each corner *piece* and each corner *place* has a reference > sticker/side/direction/whateverYouWannaCallIt. A *piece* is called > "correctly oriented" iff its reference sticker is in the same > direction as that of the *place*. Now what you're doing is you define > the reference directions to be all on U and D. > > What I suggest instead is to rotate all reference directions in the D > layer clockwise. That results in these rules for "correct > orientation": > > - U corner in U layer must have U sticker on U face. > - D corner in D layer must have D sticker on D face. > - U corner in D layer must have U sticker clockwise from D face. > - D corner in U layer must have D sticker anticlockwise from U face. > > The advantage of this is that any 3-cycle of corners that includes > both U and D layers (which is 75% of the time) is a simple 8-move > commutator. > > Using the example Thomas posted... > > Scramble: > D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2 F2 R B L' B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2 > F2 R U' > > Orient L-corners: > (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L2 > > Orient R-corners: > (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R > > Permute corners: > (F' U' F) D' (F' U F) D > (R' D2 R) U2 (R' D2 R) U2 > (R' D2 R) U (R' D2 R) U' > > What do you think? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! doce lar. FaÂ¤a do Yahoo! sua homepage. > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Yahoo! doce lar. FaÂ¤a do Yahoo! sua homepage.
53. Re: An idea for you naive orient-first guys
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 19:20:46 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote: > > The only thing I don't like is that now I can't use the (R' F R F') x3 > move really anymore. How do you like these? x' (U R U' R' U' R U' R' U2 R U' R' U' R U' R' U) x x' (R' U') (R' U R2 U' R' U R' U') (R' U R2 U' R' U) x Cheers! Stefan
54. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: An idea for you naive orient-first guys
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 19:21:46 +0000 (GMT)

yeah, it's really hard...much sorry...My yahoo puts a blue line on the left side of the previous message, so I put those > to separate what was my answer...but, well...the result was not good...: ) I'll do it again, on a more readable format... Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> escreveu: Hi Pedro, please take a look at this: http://tinyurl.com/cgun2 Can we agree this is really really hard to read? Cheers! Stefan --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > > > Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@g...> escreveu: To those who orient corners first so that U/D stickers are all on U/D > faces: Why on earth do you do that? > > >Well, I think I do that because that was the way >I learned from Macky's site...LOL...but, >seriously, I think that's because it's easier to >see the orientation pattern. I just search for >the brightest stickers on the corners, and >memorise the positions. Having U/D as reference >is good for this, since you don't have to check >if the corner is from U or D. How do you think >Tyson memorises everything in 50 seconds or >less?...hehe > >But your idea sounds good, with some practice I >think it's worth...not sure...I need to practice >more BLD... > > >Pedro > > Each corner *piece* and each corner *place* has a reference > sticker/side/direction/whateverYouWannaCallIt. A *piece* is called > "correctly oriented" iff its reference sticker is in the same > direction as that of the *place*. Now what you're doing is you define > the reference directions to be all on U and D. > > What I suggest instead is to rotate all reference directions in the D > layer clockwise. That results in these rules for "correct > orientation": > > - U corner in U layer must have U sticker on U face. > - D corner in D layer must have D sticker on D face. > - U corner in D layer must have U sticker clockwise from D face. > - D corner in U layer must have D sticker anticlockwise from U face. > > The advantage of this is that any 3-cycle of corners that includes > both U and D layers (which is 75% of the time) is a simple 8-move > commutator. > > Using the example Thomas posted... > > Scramble: > D' B2 L B' F' R' F' D2 F2 R B L' B' U F R U2 F R U2 L2 D' U F' L R' B2 > F2 R U' > > Orient L-corners: > (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L' (U' R U R')2 L2 > > Orient R-corners: > (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R (U L' U' L)2 R (L' U L U')2 R > > Permute corners: > (F' U' F) D' (F' U F) D > (R' D2 R) U2 (R' D2 R) U2 > (R' D2 R) U (R' D2 R) U' > > What do you think? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! doce lar. FaÂ¤a do Yahoo! sua homepage. > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 55. Re: An idea for you naive orient-first guys
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 19:38:14 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" > <foozman17@h...> wrote: > > > > The only thing I don't like is that now I can't use the (R' F R F') > x3 > > move really anymore. > > How do you like these? > > x' (U R U' R' U' R U' R' U2 R U' R' U' R U' R' U) x > x' (R' U') (R' U R2 U' R' U R' U') (R' U R2 U' R' U) x After practicing a bit, I think I like the first one better since there's not a single regrip. And it's very repetitive, the right hand always goes back and forth every second move, and the left hand pulls U' every other move, except those few occasions where the right hand instead pulls U. Modifying them a bit you also get more nice algs: (R U' R' U' R U' R' U2)2 ((L U' L2 U) (L U' L U))2 Cheers! Stefan
56. What was I thinking?
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 19:48:01 -0000

Hey everyone,

I started thinking today, and since I do my 5x5x5 central edges using
freestlye commutators, then why the heck do I still use regular
speedsolve 3 cycles for the 3x3x3 BLD for edges on a hard cycle?

I can definitely see some cases where a speedsolve move would be
faster, but some of my cases use 2 setups moves and a x2 cube
rotation, when I could just easily use an 8 move commutator.

Stefan actually your post about the new way to orient the corners got
me thinking about this. I've hit a plateau for the 3x3 with
speedsolve 3 cycles, I want to try to start using my usual commutators
in there for my harder cases and see if it helps.

heh heh I like the flow of ideas on this forum, it's really cool to
get a new idea from someone and try to see how it would help.

Not sure if this will work, but what's the harm in trying right?

Chris







57. Re: An idea for you naive orient-first guys
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2006 22:05:19 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > How do you like these? > > > > x' (U R U' R' U' R U' R' U2 R U' R' U' R U' R' U) x > > x' (R' U') (R' U R2 U' R' U R' U') (R' U R2 U' R' U) x > > After practicing a bit, I think I like the first one better since > there's not a single regrip. Ok I changed my mind again. The second alg is faster for me, it flows very well. I just got too confused initially because of the repetion. Hey Chris, are these good enough to be comparable to 3*(R B' R' B)? Cheers! Stefan
58. 4x4x4 BLD video
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 2006 03:10:16 -0000

Hey everyone,

Chris Hunt just posted the 4x4x4 BLD video I made to strangepuzzle.com
so feel free to check it out. It's in the BLD section on the site.

Here are the steps going back and looking at the video again:

Memorize centers: 4:08
Memorize edges: 7:17
Start solving: 8:33
Corners solved: 9:09
Edges solved: 12:58
cube solved: 15:39

Chris

63. Corner Permutation
From: "pig6464" <filsquatre@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 2006 18:08:59 -0000

I know how to number cycles but after that I have no clue what to do.
Can someone help me by supplying a few good algorithms and explaining
what do to with an example. Thanks






64. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Corner Permutation
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 2006 18:28:56 +0000 (GMT)

To permute the corners you can use: R B' R F2 R' B R F2 R2 (or x' R U' R D2 R' U R D2 R2 x) L' B L' F2 L B' L' F2 L2 (or x' L' U L' D2 L U' L' D2 L2 x) something like (R' F R F')*3 a PLL alg that swaps adjacent corner, 2 by 2, like: L U' R D2 R' U L' R U' L D2 L' U R' and several others Pedro pig6464 <filsquatre@...> escreveu: I know how to number cycles but after that I have no clue what to do. Can someone help me by supplying a few good algorithms and explaining what do to with an example. Thanks --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Yahoo! doce lar. FaÂ¤a do Yahoo! sua homepage.

Heh heh yeah sorry I should have been more specific on that list ;-
) Yeah corners was the last part, I took a long time to memorize
since if you mess up the corners but get everything else right, it's
still a DNF :-( (as you know of course, but that gets pretty
stressful for me when memorizing corners) :-)

>
> Hey, from 12:18 to 12:30 that's a parity fix I guess? Cause all of
a
> sudden you're twisting like a madman there...
>

heh heh yeah that was r l r2 B2 U2 l U2 r' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l' B2 r2
R L U2 L' R' U' R L U2 L' R' U' l' r' So a setup before hand (which
looking back on I could have combined moves at the start, but oh
well)

> Great achievement and great video, thanks!! Maybe you've motivated
me
> enough now to try 4x4, too...

Thanks, and you should! If you can do the megaminx BLD, which still
scares me btw :-P then you can definitely do the 4x4 in some low
times. It just took getting through the DNFs when first trying to
go fast to get my brain used to it, but it sounds to me that you're
already used to the crazy hard thinking so you might not even have
that.

66. Re: 4x4x4 BLD video
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 2006 19:47:56 -0000

Hey Pedro, Thanks, but it really isn't as hard as it might seem compared to 3x3 BLD, it just takes longer really. You should definitely try it, it's a lot of fun! For centers I use freestyle commutators, stuff like [r U2 r', d] [r U2 r', d2] [r' u r, U] [r' u r, U2] [U2, f' u2 f] Of course I also use setup moves to setup something like that if I have something weird. I do have one question for the group here, I always get slowed down by ending my centers solve with something like lbD<->rfU How do you guys do something like that? I would do lbD<->rfU l' [r d2 r', U'] l Is there a faster way? Maybe it's not as hard as I've been thinking and I just need to get over it confusing me for some reason. Chris P.S. Stefan what is your notation again to show a commutator with a setup move? Would l' [r d2 r', U'] l be [l : r d2 r', U'] ? --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Wow, that's just amazing...I reallly have to try someday...maybe when my 4x4x4 gets here...hehe > > But congratz, Chris, that's incredible > > I think you already said this, but what technique do you use for the centers? > > Pedro

69. Re: 4x4x4 BLD video
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 2006 23:10:58 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote: > > heh heh yeah that was r l r2 B2 U2 l U2 r' U2 r U2 F2 r F2 l' B2 r2 > R L U2 L' R' U' R L U2 L' R' U' l' r' So a setup before hand (which > looking back on I could have combined moves at the start, but oh > well) If you did centers before edges you could use: F2 (r U2 r U2) x (U2 r U2 l') x' (U2 l U2 r2) F2 Cheers! Stefan

71. Re: 4x4x4 BLD video
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 13 Jan 2006 23:24:33 -0000

> > I would do
> > lbD<->rfU
> > l' [r d2 r', U'] l
> >
> > Is there a faster way? Maybe it's not as hard as I've been
thinking
> > and I just need to get over it confusing me for some reason.
>
> [b2, r' F' r]
>

Oh wow I can't belive I never saw that! That's exactly how the
standard 3 corner cycles work too! R2 B2 R F R' B2 R F' R which is
just [R2 : B2, R F R']

heh heh "duuuuh" ok I feel stupid, but Stefan thanks for pointing
that out! I'll have to use that from now on.

> > P.S. Stefan what is your notation again to show a commutator
with a
> > setup move? Would l' [r d2 r', U'] l be [l : r d2 r', U'] ?
>
> If I remember correctly, yes :-)

Ok cool, just wanted to make sure I was doing it correctly. :-)

>
> Cheers!
> Stefan
>

Thanks again!
Chris

73. Re: test
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Jan 2006 00:36:03 -0000

I don't exactly remember what it was. Not a 404 or connection problem. It was a yahoo group special error message, something like "we don't know where you're coming from". Maybe it had to do with me opening two posts in different windows, then click "reply" on both, then had to log into both, then wrote and submitted both replies. So maybe it got confused between the separate windows and the logging in. No idea. If it ever happens again, I'll let you know. Now something slightly more interesting again: I've tried your edge-3-cycle-freeystyle again (sighted), I'm nowhere near your times but I'm getting better, now around 6 minutes and fewer errors. But I'm also trying to improve my own method, solving one edge at a time with the buffer/helper idea. The old way is setup the goal to FUr, apply the 3-cycle "swap" with 10 moves, then undo the setup moves. I'm trying without setup moves and 8-move 3-cycle "swaps" now. I'll let you know once I have some results (right now I'm still defining the algs). Cheers! Stefan --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@h...> wrote: > > Hey Stefan, > > I would be interested in hearing what happened to your posts and what > sort of errors you got? > > Although I prefer the yahoo groups for their e-mail capabilities, if > there is a big problem with them perhaps we should consider switching > them to a real forum. > > Chris > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > this is a test and if this message appears before my other two posts > > then that's proof how much yahoo groups suck cause it means the > error > > message for *both* of them was really serious. They suck, now I have > > to write both again, and I'll do it in a text editor... > > > > Stefan > > >
74. Re: 4x4x4 edges stuff
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Jan 2006 05:45:02 -0000

> Now something slightly more interesting again: I've tried your
> edge-3-cycle-freeystyle again (sighted), I'm nowhere near your times
> but I'm getting better, now around 6 minutes and fewer errors. But
I'm
> also trying to improve my own method, solving one edge at a time
with
> the buffer/helper idea. The old way is setup the goal to FUr, apply
> the 3-cycle "swap" with 10 moves, then undo the setup moves. I'm
> trying without setup moves and 8-move 3-cycle "swaps" now. I'll let
> you know once I have some results (right now I'm still defining the
> algs).

Hey Stefan,

I did another sighted average with my 4x4x4 BLD edges method. I did
it the way we did before, I solved the centers and corners as
referrence points, but I still solved parity as if the centers were
unsolved, same as I regularly do.

1:54.45 1:57.50 1:44.42 1:47.78 1:58.41 2:02.82 1:39.90 (2:13.49)
2:07.03 1:38.44 1:54.39 (1:28.94) = 1:52.51

I'm glad that I've gotten faster, but I'm still inconsistent with a
44.55 second spread. Ending with lots of odd cycles is faster for me
but still slow. I still use the (ABC) followed by (ADC) method to
solve all but the last if there is parity and I only ever use that
terrible parity alg once a solve, and then only if there is parity
obviously.

Again I would like to stress that this was a sighted average and that
I don't go quite that fast on real solves, since part of my time is
spent on recall and I can't transition from one cycle to the next as
fast as with my eyes open.

I think I still average pretty close to 1.0 for the setup moves.
Again often I do just one, sometimes I do 2 and just about as often as
2 I do none.

I use all the types of commutators before that I was like "Oh man I
need to learn that!" so I have a pretty varied toolbelt to draw from
now that I am also very used to using.

I personally really like this method, since it uses so many fewer
moves, and if practiced can be done quickly. However your method uses
less thought than mine by design and if it were equally as practiced
and with your dexterity for alg execution, I think it could probably
be equally as fast. I'm going to say that BLD for edges is probably
fast with either method if practiced well enough, so I don't find one
better than the other.

I hope your method works out as well as freestyle cycles, it feels
awesome to use your own idea. I don't know if I'm the first to try
freestyle cycles, but I think even if it has been invented that I have
added my own personal touch to it. Just for that reason I like using
my own personal version of it and will most likely just try to improve
it.

>
> Cheers!
> Stefan

Happy cubing, and god luck with your method! I hope it turns out to
be fast!

Chris

78. Re: Stefan Pochmann's Method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Jan 2006 23:08:42 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Anssi Vanhala" <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: > > I learned maybe half of them. I'm too lazy to think. My current BLD > method is (still) Stefan's T-PLL method with couple of edge and > corner orientation algs (if piece is in correct place but not > correctly oriented). Best time 2 min 58 s and almost always under 5 > min. Hey Anssi, please tell me you don't use my earliest version, i.e. the one with just a single alg (the T-perm)... For edges that's alright but for corners it sucks... I'm using this alg for corners now: (R U' R' U' R U R' F') (R U R' U' R' F R) You also get these helpful variants "for free": (R2 U' R' U' R U R' F') (R U R' U' R' F) (U' R' U' R U R' F') (R U R' U' R' F R2) And some more with nice flowing setup moves, e.g. F (R U' R' U' R U R' F') (R U R' U' R' F R) F' R' F (R U' R' U' R U R' F') (R U R' U' R' F R) F' R R2' F (R U' R' U' R U R' F') (R U R' U' R' F R) F' R2 But you're faster with my method than I am, so maybe I should shut up :-) Cheers! Stefan
79. Re: Stefan Pochmann's Method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 14 Jan 2006 23:11:19 -0000

Yes, you don't "need" to, but you *can*, because there are so few possibilities. Also, for edges every setup alg appears about every second solve, and for corners every third solve. So it's not *that* different every time. Cheers! Stefan --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > You don't need to learn setup moves. about!) and did it in 47:45.55. But my question is, it still takes me
forever to memorize and to solve compared to what I feel I should be
doing. I tend to memorize the 4x4 in anywhere from low 5 minutes to
high 7 minutes, so theoretically if I memorize the 4x4x4 within the
5x5x5 in 7 minutes say, then I should theoretically memorize the
+centers in 3 minutes and the central edges in 1:00 more I should be
done memorizing by 11:00-12:00 minutes, somewhere around there.

Well my solve today took me 23:22 to memorize. Marcus did his entire
solve in only about a minute and a half more so clearly I am wasting a
whole lot of time somewhere.

I still feel scared to go too fast for the 5x5x5 for both memorizing
and solving. Getting 45-50 minutes of quiet time to sit down and
memorize and solve without being disturbed is sort of rare for me.
Should I just try to get over this by going fast and just work through
the initial DNFs?

That was my strategy with the 4x4 pretty much, go slow at first to get
used to the method, then when I felt I had an ok grasp of it I started
to purposefully go really fast. I had to work through long strings of
DNFs but eventually I got to where that faster pace turned into my
normal pace and my accuracy came back.

Should I do this with the 5x5x5 too? Marcus how did you get so
incredibly fast at this? I mean I can see how the theory (11-12 min
for memorization and 11-12 min for the solve) can get to your time,
now I just need to get rid of my tremendous number of delays.

Dror, how do you memorize and solve so fast? I'm still a good 10
minutes at least from your solving times and don't know how to whittle
that time away.

Thanks in advance for any help,
Chris







82. Block method for 4x4x4 BLD centers
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 16 Jan 2006 16:27:42 -0000

Hey everyone,

I've recently started working on this, and have gotten a successful
BLD centers solve with it so far.

I just got a 13:09 DNF (grrrrr), but my mistake was in the edges and I
was only off by 3 edges in a cycle. For the centers I used a new
approach and it worked and they were solved.

Normally I always cycle a center to my next highest priority spot on
the given face (each of the four spots has a rank, and I can tell
which spots I am at when I cycle back to that face based on the last
noun I've used in that category).

Well this time I had a nice *almost* block transposition, so rather
than have to cycle all of those pieces around and waste the
opportunity, I used my center cycles to create the block transposition
and then solved it at the end. This shortened my main centers cycles
by 3 pieces, which sped up my memorization considerably.

Basically what I did was this, if I had had a green center at dfL I
would have been able to do the block cycle (dbL + dfL) <-> (dlF +
drF). So instead of cycling all those wrong pieces once the priority
got there on that face I cycled my first green piece to dfL and
created that block cycle. I then pretended the two blocks were solved
for the rest of my centers cycle. During the solve, I did the whole
main centers cycle first, then at the very end finished with:
[u (lr)2 u', L2]

I have used this strategy before if the blocks were already built, but
I have never changed my centers cycles in order to setup a block cycle
until now.

I think this is a great trick to speed up memorization for the 4x4x4,
I didn't check the time but it felt much faster than usual since I had
to create 3 less additions to my story with the nouns.

Anyway, I post this since I think it is an awesome trick to use for
the 4x4x4 centers, and I will definitely be using this in the future.

Hope this helps for you other 4x4x4 BLD'ers,
Chris

86. Blindfold help
From: "qqwref" <mzrg@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Jan 2006 00:51:04 -0000

Hello all... I've been here for a while, lurking, listening to your
interesting discussions... but I haven't actually tried to learn BLD
until recently.

Could someone help me out? I've read two or three blindfold manuals,
but I've still got a bunch of problems:
1) I haven't found a decent method for memorizing corner permutation
(note: I'm not a visual learner, I need #s). Could someone supply one?
2) I'm not familiar with Fridrich, so could someone provide an
explanation (or an algorithm) for the edge/corner permutation parity
switch other than "use the T perm" (what is that?!?)?
3) How do I keep track of setup moves? I keep messing up the entire
thing (and I'm still doing sighted solves, btw)...
4) Can someone please explain the corner orientation commutators? I
don't get those.

Would it be possible, anyway, for someone to provide a sample scramble
and the whole memorization/moves thing? I need an example...






87. 4x4x4 block centers cycling really works!!
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Jan 2006 04:01:38 -0000

Hey everyone,

I've been thinking about block centers cycling all day, and tonight I
purposefully did it on a solve where I normally wouldn't do anything
special. Man it works well!

I just got a successful 12:04.48 4x4x4 BLD solve using it too!

Again I created two clocks to be cycled at the very end for the
centers. If I had had a blue center piece at frU I would have had
the group cycle (frU + brU)<->(urB+drB).

So instead of cycling through the pieces like I usually do I cycled my
first blue piece in the cycle to frU and at the very end of my centers
solve I ended with
[l' (fb)2 l, B2] to solve the cube.

What makes this technique so nice is that it really speeds up the
centers memorization, and the solving goes a lot faster, since I cycle
4 pieces to their correct spot in 1 commutator.

The memorization for this solve took 5:25 (a very good time for me
usually, so this shows how block memorizing helps) and the solve was
about 6:40 which is also a very good solve for me too.

This is definitely my new method and I will try to actively search for
ways to form these blocks on every solve. If you have a row of two
same colored centers on the wrong face, then all you have to do is to
create a block on the face where it belongs and you have a block cycle.

Wow this technique rocks! I want to turn it into a common approach
rather than a trick to be used every now and then if possible.

Has anyone else tried it yet? It really does work nicely!

Chris







88. Re: Blindfold help
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 17 Jan 2006 04:41:33 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "qqwref" <mzrg@v...> wrote: > > Hello all... I've been here for a while, lurking, listening to your > interesting discussions... but I haven't actually tried to learn BLD > until recently. > > Could someone help me out? I've read two or three blindfold manuals, > but I've still got a bunch of problems: > 1) I haven't found a decent method for memorizing corner permutation > (note: I'm not a visual learner, I need #s). Could someone supply one? Hey, let me try to help out some. For corner permutation you can use the numbers 1-8. You could have a scheme such that say UBL=1 UBR=2 UFR=3 UFL=4 DBL=5 DBR=6 DFR=7 DFL=8 or of course any scheme you want. That works quite well for helping memorize. The scheme I use when I use numbers is this UBL=1 UBR=2 UFL=3 UFR=4 DBL=5 DBR=6 DFL=7 DFR=8 > 2) I'm not familiar with Fridrich, so could someone provide an > explanation (or an algorithm) for the edge/corner permutation parity > switch other than "use the T perm" (what is that?!?)? You want to use an algorithm that swaps two corners and two edges. The common one is the "T-perm" which is R U R' U' R' F R2 U' R' U' R U R' F' > 3) How do I keep track of setup moves? I keep messing up the entire > thing (and I'm still doing sighted solves, btw)... Say them outloud as you do them, or even before too. This way you use your auditory memory to help you remember them. So if my moves are F2 U then a three cycle, I'll say "F2 U" as I do the moves, and while doing the 3 cycle I think F2 U F2 U F2 U..... > 4) Can someone please explain the corner orientation commutators? I > don't get those. There are different algs, so here is my version to do this (but there are many). If all three corners flip the same way use this below. 1) move the UFL corner to UFR using U' 2) flip the corner using either (R U R' U' R U R') or (R' U R U' R' U R) depending on which direction it goes 3) move the next corner on the L face to UFL with L 4) move the new UFL corner to UFR with U' and then do either (R U R' U' R U R') or (R' U R U' R' U R) but do the same one as from #2 5) move the next L face corner to UFL with L 6) move UFL to UFR with U' and then do (R U R' U' R U R') or (R' U R U' R' U R) but again do the same as from #2 and #4 7) undo all your L turns with L2 To flip two corners opposite ways I use R' U2 R U R' U R L U2 L' U' L U' L' and its inverse. > > Would it be possible, anyway, for someone to provide a sample scramble > and the whole memorization/moves thing? I need an example... > I can work on writing out a solve, search in the archives maybe 50 messages back, there are 3-4 of us who did the same solve and wrote out how we did it. Hope that helps, Chris
