252. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Blindfold Solve video
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 22 Feb 2006 18:39:07 -0800

Hi Stefan, Thank you very much. My apologies for being too lazy to compress... but I uploaded the file onto strangepuzzle.com. Marcus, if you need a place to host your video, just use strangepuzzle.com. You can send your video to Chris Hunt by using yousendit.com or some other web service like that. Otherwise, if you want to transfer it to me, I'd be happy to upload it onto my web space. Just in case you forgot, the scramble is here: D2 U R U L' U D2 R U L' D B2 U' D L' B' R2 D2 B2 U2 F2 D' F2 L F How did you correct the edge parity? I did it in an inefficient manner, which explains my pause right before I corrected it. I was trying to think of something good, but then decided to give up on it for the sake of total time. I have a better way now but I'd be curious as to how you solved it. If you don't remember, I'm sure we can figure it out from the video you took. Tyson Mao Astrophysics '06 California Institute of Technology On Feb 22, 2006, at 5:24 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@. > ..> wrote: > > > > Hi Marcus, > > > > Is your video uploaded?  Here's mine: > > > > http://www.astro.caltech.edu/~tmao/111.09BLD.AVI > > > > 1 minute 51.09 seconds > > > > Tyson Mao > > Astrophysics '06 > > California Institute of Technology > > Same but only 1/12 the file size: > http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/111.09BLD.WMV > > Learn to compress, Tyson :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan
253. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] electroencephalogram
From: "Thomas Kohn" <thomas.kohn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 13:50:19 +0100 (MET)

hi guys! yesterday i did a successful BLD-solve while my brain waves were measured (EEG). i kept my eyes closed and didn't have to use a blindfold, because they see every single eye-movement and if you twinkle or not. in the first 20 seconds i calmed down and tried to think of nothing. during the memorization phase my eyes moved rapidly and the brain activity raised (i memorized for 2 minutes because i wantet to play it safe). during the solve (also 2 minutes) you can see that i needed one second of thinking, then i execute a move deep im my subconsciousness, while the activity goes down. a few seconds of thinking and then the next algorithm and so on. i don't know what we can learn out if it and if i could get faster by cubing during the EEG, but it was funny. i would lilke to check the differences between memorizing with numbers and with pictures. > --- UrsprÂ¤ngliche Nachricht --- > Von: "Thomas Kohn" <thomas.kohn@...> > An: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com > Betreff: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] electroencephalogram > Datum: Tue, 21 Feb 2006 14:23:54 +0100 (MET) > > hi guys! > > tomorrow i will do a BLD-solve while my brain activity is measured via > EEG. > i dont know if we can learn something out of the results, but it is fun. i > will post the video and the results as soon as i have them. > > thomas > > -- > 10 GB Mailbox, 100 FreeSMS/Monat http://www.gmx.net/de/go/topmail > +++ GMX - die erste Adresse fÂ¤r Mail, Message, More +++ > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > -- Lust, ein paar Euro nebenbei zu verdienen? Ohne Kosten, ohne Risiko! Satte Provisionen fÂ¤r GMX Partner: http://www.gmx.net/de/go/partner
254. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] electroencephalogram
From: "Sachin Shirwalkar" <sachinss@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:45:16 +0530

Hehe. nice move! Btw how did u do the actual ecg? do u go into some hospital or something? And are there any dnloadable images/movies that u can share with us? Sachin. On 2/23/06, Thomas Kohn <thomas.kohn@...> wrote: > hi guys! > > yesterday i did a successful BLD-solve while my brain waves were measured > (EEG). i kept my eyes closed and didn't have to use a blindfold, because > they see every single eye-movement and if you twinkle or not. in the first > 20 seconds i calmed down and tried to think of nothing. during the > memorization phase my eyes moved rapidly and the brain activity raised (i > memorized for 2 minutes because i wantet to play it safe). during the solve > (also 2 minutes) you can see that i needed one second of thinking, then i > execute a move deep im my subconsciousness, while the activity goes down. a > few seconds of thinking and then the next algorithm and so on. i don't know > what we can learn out if it and if i could get faster by cubing during the > EEG, but it was funny. i would lilke to check the differences between > memorizing with numbers and with pictures. > > > > > > --- Ursprüngliche Nachricht --- > > Von: "Thomas Kohn" <thomas.kohn@gmx.de> > > An: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com > > Betreff: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] electroencephalogram > > Datum: Tue, 21 Feb 2006 14:23:54 +0100 (MET) > > > > hi guys! > > > > tomorrow i will do a BLD-solve while my brain activity is measured via > > EEG. > > i dont know if we can learn something out of the results, but it is fun. i > > will post the video and the results as soon as i have them. > > > > thomas > > > > -- > > 10 GB Mailbox, 100 FreeSMS/Monat http://www.gmx.net/de/go/topmail > > +++ GMX - die erste Adresse für Mail, Message, More +++ > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > -- > Lust, ein paar Euro nebenbei zu verdienen? Ohne Kosten, ohne Risiko! > Satte Provisionen für GMX Partner: http://www.gmx.net/de/go/partner > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
255. I like the 3x3 speed corner cycle
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 17:26:45 -0000

The 3x3 speed corner cycle is awesome. I was inspired by it to find a
way to fix one of my worst edge cycles.

I use to hate seeing lUB -> lUF -> lDF but now I just use the same
idea as the corners cycle,

F' d F' U2 F d' F' U2 F2

:-D

I like that style of conjugate, having the conjugate move combine with
the first move of the commutator itself, so it condenses to 9 moves.
Not sure if anyone has tried that cycle, but I like it a lot. Works
for 5x5 too.

Chris






256. Re: Let's talk 3x3x3 corners
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 19:01:28 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Let's say I have the cycle (UBL -> DBL -> DBR) > > I used to use this move, D' B2 R F R' B2 R F' R' D If you used the orientation scheme I suggested a while ago, then you could use one of these: B' U' B D B' U B D' L' B R B' L B R' B' The latter can be nicely executed as: r' U R U' L U l' B' Cheers! Stefan
257. Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 19:35:51 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > Just wanted to post some recent times I was proud of: > > 3x3: 1:17:05 (give or take .25 seconds or so hitting the stop button) > 5x5: 27:02:34 > What was the break down between memorization and solve (if you remember) and also, do you have the scramble? It's very interesting for me to see these times because I recall you saying that your memorization time was between 15 and 25 seconds. Personally, my fastest memorization time is about 35 seconds and I had a 1:29 with that... but for an average solve, my break down is 50 and 70 (whereas Leyan is 60 and 60). In other words, out memorization and execution are much more closely matched whereas your memorization is far faster than your execution. Are you having a lot of delays during your solve as a result of very quick memorization? I think I could memorize the cube in 25 seconds, but it would take me time to reconstruct stuff in my head. If you have the scramble, it would be interesting for me to see what I could do on this solve.
258. Sub-30!!!!!!
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 20:43:23 -0000

Hey everyone,

I finally managed a sub-30 solve for the 5x5x5 BLD :-D The time was
28:57.40 :-D

Memorization took right at 16:00 (or very close at least) so the solve
time was about 12:50 something probably.

Very glad to have joined the sub-30 club :-) Also, look out Marcus,
25 minutes still seems very fast to me, but not impossible anymore ;-)

Chris







259. Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 20:49:40 -0000

The 1:17 solve had no edge orientation issues and had three/four
edges solved already. Memorization was about 22 seconds. My
memorization times are not normally this low -- I'd say on average
it takes me maybe 25-30 seconds for an average solve. 15 is the
lower bound and usually occurs around cases with more obvious visual
patterns that stand out (for instance, in a corner orientation case
looks kinda like a Sune, etc).

My execution time is indeed slow because of wrist pain. I used to
have a speedsolving average of about 15 or so seconds but that
quickly shot back down to around 30 or 35, where I am now actually.
My fingers and hands just hurt like hell trying to do fast finger
tricks (there is also a lot of shaking in my fingers). A lot of
this probably has to do with my DDR playing (sometimes I like to
play really hard songs on the keyboard). You've seen my PSMO video
so you can see how hard it is on the hands (if you look at them in
action). Over time this has probably caused damage so I'm staying
away from damaging my hands in whatever ways I can. The damaged
hands was the sole reason in the first place why I attempted to find
better memory methods.

And no I don't happen to have the scramble, I didn't keep it.
Furthermore I need a battery to access my camera, I can't access it
otherwise even with the USB connector; it just doesn't turn on.
I'll probably do a search on Ebay or something.


> What was the break down between memorization and solve (if you
remember) and also, do
> you have the scramble? It's very interesting for me to see these
times because I recall you
> saying that your memorization time was between 15 and 25 seconds.
Personally, my
> fastest memorization time is about 35 seconds and I had a 1:29
with that... but for an
> average solve, my break down is 50 and 70 (whereas Leyan is 60 and
60). In other words,
> out memorization and execution are much more closely matched
whereas your
> memorization is far faster than your execution. Are you having a
lot of delays during your
> solve as a result of very quick memorization?
>
> I think I could memorize the cube in 25 seconds, but it would take
me time to reconstruct
> stuff in my head. If you have the scramble, it would be
interesting for me to see what I
> could do on this solve.
>

261. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 13:19:49 -0800

Wait a second....

So what type of method are you using? If your execution is slow
because of hand pain, but your memorization is about 25-30 seconds,
that would still mean 60 seconds for execution. Leyan's execution is
about 60 seconds, and my execution is about the same speed, maybe
slightly slower. If you look at the video of my solve, I have a few
pauses here and there, but generally the moves I'm doing take a good
amount of dexterity. Leyan, on the other hand, will do 60 seconds or
less on execution, but he's making the same number of moves as me, and
he's just not pausing.

In other words, if your speed solve goes from 15 seconds and increases
to 30 seconds, it seems like you're making moves twice as slowly as
before. I would think that your maximum hand speed is about the same
as Leyan who has recorded 15.1x averages in competition, so if you're
executing the moves on the cube in 60 seconds for the blindfold method,
your method must take half as many moves.

What method are you using?

Tyson Mao
Astrophysics '06
California Institute of Technology

264. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 13:38:55 -0800

You've forgotten F2L algorithms? Aren't almost all but two of them practically intuitive? In other words, someone who has cubed as much as you to get a 15.15 average should certainly be able to manufacture F2L algorithms on the fly. Tyson Mao Astrophysics '06 California Institute of Technology On Feb 23, 2006, at 1:27 PM, kyuubree wrote: > I wouldn't say my handspeed has gone down by half -- I can still do > a fair amount of moves quickly, but it just hurts to do so.  For > speedcubing I use the Fridrich method but I don't know all of > OLL/PLL/nifty F2L algs anymore.    > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > <tmao@...> wrote: > > > > Wait a second.... > > > > So what type of method are you using?  If your execution is slow > > because of hand pain, but your memorization is about 25-30 > seconds, > > that would still mean 60 seconds for execution.  Leyan's execution > is > > about 60 seconds, and my execution is about the same speed, maybe > > slightly slower.  If you look at the video of my solve, I have a > few > > pauses here and there, but generally the moves I'm doing take a > good > > amount of dexterity.  Leyan, on the other hand, will do 60 seconds > or > > less on execution, but he's making the same number of moves as me, > and > > he's just not pausing. > > > > In other words, if your speed solve goes from 15 seconds and > increases > > to 30 seconds, it seems like you're making moves twice as slowly > as > > before.  I would think that your maximum hand speed is about the > same > > as Leyan who has recorded 15.1x averages in competition, so if > you're > > executing the moves on the cube in 60 seconds for the blindfold > method, > > your method must take half as many moves. > > > > What method are you using? 265. Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 21:44:18 -0000

Honestly my F2L is fine -- it's just the LL. Those aren't intuitive to me and I needed algs to do them. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > > You've forgotten F2L algorithms? Aren't almost all but two of them > practically intuitive? 266. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 14:13:58 -0800

Oh yeah, that's definitely true. So how do you still solve the cube? I'm guessing if you come across an OLL you don't know, you just do something twice, like (R U F U' R' F') until you get an algorithm that you do know, and for PLL, you just use A-perms to fix the corners and things like that? Are you using BLD moves that you haven't forgot as well? The reason I ask is that if your hand speed is still the same and you still have all of your F2L, then your times shouldn't really drop from 15 to 30... F2L is the main component of any speed solve, and using a four-look LL, I can still average under 20. Are you using BLD algorithms to put everything in place gradually which accounts for the 15 seconds extra it's taking you to solve the cube? Tyson Mao Astrophysics '06 California Institute of Technology On Feb 23, 2006, at 1:44 PM, kyuubree wrote: > Honestly my F2L is fine -- it's just the LL.  Those aren't intuitive > to me and I needed 267. Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:16:43 -0000

Hey everybody,

It has been a while since I did anything with blindfold cubing... But
did any of the top-blindfold cubers try Stefan Pochmanns method? And
what do you think about it?

I personally believe that it will be faster that the OE/PE strategy,
if you can learn to use three cycles and still do
orientation/permuation at the same time... And I would just love to
see a top-blindfold cuber try that.

I haven't done it in a while, but maybe I have some ideas to expand my
system of memorisation... I'll try that soon.

- Joël.






268. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:20:11 -0000

I just meant this the edges OE/PE strategy by the way! I still don't know about the corners! --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > Hey everybody, > > It has been a while since I did anything with blindfold cubing... But > did any of the top-blindfold cubers try Stefan Pochmanns method? And > what do you think about it? > > I personally believe that it will be faster that the OE/PE strategy, > if you can learn to use three cycles and still do > orientation/permuation at the same time... And I would just love to > see a top-blindfold cuber try that. > > I haven't done it in a while, but maybe I have some ideas to expand my > system of memorisation... I'll try that soon. > > - Joël. >
269. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:21:34 -0000

Hey Joel, I'm currently working on a similar approach, inspired by Stefan's method, for 5x5x5 central edges (and thus also 3x3x3 edges). My plan is to use commutators and setup moves to solve orientation and permutation at the same time for two pieces per cycle. So I would correctly permute and orient 2 pieces for each three cycle, then let the 3rd edge just make it a possible cycle. Then at the end I might have to flip a few edges, but there would not be much work left to do either way. Not sure if that qualifies exactly as Stefan's method, but it is heavily inspired by his method. I'm not sure how fast it would be for 3x3x3, but it would save me a lot of moves for the 5x5x5, since my edge flip algs are very slow to execute. Not sure if this is what you're asking for, but it is something inspired very strongly by ideas form Stefan. Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > Hey everybody, > > It has been a while since I did anything with blindfold cubing... But > did any of the top-blindfold cubers try Stefan Pochmanns method? And > what do you think about it? > > I personally believe that it will be faster that the OE/PE strategy, > if you can learn to use three cycles and still do > orientation/permuation at the same time... And I would just love to > see a top-blindfold cuber try that. > > I haven't done it in a while, but maybe I have some ideas to expand my > system of memorisation... I'll try that soon. > > - Joël. >
270. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 14:24:23 -0800

Oik... the only "top BLD" cuber that uses Stefan's method is Jean Pons
I believe... and by "top," I guess I mean under 2:30. But yeah, he did
a low 2-minute solve at worlds so I know times like those are
definitely possible with the Pochmann method.

No offense to Stefan's method... Leyan and I just hand around Macky a
lot so we learned by diffusion.

Tyson Mao
Astrophysics '06
California Institute of Technology

271. Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:24:51 -0000

You pretty much have it down -- I use algs I know until I see a case I remember. I generally only use blindfold algs for the LL if they only deal with sets of pieces that are identical (eg all edges, all corners). I just tried speedsolving and got 24 seconds so I am not actually so far down the line, but the last layer eats up a lot of my time. I really can't say where the time is going -- it's not just one factor but the sum of many, and the times are a lot different if I happen to remember or not remember a certain OLL or PLL case. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > > Oh yeah, that's definitely true. So how do you still solve the cube? > I'm guessing if you come across an OLL you don't know, you just do > something twice, like (R U F U' R' F') until you get an algorithm that > you do know, and for PLL, you just use A-perms to fix the corners and > things like that? Are you using BLD moves that you haven't forgot as > well? > > The reason I ask is that if your hand speed is still the same and you > still have all of your F2L, then your times shouldn't really drop from > 15 to 30... F2L is the main component of any speed solve, and using a > four-look LL, I can still average under 20. Are you using BLD > algorithms to put everything in place gradually which accounts for the > 15 seconds extra it's taking you to solve the cube? > > Tyson Mao > Astrophysics '06 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 23, 2006, at 1:44 PM, kyuubree wrote: > > > Honestly my F2L is fine -- it's just the LL.Â  Those aren't intuitive > > to me and I needed algs to do them. > > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > > <tmao@> wrote: > > > > > > You've forgotten F2L algorithms?Â  Aren't almost all but two of > > them > > > practically intuitive?Â  In other words, someone who has cubed as > > much > > > as you to get a 15.15 average should certainly be able to > > manufacture > > > F2L algorithms on the fly. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > Astrophysics '06 > 272. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 14:28:26 -0800

What happened to taking your midterm? Quick test? Tyson Mao Astrophysics '06 California Institute of Technology On Feb 23, 2006, at 2:24 PM, kyuubree wrote: > You pretty much have it down -- I use algs I know until I see a case > I remember.  I generally only use blindfold algs for the LL if they > only deal with sets of pieces that are identical (eg all edges, all > corners). I just tried speedsolving and got 24 seconds so I am not > actually so far down the line, but the last layer eats up a lot of > my time.  I really can't say where the time is going -- it's not > just one factor but the sum of many, and the times are a lot > different if I happen to remember or not remember a certain OLL or > PLL case.  > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > <tmao@...> wrote: > > > > Oh yeah, that's definitely true.  So how do you still solve the > cube?  > > I'm guessing if you come across an OLL you don't know, you just do > > something twice, like (R U F U' R' F') until you get an algorithm > that > > you do know, and for PLL, you just use A-perms to fix the corners > and > > things like that?  Are you using BLD moves that you haven't forgot > as > > well? > > > > The reason I ask is that if your hand speed is still the same and > you > > still have all of your F2L, then your times shouldn't really drop > from > > 15 to 30... F2L is the main component of any speed solve, and > using a > > four-look LL, I can still average under 20.  Are you using BLD > > algorithms to put everything in place gradually which accounts for > the > > 15 seconds extra it's taking you to solve the cube? > > > > Tyson Mao > > Astrophysics '06 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 23, 2006, at 1:44 PM, kyuubree wrote: > > > > > 273. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:30:18 -0000

That's not an answer to my question. YOU are a top-BLD cuber, and I was wondering what you think about it. I mean, doing the edges by first orient them, and permute them next... Don't you think that's a waste of your own potential? Or am I wrong? - Joël. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > > Oik... the only "top BLD" cuber that uses Stefan's method is Jean Pons > I believe... and by "top," I guess I mean under 2:30. But yeah, he did > a low 2-minute solve at worlds so I know times like those are > definitely possible with the Pochmann method. > > No offense to Stefan's method... Leyan and I just hand around Macky a > lot so we learned by diffusion. > > Tyson Mao > Astrophysics '06 > California Institute of Technology > > On Feb 23, 2006, at 2:16 PM, JoÃ«l van Noort wrote: > > > Hey everybody, > > > > It has been a while since I did anything with blindfold cubing... 274. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:30:35 -0000

Well.. I wasn't really asking for this, but it's nice to hear anyway :). --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Hey Joel, > > I'm currently working on a similar approach, inspired by Stefan's > method, for 5x5x5 central edges (and thus also 3x3x3 edges). > > My plan is to use commutators and setup moves to solve orientation and > permutation at the same time for two pieces per cycle. So I would > correctly permute and orient 2 pieces for each three cycle, then let > the 3rd edge just make it a possible cycle. Then at the end I might > have to flip a few edges, but there would not be much work left to do > either way. > > Not sure if that qualifies exactly as Stefan's method, but it is > heavily inspired by his method. > > I'm not sure how fast it would be for 3x3x3, but it would save me a > lot of moves for the 5x5x5, since my edge flip algs are very slow to > execute. > > Not sure if this is what you're asking for, but it is something > inspired very strongly by ideas form Stefan. > > Chris > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@> wrote: > > > > Hey everybody, > > > > It has been a while since I did anything with blindfold cubing... But > > did any of the top-blindfold cubers try Stefan Pochmanns method? And > > what do you think about it? > > > > I personally believe that it will be faster that the OE/PE strategy, > > if you can learn to use three cycles and still do > > orientation/permuation at the same time... And I would just love to > > see a top-blindfold cuber try that. > > > > I haven't done it in a while, but maybe I have some ideas to expand my > > system of memorisation... I'll try that soon. > > > > - Joël. > > >
275. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 14:36:01 -0800

Oh... sorry Joel, I didn't read your message that carefully. I personally haven't tried Stefan's method. One reason is that I don't understand it completely, but part of that is because I haven't spent the time to study it. I've been so lazy lately in terms of practicing because, well, when you cube for a public audience, (i.e., in front of hot girls) your times don't matter. These last few days I've been getting back into the groove of things and I think my times are strong again. No more of these DNF, DNF, 2:40 competitions :-P. Georgia 3/11 should be better. Anyway, it seems that Stefan's method can be very powerful. Perhaps the utilization of 2-cycles as opposed to 3-cycles gives less delays during the execution. One question which I'm not sure about is the ease in memory. I can generally memorize the edge permutation by my method in under 20 seconds... I wonder what it would increase to? One thing to keep in mind is that edge orientation memorization takes maybe 2 to 3 seconds, and edge orientation execution takes another 3 to 5 seconds... so I'm not sure how much you save. Time to run. Yay! Cube mile anyone? Well... hmm... I should look into it. I might e-mail some of you guys for help, but my idea is that if I can memorize the edges using Stefan's method in under 25 seconds, then the payoff is worth it. Otherwise, I'm not sure, because edge orientation in our method is so trivial to deal with. It literally is "glance, put on blindfold, execute"... many times just one setup move plus one algorithm... 276. Re: Memorization
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:40:14 -0000

> I need a better technique, but 'spiderman-banana-abacus' doesn't
> appeal to me.
>
> ~Thom
>

Haha...

This thread is really making me think about where I can improve my
memorisation. I basically use 24 letters for the edges (letters that
are connected to words like 'Donald duck' yes). And a while ago, I
got to the point where I could instantly convert cubies into letters
and vice versa. However, memorising a sequence of letters was
actually quite timeconsuming (allthough I was getting better a
little while ago), so I was thinking about a system to make a story
with them... Of course, this can slow me down too, but if I
can 'standardise' the story, I don't have to make the whole thing up
on the fly... So maybe that would work...

Or maybe I should just memorise the first 5 letters, and think 'this
pattern, that pattern' for the rest ;). I know Jean Pons memorised 7
objects, and does the rest with numbers, because he says 7 objects
are not hard to memorise...

- Joël.






277. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 22:51:00 -0000

Hey Tyson Well, breaking up the 3 cycles into 2-cycles is not the power of the method... I actually suspect you will have to use three cycles to make it more powerfull than what you do now. I definately think memorisation of the whole permutation can be done in the same time as you memorise your permutation. I remember Dror Vomberg told me there is too much information to memorise if you do orientation and permutation in one go, but I actually think you memorise less information... You memorise the same amount of info as you memorise for the permutation only, not more than that. So I predict you save at least 7 (that is 5+2) seconds on the edges orientation. It will however take time to develop a nice system of memorisation (you'll need 24 numbers, or 'objects') and it will take time to get used to doing it in three cycles... The reason for this post is just that I would love to see a top BLD cuber try it, so one person can compare both methods. - Joël. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > > Oh... sorry Joel, > > I didn't read your message that carefully. I personally haven't tried > Stefan's method. One reason is that I don't understand it completely, > but part of that is because I haven't spent the time to study it. I've > been so lazy lately in terms of practicing because, well, when you cube > for a public audience, (i.e., in front of hot girls) your times don't > matter. These last few days I've been getting back into the groove of > things and I think my times are strong again. No more of these DNF, > DNF, 2:40 competitions :-P. Georgia 3/11 should be better. > > Anyway, it seems that Stefan's method can be very powerful. Perhaps > the utilization of 2-cycles as opposed to 3-cycles gives less delays > during the execution. One question which I'm not sure about is the > ease in memory. I can generally memorize the edge permutation by my > method in under 20 seconds... I wonder what it would increase to? > > One thing to keep in mind is that edge orientation memorization takes > maybe 2 to 3 seconds, and edge orientation execution takes another 3 to > 5 seconds... so I'm not sure how much you save. > > Time to run. Yay! Cube mile anyone? > > Well... hmm... I should look into it. 278. Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:08:03 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > I used to > have a speedsolving average of about 15 or so seconds but that > quickly shot back down to around 30 or 35, where I am now actually. Can you tell how long ago you had that 15 seconds average? Cheers! Stefan
279. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:19:34 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@. ..> wrote: > > I personally haven't tried Stefan's method. One reason is > that I don't understand it completely It's real easy, the core idea is just: "Solve one piece at a time." That's the simplest most natural idea that comes to my mind after thinking that for blindsolving, you want to go in very small steps. Doing orientation and permutation together is inherent and natural in this idea, or in other words: even thinking about these two issues as separate issures is unnatural (for my idea). So yeah, solving two pieces at a time could be called an extension of my method, but on the other hand it breaks with the core idea. It does share the aspect of doing orientation and permutation together, but actually that's only noticed by people who think of them separately. So for me this shared aspect isn't even really noticable, but the difference of solving two pieces instead of one is. > One thing to keep in mind is that edge orientation memorization takes > maybe 2 to 3 seconds, and edge orientation execution takes another 3 to > 5 seconds... so I'm not sure how much you save. In addition to not doing orientation separately, it might also save time for setup moves. With the orient-first strategy, you need to setup pieces with a certain orientation. Actually of course it depends on how you execute both methods, particularly whether you setup pieces to certain standard positions or do completely free-style cycles like Chris does for 4x4 edges. Cheers! Stefan
280. Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:22:04 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > You've seen my PSMO video > so you can see how hard it is on the hands (if you look at them in > action). Gah, forgot this one... so what's PSMO, and is the video still available somewhere? Cheers! Stefan
281. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:33:49 -0000

Hey Stefan, Actually Stefan, this is really a funny post to me... > It's real easy, the core idea is just: > "Solve one piece at a time." Haha... I was almost going to say: 'You are sooo wrong about that!'. But of course, it's your method, so you must be right.. Right? Well, actually, with the traditional cycle method, I solved one piece at a time when I did the corners. In my view, the essential new thing of your method is NOT solving 1 piece at the time, but losing the orientation, because it is an unnesecary burden. As you say, there's no need to think about orientations. Even when the piece is in place. It's just that most of us (including me) think of it that way! > Actually of course it depends > on how you execute both methods, particularly whether you setup pieces > to certain standard positions or do completely free-style cycles like > Chris does for 4x4 edges. Hmm.. I haven't been following this group, so I am not sure what you mean by free-style cycles... But it sounds funny :). - Joël. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@ > ..> wrote: > > > > I personally haven't tried Stefan's method. One reason is > > that I don't understand it completely > > It's real easy, the core idea is just: > "Solve one piece at a time." > > That's the simplest most natural idea that comes to my mind after > thinking that for blindsolving, you want to go in very small steps. > > Doing orientation and permutation together is inherent and natural in > this idea, or in other words: even thinking about these two issues as > separate issures is unnatural (for my idea). > > So yeah, solving two pieces at a time could be called an extension of > my method, but on the other hand it breaks with the core idea. It does > share the aspect of doing orientation and permutation together, but > actually that's only noticed by people who think of them separately. > So for me this shared aspect isn't even really noticable, but the > difference of solving two pieces instead of one is. > > > One thing to keep in mind is that edge orientation memorization > takes > > maybe 2 to 3 seconds, and edge orientation execution takes another 3 > to > > 5 seconds... so I'm not sure how much you save. > > In addition to not doing orientation separately, it might also save > time for setup moves. With the orient-first strategy, you need to > setup pieces with a certain orientation. Actually of course it depends > on how you execute both methods, particularly whether you setup pieces > to certain standard positions or do completely free-style cycles like > Chris does for 4x4 edges. > > Cheers! > Stefan >
282. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:38:04 -0000

Ok, lets take a sample solve of however you want this done.

Algo Scramble 3x3: F D U' R D B2 U2 R D2 B2 R' D2 F R2 L2 D2 L2 D L2
U2 R' F' R B R'

d'L' (F2UM'U2MUF2) Ld
FL2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) L2F'
B2U2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) U2B2
M'L (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) L'M
d2L'y2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) y2Ld2

Maybe this is a lucky case, but no more than two setup moves on this?
That's amazingly good. I think corners should still be done
traditionally, though.

I agree that it's just like memorising permutation on it's own. I
memorise faster by remembering orientation + permutation together than
if I remember just the permutation. It's probibly the way I memorise,
though.

> (you'll need 24 numbers, or 'objects')

not if you're cool and use patterns ;) Seriously, I belive patterns
eliminate a further level of memorisation.

I shall try a few solves of this method tomorrow and see what becomes
of it.

~Thom






283. Looking for advice for freestlying EO+EP
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:38:40 -0000

Hey everyone,

Let me just state from the start that my purpose in using this
approach if for the 5x5x5 central edges. I'm not interested in making
the new fastest approach for 3x3 edges ever, I don't even know if it
could be done. I like it because it uses fewer moves than my current
approach for the 5x5x5 central edges.

Ok with that disclaimer, I am going to show this on a 3x3x3 cube, even
though it's purpose is to be used on the 5x5x5.

Do the scramble: L' B' F2 U' D2 R B R B2 D2 U L2 U L R D F D' B R D2
R2 L' D' B

After doing this scramble the edge permutation is even, so I will
solve the edges ignoring the corners.

To solve the edges with this new approach I am going to use freestlye
commutators to perform 3 cycles, and each 3 cycle will completely
solve two pieces.

Step 1:
UB -> UR -> DR and UR needs to flip before cycling to DR.

To do this I would do D' F U R E2 R' U' R E2 R' F' D

I don't care how this moves the DR edge to UB, all I care is to
memorize how the DR edges ends up at UB.

Ok so now I have solved UR and DR. Now I have UB -> DF -> DB and DF
needs to flip before going to DB.

To do this I would do U2 B' L' M' U2 M D M' U2 M D' L B U2

Ok now I have DF and DB solved. Next I start with UB and continue.

I have UB <-> FR and UB needs to flip before going to FR. I'll save
this till the end instead of doing it now.

Next I'll start looking at UL and see how the cycles from there go.

So I have UL -> DL -> FL and I need to flip UL before placing it in DL.

To do this I would do: F' L' E L D' L' E' L D F

Now I start over at UL and move on
UL -> BR -> UF and I need to flip UL before placing in BR.

To do this I do: F R S D2 S' U2 S D2 S' U2 R' F'

Now I have that UL <-> BL and I need to flip UL before placing in BL.

So now I have two transpositions left, which I'll do as two 3 cycles.

So to do the first three cycle, I only need to solve 1 piece
correclty. I'll place UL -> BL -> FR and placing BL to FR will be my
side effect.

To do UL -> BL -> FR I do: E2 R U2 R' E2 R U2 R'

Now all I have is UB -> FR -> UL and FL needs to flip before going to
UB and UB needs to flip before going to FR.

To do this I do: B U L B E2 B' U B E2 B' U' L' U' B'

--------

So step by step I did this:
1) D' F U R E2 R' U' R E2 R' F' D
2) U2 B' L' M' U2 M D M' U2 M D' L B U2
3) F' L' E L D' L' E' L D F
4) F R S D2 S' U2 S D2 S' U2 R' F'
5) E2 R U2 R' E2 R U2 R'
6) B U L B E2 B' U B E2 B' U' L' U' B'

If you made it this far, first off congratulations, I don't expect
many people will have read this far. If you did read this far, my
thoughts on this method are are that for the 5x5x5 central edges it is
awesome. It is far fewer moves then first flipping and then moving
edges. Also it will speed up my memorization in that I memorize the
edge cycles by sticker to also include orientation as well as permutation.

I guess my question is, should I memorize the cycles the same way as
Stefan does, by stickers as well as by where the pieces go? Meaning I
think that the U sticker of UB goes to the D sticker of DF rather than
UB goes to DF?

Also, I've been thinking about the setup moves, and because I can do
the commutators any way I want, setup moves might only be to flip one
edge, then do a usual commutator, then at the end unflip that edge.
So setup moves might average about 3 per cycle, which is not bad.
With a rigid system I think it will be very fast.

So anyway, this is what I'm in the process of learning. Does any
other 5x5 BLD'er have any comments? Also do any of you 3x3 guys have
any interest in a system like this? My guess is not really, probably
absolutely not for you top cubers, but I thought I would ask in case
anyone is interested.

Chris







284. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:52:07 -0000

Hi, Yeah.. Thats my idea of solving.. There are a lot of nice special cases where you can easily solve 2 edges in one alg, often with few setup moves. > Ok, lets take a sample solve of however you want this done. > > Algo Scramble 3x3: F D U' R D B2 U2 R D2 B2 R' D2 F R2 L2 D2 L2 D L2 > U2 R' F' R B R' > > d'L' (F2UM'U2MUF2) Ld > FL2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) L2F' For the last one, I would do another 'commutator' aproach. The firs target is DL, the second target is LF. I setup the second target on the bottom: F'U (D M'U2M D' M'U2M) U'F There are a lot of funny commutators that you can use for this... Not only the standard U permutations ;). --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...> wrote: > > Ok, lets take a sample solve of however you want this done. > > Algo Scramble 3x3: F D U' R D B2 U2 R D2 B2 R' D2 F R2 L2 D2 L2 D L2 > U2 R' F' R B R' > > d'L' (F2UM'U2MUF2) Ld > FL2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) L2F' > B2U2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) U2B2 > M'L (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) L'M > d2L'y2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) y2Ld2 > > Maybe this is a lucky case, but no more than two setup moves on this? > That's amazingly good. I think corners should still be done > traditionally, though. > > I agree that it's just like memorising permutation on it's own. I > memorise faster by remembering orientation + permutation together than > if I remember just the permutation. It's probibly the way I memorise, > though. > > > (you'll need 24 numbers, or 'objects') > > not if you're cool and use patterns ;) Seriously, I belive patterns > eliminate a further level of memorisation. > > I shall try a few solves of this method tomorrow and see what becomes > of it. > > ~Thom >
285. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:51:49 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > In my view, the essential new thing of your method is NOT solving 1 > piece at the time, but losing the orientation, because it is an > unnesecary burden. Hmm... like I said, my main concern is to make it easy and thus the idea "solve one piece at a time". This then *includes* the aspect of orienting and permuting together. The only methods I had seen before inventing mine were Richard Carr's and Oliver Hayden's, both orient and permute separately and work on more than one piece at a time. Were there any others? If not, then indeed both the single-piece and the complete-solve ideas were "new", though I really tend to think of the latter being included in the former. > Hmm.. I haven't been following this group, so I am not sure what you > mean by free-style cycles... But it sounds funny :). I myself have a very strict way, I do 2-cycles and one piece is always the UR edge (for edges) or the ULB corner (for corners). And I use setup moves to bring pieces to standard positions. Now imagine just the opposite, i.e. no fixed included pieces (cycling *any* three pieces) and no setup moves except necessary for a core cycle (in Chris's case, an 8-move edges-cycle). So pretty much the shortest way to solve with 3-cycles. Cheers! Stefan
286. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 2006 23:53:44 -0000

> not if you're cool and use patterns ;) Seriously, I belive patterns
> eliminate a further level of memorisation.

I wast almost about to mention that too, but I thought Tyson memorises
with numbers... Well maybe I should try patterns too.. But I am not
sure if my mind works that way...

It's a shame that you lost the battery to the camera after you took the PSMO video, because that DDR video was definitely amazing. 288. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 00:02:48 -0000

Hi again Stefan. 1. Go to sleep. 2. I guess I just interpreted your method differently that you did yourself. And I don't think that's a bad thing! Solving 1 pieces at a time is efficient, but I am pretty sure solving 2 pieces at a time with your method will be just as easy as solving 2 pieces at a time with the traditional EO/EP methods, after enough practice, and it will be faster than solving 1 piece at a time. The way you describe solving the edges sounds exactly like what I am working on... Allthough I haven't been doing it for 2 months now... I think it has great potential. I am just looking for a top-cuber to proove it :). - Joël --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@> wrote: > > > > In my view, the essential new thing of your method is NOT solving 1 > > piece at the time, but losing the orientation, because it is an > > unnesecary burden. > > Hmm... like I said, my main concern is to make it easy and thus the > idea "solve one piece at a time". If not, then indeed both the single-piece and the > complete-solve ideas were "new", though I really tend to think of the > latter being included in the former. > > > Hmm.. I haven't been following this group, so I am not sure what you > > mean by free-style cycles... 289. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 00:11:05 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...> wrote: > > Ok, lets take a sample solve of however you want this done. > > Algo Scramble 3x3: F D U' R D B2 U2 R D2 B2 R' D2 F R2 L2 D2 L2 D L2 > U2 R' F' R B R' > > d'L' (F2UM'U2MUF2) Ld > FL2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) L2F' > B2U2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) U2B2 > M'L (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) L'M > d2L'y2 (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) y2Ld2 And free-style it could be done like this: U (U L E' L' U' L E L') U' (U F U' S2 U F' U' S2) (U' M U2 M' U') l (U M U2 M' U) l' U (F E' F' U F E F' U') U' Cheers! Stefan
290. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 00:18:45 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > F'U (D M'U2M D' M'U2M) U'F See? Perfect example why you shouldn't ignore Q=innerSlice: (U F U') S2 (U F' U') S2 If you really want a setup move, use y': y' (U R U') M2' (U R' U') M2' y How's that for speed? Cheers! Stefan
291. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 00:25:56 -0000

Yes.. Stefan, I know I am not very good with inner slice moves for Q. :). But I don't ignore them.. I just don't spot them very easily.. And yes, I could have also saved 2 moves by making a cube rotation, but I would not prefer to do that in a blindfold solve, because I find it confusing. And the first one is exactly the reason why I like the idea of free- style, but I also realise that too much freedom will slow me down (because I would have to think too much). That's why I am more thinking of a method where UR is the 'buffer', the first target can be anything, and the setup moves depend on the second target... So the setup moves are always the same in similar situations... Go to sleep! ;) - Joël --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@> wrote: > > > > F'U (D M'U2M D' M'U2M) U'F > > See? Perfect example why you shouldn't ignore Q=innerSlice: > > (U F U') S2 (U F' U') S2 > > If you really want a setup move, use y': > > y' (U R U') M2' (U R' U') M2' y > > How's that for speed? > > Cheers! > Stefan >
292. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 00:27:49 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > Hi again Stefan. > > 1. Go to sleep. You go first. > solving 2 pieces at a time with your method will be just as easy as > solving 2 pieces at a time with the traditional EO/EP methods, after > enough practice, and it will be faster than solving 1 piece at a > time. The speed will come from a different source, though. The speed of my single-piece method comes from its simplicity. Setting up a single piece should be a no-brainer after some practice. Also, I'm looking for direct algorithms so not using any setup moves anymore. Then for each piece, you just apply one algorithm and that's it. No setup, shoot, setdown, setup, shoot, setdown, ... anymore. Just shoot, shoot, shoot, ... Cheers! Stefan
293. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 00:33:22 -0000

Hi Stefan, You say the speed comes from simplicity. How ever.. I think you can devellop a procedure where you solve 2 edges at a time, and it's still simple. You know, I remember something Ron told us at the yahoo group: When he say the idea of solving CE pairs for speedcubing, he wrote down 'too hard to apply' next to it... Now, for most of the speedcubing population, solving a CE pair is a no- brainer. I really think that it's possible to use your method to solve 2 edges at a time, without getting too difficult. - Joël. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@> wrote: > > > > Hi again Stefan. > > > > 1. 295. Re: Looking for advice for freestlying EO+EP
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 00:57:03 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Step 1: > UB -> UR -> DR and UR needs to flip before cycling to DR. > > To do this I would do D' F U R E2 R' U' R E2 R' F' D How about this instead: U (R' E' R) U' (R' E R) > Ok so now I have solved UR and DR. Now I have UB -> DF -> DB and DF > needs to flip before going to DB. > > To do this I would do U2 B' L' M' U2 M D M' U2 M D' L B U2 How about this instead: D' - M (U' R2 U) M' (U' R2 U) - D Btw, would be nice if you could write parentheses around your P-parts as well, makes it easier to read. > So I have UL -> DL -> FL and I need to flip UL before placing it in DL. > > To do this I would do: F' L' E L D' L' E' L D F How about this instead: S' (D F' D') S (D F D') This would be faster, though: (z y') - (R U R' U') M' (U R U' r') - (y z') > Now I start over at UL and move on > UL -> BR -> UF and I need to flip UL before placing in BR. > > To do this I do: F R S D2 S' U2 S D2 S' U2 R' F' How about this instead: x' U' - (U' L' U) M2 (U' L U) M2 - U x Oh, and I hope you don't mind my provocative replacement alg suggestions :-) > To do UL -> BL -> FR I do: E2 R U2 R' E2 R U2 R' Accepted :-) > Now all I have is UB -> FR -> UL and FL needs to flip before going to > UB and UB needs to flip before going to FR. > > To do this I do: B U L B E2 B' U B E2 B' U' L' U' B' How about this instead: l - E' (L' U L) E (L' U' L) - l' > Also do any of you 3x3 guys have any interest in a system like > this? My guess is not really, probably absolutely not for you > top cubers, but I thought I would ask in case anyone is interested. Yes, me, me :-) Also, let me again offer you to show my newest method. I'll make it even easier this time and not ask you to pick a scramble but just pick a number from 1-50. Cheers! Stefan

297. Re: Looking for advice for freestlying EO+EP
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 01:15:52 -0000

> So anyway, this is what I'm in the process of learning. Does any
> other 5x5 BLD'er have any comments? Also do any of you 3x3 guys have
> any interest in a system like this? My guess is not really, probably
> absolutely not for you top cubers, but I thought I would ask in case
> anyone is interested.
>
> Chris

Yes!! I am interested... I was experimenting with Stefan's method a
while ago, and I did a few slow solves blindfolded, exactly like you
described here: solving 2 edges at a time.

I am working on a way to 'standardise' this 'method' so I don't have
to think about it, but can solve 2 pieces at a time using 3 cycles...
Maybe not optimal, but with easy setup-moves and fast algorithms.

I'll let you know when I have any succes :).

Joël.







298. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 01:16:41 -0000

> I really think that it's possible to use your method to solve 2
> edges at a time, without getting too difficult.
>
> - Joël.

Hey Joel,

You can do this actually, and is really isn't that hard. I just got
my first successful BLD solve of edges using an approach like you
describe just a few minutes ago. See the thread "Looking for advice
for freestlying EO+EP" and also Stefan's response. This thread deals
with exactly that, Stefan's method only you solve two edges at a time
instead of just one.

Freestlye cycling is quickly becoming a favorite strategy of mine,
though of course it's downside is the thinking time. I spend probably
3 times as long as Stefan does thinking about my cycles, if not more.
However, I try to make up for that by doing many fewer moves than he
does. It's all about what approach you like, both approaches are
proven to be equally fast (Stefan and I raced eachother for 4x4x4
edges many many times, and got very similar averages as far as solving
time goes).

Chris







299. Re: Stefan Pochmann's method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 01:30:56 -0000

> Freestlye cycling is quickly becoming a favorite strategy of mine,
> though of course it's downside is the thinking time. I spend
probably
> 3 times as long as Stefan does thinking about my cycles, if not more.
>
> Chris
>

Hey Chris,

Yes... This is the main problem... But I was thinking about
standardising the moves a bit like this:

The first sticker of the cycle is always UR.

- If the second sticker is on the D face, setup the third sticker in
the D face, and use the same standard commutator every time. (Like y
M'U2 M D M'U2M D' y')

- If the second sticker in in the D layer (NOT D face), setup the
third sticker in the D layer (not D face) and use a standerd
commutator for this case every time. (Like M'UM D M'U'M D')

- ...

Maybe I'll even make large tables to describe all the cases and their
solutions... But maybe you can also do it on the fly once you get used
to it..

Anyways, I should go to sleep...

Good luck!

Joël.

301. Re: Random 3x3 and 5x5
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 01:38:27 -0000

Yes please.. I can host it if you like... You can send it to: jnoort [at] gmail [dot] com. - Joël. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > I still have that particular video on my harddrive, I can upload it > if anyone cares to see it. > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > <tmao@> wrote: > > > > PSMO stands for Paranoia Survivor Max Oni. It's a song on DDR > that's > > considered one of the most difficult. I was talking with Marcus > one > > night and he told me he would make a video, and he managed to get > every > > single not perfect (I think) while playing the Step Mania version > of > > PSMO... which is of course, very impressive and only a feat that > can be > > done by a few. > > > > It's a shame that you lost the battery to the camera after you > took the > > PSMO video, because that DDR video was definitely amazing. > > > > Tyson Mao > > Astrophysics '06 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Feb 23, 2006, at 3:22 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" > > > <agent_m80@> wrote: > > > > > > > > You've seen my PSMO video > > > > so you can see how hard it is on the hands (if you look at > them in > > > > action). > > > > > > Gah, forgot this one... so what's PSMO, and is the video still > > > available somewhere? > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > Jigsaw puzzle game > > > Free puzzle inlay games > > > Educational game and puzzle > > > Word puzzle game > > > Kid puzzle game > > > Puzzle games > > > > > > YAHOO! 303. Re: Looking for advice for freestlying EO+EP
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 01:48:49 -0000

Hey Stefan, I just successfully tried a BLD solve on edges using this approach again and was able to use nicer moves more like what you are doing. I think I was thinking a bit too restrictive with my solves on that first attempt. I probably averaged about my usual 1.0-1.25 on setup turns by just trying to think of two edges already setup nicely, then maneuever the third edge into a good position as compared to the other two. Thanks for the heads up and making me think a bit more about these types of cycles. Also Joel, yes I think having a set strategy would be a very good idea. I found also that I do care how I cycle the third edge to UB, in that I have to keep all the edges oriented in the commutator such that my sticker of the third edge ends up as the U sticker of UB (I always start with UB, but it can be UR too). I think allowing more freedom, and being able to switch between the B and the U sticker of UB and make my cycles a little less rigid would be a good way to speed up this method. I would just have to know when the third edge is flipped when it is sent to UB (or UR for you) and when it is not. I think allowing that freedom for the third edge would make this metod even more powerful. Just some ideas to throw out, I'm starting to like this approach already. Can't wait to try it out on an actual 5x5x5 BLD solve, but I need to be more comfortable with it on my 3x3x3 first. Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" > <foozman17@> wrote: > > > > Step 1: > > UB -> UR -> DR and UR needs to flip before cycling to DR. > > > > To do this I would do D' F U R E2 R' U' R E2 R' F' D > > > How about this instead: > U (R' E' R) U' (R' E R)

312. Visual memorizing
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 04:05:10 -0000

Hey everyone,

Well I think I am finally starting to get the hang of visual
memorization. I've been using it lately for the 3x3 and also for the
4x4x4 and 5x5x5 edges.

What I used to do was have an internal dialogue with myself "this
piece goes here, then the piece that is there goes over to here".
When I first started I had even done that in addition to numbering
each piece, but I didn't even remember the numbers, I just numbered
them so as to count all 12 edges which is not necessary.

Well, tonight I just improved my 3x3x3 BLD record using this new
technique, I got 1:48.12 which makes me very happy! I purposely did
not allow myself to speak internally (my usual dialogue) during the
memorization, except that I did use my usual names for shapes in the
CO and EO steps.

Also, I've found that I am getting a bit more accurate with big cube
edges by simply trying to picture 3-4 pieces at a time for any given
part of the cycle, rather than to say "ok so if I am at lUB I go
'short hop' to uFL then I move 'far away' to bDR..." etc. which is how
I used to do things. I still have my names for different ways to move
around the cube, in case the visual part is a bit weird, but I don't
use them as often.

Again this is like changing the way that I read, it's so fundamental
to the way I think. So anyway, it feels weird to memorize this way,
but it is definitely faster. Can't wait until I get used to this.

Thanks for showing me that my brain was broken! I'm glad to finally
be on the right track to fixing it.

What worries me though is actually trying to read in a visual sense
rather than with an internal dialogue. I've been cubing for only 7
years, but I've been reading for about 17 so that's quite a lot of bad
habit to break.

Thanks for the help guys! It is very much appreciated!

Chris






313. Re: Visual memorizing
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 04:28:49 -0000

Glad to hear that your times are improving -- cubing is very visual, so it helps to think this way! --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > Well I think I am finally starting to get the hang of visual > memorization. 316. Random method ideas.
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 11:13:05 -0000

BLD method

I've slept on it, and came up with a few ideas.

Memorise a cycle of stickers, not cubies.

Just need to get all the lead stickers on the same face and do a
three-cycle, they can be on any face in any order, moves are also not
restricted. Cycle with (F2UM'U2MUF2) and (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) or similar.

Look at the patterns, if the cycle that returns to the piece returns
to a sticker that is not the sticker of that at the start, the last
edge in the cycle will need to be flipped with another flipped edge.

Improvements; they don't even have to be on the same face, a la the
following:

R U R' U' r R' U R U' r'
r U R' U' r' R U R U' R'

This lets you cycle around the LU, UF and UR stickers. "this pattern ;)"

I'm not any good with making up algs on the fly, but if I learnt a lot
of algs with multiple ways to cycle the pieces, I'm sure this could be
very powerful.

Note: the following is a baad way to go about it.

On swapping two sets of two pieces;

Just solve them pochmann style, the corners will be fine at the end,
and if pieces from the two sets need to be flipped, they cancel, if
not, the flipped piece will be the buffer. Then you can use the buffer
as one of the flipped pieces from the end of another cycle.

On swapping one set of pieces;

Swap them with the set of buffer corners, if the cycle that returns to
the piece returns to a sticker that is not the sticker of that at the
start, on the one at the start of the cycle,, pick the sticker that is
the one at the end of the cycle to be the one at the start, then at
the end, the buffer piece will be flipped, leaving you to flip it with
another piece, or just fix the flipped buffer.

And remember, memorise the patterns :)

So, in what ways can this be improved? I'm sure this isn't the best
way to go about this, I doubt it's even a good way, in fact ;) The
bits where you ahve two pieces to swap are really bad. But this is all
I could think of for now. Maybe it shouldbn't be for a full method,
maybe just for little bits here and there.

Hey, at least I'm thinking.

~Thom







317. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Random method ideas.
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 03:18:19 -0800

It's easier if you just peak under the blindfold.

Tyson Mao
Astrophysics '06
California Institute of Technology

On Feb 24, 2006, at 3:13 AM, thomkirjava wrote:

> BLD method
>
> I've slept on it, and came up with a few ideas.
>
> Memorise a cycle of stickers, not cubies.
>
> Just need to get all the lead stickers on the same face and do a
> three-cycle, they can be on any face in any order, moves are also not
> restricted. Cycle with (F2UM'U2MUF2) and (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) or similar.
>
> Look at the patterns, if the cycle that returns to the piece returns
> to a sticker that is not the sticker of that at the start, the last
> edge in the cycle will need to be flipped with another flipped edge.
>
> Improvements; they don't even have to be on the same face, a la the
> following:
>
> R U R' U' r R' U R U' r'
> r U R' U' r' R U R U' R'
>
> This lets you cycle around the LU, UF and UR stickers. "this pattern
> ;)"
>
> I'm not any good with making up algs on the fly, but if I learnt a lot
> of algs with multiple ways to cycle the pieces, I'm sure this could be
> very powerful.
>
> Note: the following is a baad way to go about it.
>
> On swapping two sets of two pieces;
>
> Just solve them pochmann style, the corners will be fine at the end,
> and if pieces from the two sets need to be flipped, they cancel, if
> not, the flipped piece will be the buffer. Then you can use the buffer
> as one of the flipped pieces from the end of another cycle.
>
> On swapping one set of pieces;
>
> Swap them with the set of buffer corners, if the cycle that returns to
> the piece returns to a sticker that is not the sticker of that at the
> start, on the one at the start of the cycle,, pick the sticker that is
> the one at the end of the cycle to be the one at the start, then at
> the end, the buffer piece will be flipped, leaving you to flip it with
> another piece, or just fix the flipped buffer.
>
> And remember, memorise the patterns :)
>
> So, in what ways can this be improved? I'm sure this isn't the best
> way to go about this, I doubt it's even a good way, in fact ;) The
> bits where you ahve two pieces to swap are really bad. But this is all
> I could think of for now. Maybe it shouldbn't be for a full method,
> maybe just for little bits here and there.
>
> Hey, at least I'm thinking.
>
> ~Thom
>
>
>
>
>
>
> SPONSORED LINKS
> Jigsaw puzzle game
> Free puzzle inlay games
> Educational game and puzzle
> Word puzzle game
> Kid puzzle game
> Puzzle games
>
> YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS
>
> ▪  Visit your group "blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube" on the web.
>  
> ▪  To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
>  blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
>  
> ▪  Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of
> Service.
>
>




318. Stefan's M2 method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 13:35:45 -0000

Ok, so here's my new method for permuting 3x3 edges, I call it "M2
method". It's very simple, fast, and 100% intuitive so you don't need
to learn a single alg for it.

Of course it's a 2-cycle method, one piece getting solved each time.
The piece to be solved is at FD. Since I can't just swap two pieces, I
need to have some side effect. Here it is swapping (FU,BD)+(U,D)+(F,B)
. Note FU and BD are solved relative to the M centers.

Here's an example solve, using scramble #28 from post #754 (http:
//tinyurl.com/lytqj). It's ready to be pasted into this page:
http://thearufam.brinkster.net/cube/wrapplet.asp

-------------------- start --------------------
[Scramble] U2 D2 L' U D2 R2 L2 D R D' B2 U D' F2 R2 U' F2 R2 B2

[solve LU] (L U' L' U) M2 (U' L U L')
[solve LD] (U' L2 U) M2 (U' L2 U)
[solve RF] (U R U') M2 (U R' U')
[solve RU] (R' U R U') M2 (U R' U' R)
[solve BD] M U2 M U2
[solve LF] (U' L' U) M2 (U' L U)
[solve RD] (U R2 U') M2 (U R2 U')
[solve FU] M U2 M U2
[solve RB] (U R' U') M2 (U R U')
[solve LB] (U' L U) M2 (U' L' U)
--------------------- end ---------------------

For M2 I use Joel's finger trick, i.e. L (l' M'), using my left ring
finger to pull the M'. My left middle finger holds the B stickers of
LB+LBD, so my ring finger is free for the M' and my index finger is
free for U'.

Oh, and actually it was a bad choice to have BU already solved. It's
the easiest to solve, it looks like:
[solve BU] M2

So, how do you like it?

Cheers!
Stefan








319. Re: Random method ideas.
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 13:47:21 -0000

> BLD method
>
> I've slept on it, and came up with a few ideas.
>
> Memorise a cycle of stickers, not cubies.

Yes, very good

> Just need to get all the lead stickers on the same face and do a
> three-cycle, they can be on any face in any order, moves are also
not
> restricted. Cycle with (F2UM'U2MUF2) and (F2U'M'U2MU'F2) or
similar.
>
> Look at the patterns, if the cycle that returns to the piece
returns
> to a sticker that is not the sticker of that at the start, the last
> edge in the cycle will need to be flipped with another flipped
edge.
>
> Improvements; they don't even have to be on the same face, a la the
> following:
>
> R U R' U' r R' U R U' r'
> r U R' U' r' R U R U' R'

The stickers don't have to be in the same layer: S R2 S' R2.

In fact, not having all the stickers in the same layer is more
efficient, I think.

> This lets you cycle around the LU, UF and UR stickers. "this
pattern ;)"
>
> I'm not any good with making up algs on the fly, but if I learnt a
lot
> of algs with multiple ways to cycle the pieces, I'm sure this
could be
> very powerful.
>
> Note: the following is a baad way to go about it.
>
> On swapping two sets of two pieces;
>
> Just solve them pochmann style, the corners will be fine at the
end,
> and if pieces from the two sets need to be flipped, they cancel, if
> not, the flipped piece will be the buffer. Then you can use the
buffer
> as one of the flipped pieces from the end of another cycle.
>
> On swapping one set of pieces;
>
> Swap them with the set of buffer corners, if the cycle that
returns to
> the piece returns to a sticker that is not the sticker of that at
the
> start, on the one at the start of the cycle,, pick the sticker
that is
> the one at the end of the cycle to be the one at the start, then at
> the end, the buffer piece will be flipped, leaving you to flip it
with
> another piece, or just fix the flipped buffer.
>
> And remember, memorise the patterns :)
>
> So, in what ways can this be improved? I'm sure this isn't the best
> way to go about this, I doubt it's even a good way, in fact ;) The
> bits where you ahve two pieces to swap are really bad. But this is
all
> I could think of for now. Maybe it shouldbn't be for a full method,
> maybe just for little bits here and there.
>
> Hey, at least I'm thinking.
>
> ~Thom
>

Yeah... For some special cases, like 2 sets of 2 pieces... I am also
not 100% what to do with those.

Funny, with my old cycle method, I hated 12 cycles for the edges...
Now I actually prefer them :).

- Joël.







320. Re: Stefan's M2 method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 14:01:25 -0000

Wow Stefan! It sure looks interesting and intuitive!! Have you been trying this blindfolded too?! I am not really sure if I understand how the M slice edges are handled... But it sure looks cool! - Joël. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > Ok, so here's my new method for permuting 3x3 edges, I call it "M2 > method". It's very simple, fast, and 100% intuitive so you don't need > to learn a single alg for it. > > Of course it's a 2-cycle method, one piece getting solved each time. > The piece to be solved is at FD. Since I can't just swap two pieces, I > need to have some side effect. Here it is swapping (FU,BD)+(U,D)+ (F,B) > . Note FU and BD are solved relative to the M centers. > > Here's an example solve, using scramble #28 from post #754 (http: > //tinyurl.com/lytqj). It's ready to be pasted into this page: > http://thearufam.brinkster.net/cube/wrapplet.asp > > -------------------- start -------------------- > [Scramble] U2 D2 L' U D2 R2 L2 D R D' B2 U D' F2 R2 U' F2 R2 B2 > > [solve LU] (L U' L' U) M2 (U' L U L') > [solve LD] (U' L2 U) M2 (U' L2 U) > [solve RF] (U R U') M2 (U R' U') > [solve RU] (R' U R U') M2 (U R' U' R) > [solve BD] M U2 M U2 > [solve LF] (U' L' U) M2 (U' L U) > [solve RD] (U R2 U') M2 (U R2 U') > [solve FU] M U2 M U2 > [solve RB] (U R' U') M2 (U R U') > [solve LB] (U' L U) M2 (U' L' U) > --------------------- end --------------------- > > For M2 I use Joel's finger trick, i.e. L (l' M'), using my left ring > finger to pull the M'. My left middle finger holds the B stickers of > LB+LBD, so my ring finger is free for the M' and my index finger is > free for U'. > > Oh, and actually it was a bad choice to have BU already solved. 321. Re: Stefan's M2 method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 14:15:28 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...> wrote: > > It sure looks interesting and intuitive!! Have you been trying this > blindfolded too?! Not yet. But it's already a lot of fun to do sighted :-) For blindsolving I'd probably use the full-cubie version (that'll be my name for both permuting and orienting a cubie). It's very similar, but instead of using U you use B, which should be done as U after cube rotation, e.g. [solve UR] x' (U' R U) M2 (U' R' U) x [solve BR] (l U' R' U) M2 (U' R U l') > I am not really sure if I understand how the M slice edges are > handled... But it sure looks cool! - FD is the buffer and thus ignored - BU is solved with M2 - FU and BD are solved relative to the M centers either with (M U2 M U2) or (U2 M' U2 M') Cheers! Stefan
322. Re: Stefan's M2 method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 14:22:27 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > For blindsolving I'd probably use the full-cubie version (that'll be > my name for both permuting and orienting a cubie). It's very similar, > but instead of using U you use B, which should be done as U after cube > rotation, e.g. > > [solve UR] x' (U' R U) M2 (U' R' U) x > [solve BR] (l U' R' U) M2 (U' R U l') Oh crap... clarification: Of course you don't just use B *instead* of U but you use it *additionally*. And actually I'd like to call the full-cubie version "M2" and the permute-only version "M2p". I just wanted to demonstrate M2p first cause it's so extremely sweet to execute and might even get the orient-first guys more interested :-) Cheers! Stefan
323. Re: Stefan's M2 method
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 14:29:18 -0000

Or did I miss something? - Joël. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@> wrote: > > > > It sure looks interesting and intuitive!! It's very similar, > but instead of using U you use B, which should be done as U after cube > rotation, e.g. > > [solve UR] x' (U' R U) M2 (U' R' U) x > [solve BR] (l U' R' U) M2 (U' R U l') > > > I am not really sure if I understand how the M slice edges are > > handled... 324. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] electroencephalogram
From: "Thomas Kohn" <thomas.kohn@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2006 15:43:05 +0100 (MET)

i do not go to a hospital, i do it here at the university of
konstanz(faculty of psychology). i have no pictures/videos but i ask them if
i could get some and if they want to do a longer study. i'm not sure if you
can get an image of your brain by EEG, i think you need MRI (magnetic
resonance imaging). for that you must go to a hospital. an other group has a
better EEG (=ECG?) with more electrodes (i only used 8, they have more than
200). i have to ask there.

thomas
