925. Re: Fast Edge Cycles and Large BLD System
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Sep 2006 03:55:54 -0000

F2 U S' U' F2 U S . U' U S' U' F2 U S . U' F2 These two algs will flip the piece going to the UB and the piece coming out of the UB. That is if UB is the target. Umm 2 extra moves for for sets and resets -vs- 4 extra odd ball moves. Indirect solving would be better than those ugly algs! What are your thoughts on a large BLD system. I'm talking about 36 algs for CP. It's all based on 9 algs that cycle three corners, but to optimize setups, you need the inverses, reflections, and inverted reflections. I'm also working on images for the 3x3x3 atm. I've got them, I just need to apply them to cubing. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@...> wrote: > > I'm really liking this. I think 1x direct has the potential to be much > faster than Pochmann edges simply because of the shorter algorithm. I'll try > using it for a while. "Shooting" to BU when it needs to be flipped has > annoying set ups though. I'm gonna look for a 3-cycle that does that without > setup moves. > > -James Stuber > > -----Original Message----- > From: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Daniel > Beyer > Sent: Monday, September 04, 2006 7:18 PM > To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Fast Edge Cycles > > Hey guys, I've been working on getting my BLD times down a lot. > I'm learning new things daily, and working on concepts. > > The fastest Cycle I could come up with was this ... seriously too. > > M'U2MU2, and any isomorphic M Slice Case thereof. > > This would be a two step for solving the edges EO and EP. > It is possible to do direct EP, but setups take a little more > thought. > > Dir = Direct = No EO > Indir = Indirect = An EO step > 2x = Permuting 2 Edges per Cycle > Slice Cycles can be used for, Dir, 2xDir, Indir, and 2xIndir on the > edges. I've achieved sub-10 BLD w/ 2xIndir, I'll try the other > three options. > > Ahhh I think I just realized how this can work. Well, we're doing > all these cycles, if we do Direct or Indirect Solving piece by piece, > It is possible to solve the edges with this method: > Set, M'U2MU2, Reset > Set, U2M'U2M, Reset > Set, M'U2MU2, Reset > Set, U2M'U2M, Reset > etc. > > Anybody interested, please look at it. Thanks > > Later, > Daniel Beyer > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links >
926. Re: Fast Edge Cycles
From: "uberstuberizzle" <jestuber@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Sep 2006 04:09:17 -0000

Okay, so targeting DF gives less setup moves. I still hate doing the four setup moves for targeting DF when it's flipped so: UB>FD: z F L'R U' R'2 U LR' F' R2 z' UF>FD: z R2 F L'R U' R2 U LR' F' z' You don't really need those, I just hate setup moves :P I'm already getting around 4 minute times with CO,CP,Direct EP, and I normally do around 3:30 for direct EP Pochmann style. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...> wrote: > > You know setups aren't all that annoying > > As I said before I was able to do a few successful 2x Indirect solves > > 1x Indirect could be very very fast > 2 setup moves R?B' and L?B or Nothing for the edges if we were to > target UB > L?D or R?D' if targeting the DF > *These two targets have different EO definitions* > > Using DF as the target and you have a "misoriented edge" > Sets would be > FL?F' > F'R?F > > still not a bad comprimise! > > I don't know what to tell you about if you target the UB directly. > That's sorta confusing. > > I also developed a "simple 2 look EO" > This would entail Setting the UE layers to a known case, performing > an alg, then rotating the D layer to the top and orienting the last > D layer then resetoring the cube > > Setups for 2 Look EO would entail 3 moves to setup max, then > reseting after performing both algorithms. > > Also I'm going to try and finish generating a Direct 3-cycle CP > method that uses a lot of short algorithms. > > The system is 9 algs > but that quadruples to 36 when you take into account inverses, > reflections, and reflected inverses. If I learn all 36 algs, I can > permute 2 corners per alg and only two move setups! > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" > <jestuber@> wrote: > > > > I'm really liking this. I think 1x direct has the potential to be > much > > faster than Pochmann edges simply because of the shorter > algorithm. I'll try > > using it for a while. "Shooting" to BU when it needs to be flipped > has > > annoying set ups though. I'm gonna look for a 3-cycle that does > that without > > setup moves. > > > > -James Stuber > > > > -----Original Message----- > > From: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com > > [mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of > Daniel > > Beyer > > Sent: Monday, September 04, 2006 7:18 PM > > To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com > > Subject: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Fast Edge Cycles > > > > Hey guys, I've been working on getting my BLD times down a lot. > > I'm learning new things daily, and working on concepts. > > > > The fastest Cycle I could come up with was this ... seriously too. > > > > M'U2MU2, and any isomorphic M Slice Case thereof. > > > > This would be a two step for solving the edges EO and EP. > > It is possible to do direct EP, but setups take a little more > > thought. > > > > Dir = Direct = No EO > > Indir = Indirect = An EO step > > 2x = Permuting 2 Edges per Cycle > > Slice Cycles can be used for, Dir, 2xDir, Indir, and 2xIndir on > the > > edges. I've achieved sub-10 BLD w/ 2xIndir, I'll try the other > > three options. > > > > Ahhh I think I just realized how this can work. Well, we're doing > > all these cycles, if we do Direct or Indirect Solving piece by > piece, > > It is possible to solve the edges with this method: > > Set, M'U2MU2, Reset > > Set, U2M'U2M, Reset > > Set, M'U2MU2, Reset > > Set, U2M'U2M, Reset > > etc. > > > > Anybody interested, please look at it. Thanks > > > > Later, > > Daniel Beyer > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > >
927. RE: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Fast Edge Cycles and Large BLD System
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2006 21:39:12 -0700

You beat me to the algs :P

I'm not a fan of large BLD system's because I'm too lazy to learn a chunk of
algorithms :P
If you're willing to put in the time necessary to make all of the algorithms
second nature to you, then by all means it's worth the saved moves.
Because a good 3/4th's of the algs you're talking about are reflections etc,
Learning them wouldn't be too bad.

-James Stuber



-----Original Message-----
From: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Daniel
Beyer
Sent: Tuesday, September 05, 2006 8:56 PM
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Fast Edge Cycles and Large BLD
System

F2 U S' U' F2 U S . U'
U S' U' F2 U S . U' F2

These two algs will flip the piece going to the UB and the piece
coming out of the UB. That is if UB is the target.

Umm 2 extra moves for for sets and resets -vs- 4 extra odd ball
moves. Indirect solving would be better than those ugly algs!

What are your thoughts on a large BLD system.

I'm talking about 36 algs for CP. It's all based on 9 algs that
cycle three corners, but to optimize setups, you need the inverses,
reflections, and inverted reflections.

I'm also working on images for the 3x3x3 atm. I've got them, I just
need to apply them to cubing.





928. Re: Fast Edge Cycles and Large BLD System
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Sep 2006 08:30:55 -0000

The great thing about learning your own work is ... its yours and it sticks to you. I hate learning OLL and PLL, it takes forever. But every algorithm I learned for BLD that I made, I still know and can use. If I can think of it all as PLL or F2L algs which I my reflections can flow very nicely for, this will be great. Inverses won't be much harder. If I can find the time to learn them, I'm sure I'll know them very quickly, just as I did w/ my 12 Simul Block algs, sadly that method just didn't work! James, lemme know how direct solving works for you. I'm going to be working on BLD most of the weekend. So I'll probablly have all 12 SB algs at my finger tips, be solving w/ Roux Cycles, and I'll probablly have 9 CP algs memorized. And this system is meant as a Pochmann based method, you're gonna keep the same buffer areas throughout the whole solve. So, if CP and Roux Cycles work as I hope I'll use 54 algorithms .3 Roux Cycles - Applicable .3 2-Cycle CP - In Use .3 2-Cycle EP - In Use .9 Progressive Parity Fixing Algs - Applicable .36 3-Cycle CP - Not Ready .43 images - Applicable I've applied "Applicables" but not quickly Using 6 Algs, I can solve sub 6 BLD now. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "James Stuber" <jestuber@...> wrote: > > You beat me to the algs :P > > I'm not a fan of large BLD system's because I'm too lazy to learn a chunk of > algorithms :P > If you're willing to put in the time necessary to make all of the algorithms > second nature to you, then by all means it's worth the saved moves. > Because a good 3/4th's of the algs you're talking about are reflections etc, > Learning them wouldn't be too bad. > > -James Stuber > > > > -----Original Message----- > From: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Daniel > Beyer > Sent: Tuesday, September 05, 2006 8:56 PM > To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Fast Edge Cycles and Large BLD > System > > F2 U S' U' F2 U S . 932. Re: Fast Edge Cycles and Large BLD System
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Sep 2006 14:09:37 -0000

I know it does have a different effect. However, by using the proper setup and M'U2MU2 (or is it U2M'U2M?) I can achieve the same result as the alg we just generated. I know what you did, and that it is the same algorithm. I'm just impressed that you looked for it at that angle, the difference in Turn metrics is what set the two apart. I'd rather do a different setup than use a longer alg. Just like if you want to target the F face of FL do: l' T-Perm l L Face of FL do: d'l T-Perm l'd same algorithm different setup. Now we could have done l' and the T perm that flips the edges too. So I think I'll prefer to use M'U2MU2 and U2M'U2M alternating as an approach to EP why alternate? because you want to consider Keeping UF Solved once it's been permuted, so just as the two corners keep being swapped back and forth in Pochmann while you are permuting the edges, well you keep swapping the UF between UB and UF using alternating slice cycles. I'm going to have to do some practice runs to make sure that I fully understand this correctly. And see what I can do w/ my old Progressive Parity Fixing algs. If any of you read on Simul Block, it's those algs optimized. If there is a parity, I'll directly solve the first corner and edge of the Cycles then do my EP and CP as normal. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > I just applied your alg from a different angle, that's all. > What do you mean you'll stick with that other alg? It has a > different effect. > > Stefan > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Beyer" > <dbeyer816@> wrote: > > > > You never cease to amaze me Stephan, you're popping out algs for > > everything. Thanks, but I'll stick w/ M'U2MU2 =P > > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan > Pochmann" > > <pochmann@> wrote: > > > > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel > Beyer" > > > <dbeyer816@> wrote: > > > > > > > > U S' U' F2 U S . U' F2 > > > > > > d M U' R2 U M' U' R2 y > > > > > >
933. Sub 4 BLD
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 10 Sep 2006 06:51:15 -0000

I just did it today. After I stressed myself so horribly yesterday, I
had 20+ DNFs, I decided to stop counting. In a 12 hour period, 20
DNFs I BLDd for like 2 hours before work, and an hour after work. I
was very flustered. But I knew it would pay off. I made two attempts
today, one was just a relaxed solve, no timing. Then about an hour
ago I did my sub 4!

Time was 3:32.94!!
Considering before this my PB was 5:27.56 ... I'm very stoked!
But I must sleep, g'nite

Later,
Daniel Beyer







934. My BLD success
From: "Bruce Norskog" <brnorsk@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Sep 2006 04:03:20 -0000

Hi,

I just had my first successful 3x3x3 BLD solve! The time was 23:52.98.

Earlier I had another successful solve, but it was the 2nd attempt for
a given scramble so I'm not counting that one.

By the way, I recently posted on the speedsolving forum that I found
the following commutator for twisting four corners (the four corners
in the U layer):

(R' D R' D R' D S) U2 (S' D' R D' R D' R) U2

but there were no responses to my post. I was wondering if this rather
simple commutator has been mentioned anywhere else for twisting four
corners without changing anything else. I haven't seen it on any BLD
sites I've looked at.

For the other case of twisting four U-layer corners, I have come up
with the following commutator, but some other (non-commutator) algs
are probably better for this case.

(L' R' D L R F B D F' B') U (B F D' B' F' R' L' D' R L) U'

- Bruce







935. Re: My BLD success
From: "suraimu_cube" <suraimu_cube@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Sep 2006 04:37:47 -0000

> (R' D R' D R' D S) U2 (S' D' R D' R D' R) U2

R U - R2 U' R2 U' - R2 U2 - R2 U' R' U - R U2' R' U

> (L' R' D L R F B D F' B') U (B F D' B' F' R' L' D' R L) U'

R' U2 R U2 R2 B' D' R'F R2 F' D B U' R' U'


-Suraimu(http://www.rubiks.biz)









936. Re: My BLD success
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Sep 2006 09:46:31 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Norskog" <brnorsk@...> wrote: > > (R' D R' D R' D S) U2 (S' D' R D' R D' R) U2 > > but there were no responses to my post. Which is a shame. I love that alg. Not for actual use (<R,U> is better), but for its ingenuity. Cheers! Stefan
937. Re: My BLD success
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Sep 2006 14:54:30 -0000

Yes :D A very sweet commutator indeed ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Norskog" > <brnorsk@> wrote: > > > > (R' D R' D R' D S) U2 (S' D' R D' R D' R) U2 > > > > but there were no responses to my post. > > Which is a shame. 938. Re: My BLD success
From: "Bruce Norskog" <brnorsk@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Sep 2006 23:58:17 -0000

For more U & R layer turns, you could do the the up-down mirror to twist the D-layer corners... R U' R U' R U' S' D2 S U R' U R' U R' D2 But that part in the middle with the S-slice turns still is a bit awkward. Even so, I think it is reasonably fast. It's my impression that many BLD solvers don't want to learn a lot of algs for BLD, and the commutator would at least be easier to learn than other algs I've seen (although people who know OLL/PLL algs may not find those others so hard.) So I think this may be useful for some people, but I wasn't meaning to imply that it's better for speed than other 4-corner twist algs. And I don't recommend using the other commutator (L' R' D L R F B D F' B' U B F D' B' F' R' L' D' R L U') with all the anti-slice moves that I came up. It's a lot of moves unless you count anti-slice moves as a single move; and I don't find it very easy to execute. It may be fairly simple to memorize, but I wouldn't use it myself. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...> wrote: > > Yes :D > > A very sweet commutator indeed ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@...m, "Stefan > Pochmann" <pochmann@> wrote: > > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Norskog" > > <brnorsk@> wrote: > > > > > > (R' D R' D R' D S) U2 (S' D' R D' R D' R) U2 > > > > > > but there were no responses to my post. > > > > Which is a shame. I love that alg. Not for actual use (<R,U> is > > better), but for its ingenuity. > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > >
939. Re: My BLD success
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 18 Sep 2006 20:12:51 -0000

Hey Bruce, Congratulations on your successful solve, that's awesome! BLD cubing is very addictive so be careful that you don't get sucked in.... too much ;-) Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Bruce Norskog" <brnorsk@...> wrote: > > Hi, > > I just had my first successful 3x3x3 BLD solve! The time was 23:52.98.
940. I know why images are slower for 3x3!!!!
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Sep 2006 03:19:28 -0000

I know why images have been much slower for memorizing the 3x3x3 for
me! Also, this means that I can speed up my memorization quite a bit
for the bigger cubes too!!

I was doing some 3x3x3 BLD solves using images rather than the normal
stuff, and realized one difference between how I do it with images and
with regular stuff. The difference was for images I often close my
eyes to get a better mental picture at my journey location. I tried
memorizing without closing my eyes, and found that it feels weird, but
I think it is something I can get used to.

This is pretty cool for the 3x3x3, but the really exciting part is
that I could be so much faster at memorizing the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 cube
because I quite often close my eyes for long stretches to really
cement in the picture at *each* journey location. If I could learn to
do this with my eyes open the whole time, then I think I could really
take a lot of time off, maybe a minute or so for the 4x4x4 and a
couple minutes for the 5x5x5.

Oh my God this is so crazy cool! I'm going to start trying to
memorize solely with eyes open, or at least try to minimize how often
I close my eyes to cement a journey location in my mind.

It has been extremely frustrating for me to be improving my big cubes
memorization times so much, and yet have that exact same images method
slow me down considerably for the 3x3x3. Well now I think about it
the other way, the way I am memorizing with images for the 3x3x3 is
the exact same as for the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5, so I must need to improve
my images method in general, which will also speed up my 4x4x4 and
5x5x5 times!

My record for memorizing the 4x4x4 is around 3:10 I believe, so I
think if I can get to the point where I can cement the images in my
location without closing my eyes at all, then I might be able to get
sub-3 for 4x4x4 memo, which is even faster than the memory experts
predicted!

I'm going to work REALLY hard on this and try to post on how it goes.
Wish me luck! I'd love to be able to memorize the 4x4 sub-3 and beat
even the predicted times of the memory masters! I think memorizing
the 5x5x5 sub-10 would be possible too, my record for 5x5 is 10:30 for
memo so I think this change could get me sub-10.

Will try to update on how the open eyed practice goes with these
images, I can't believe I didn't even realize the difference of how
often I pause, with eyes closed, to cement a journey location in my
mind. That would explain why my 3x3 is so much slower, and also the
implications for 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 are very exciting since I could
probably be memorizing them so much faster without closing my eyes
after each journey location!

Holy crap BLD cubing rocks!
Chris







941. Re: I know why images are slower for 3x3!!!!
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Sep 2006 04:01:07 -0000

I just did 5 solves on the 3x3x3 using images and not closing my eyes
during memorization. It still feels very weird to not close my eyes,
but I can still picture the journey location as well as the cube and
cement my images. I DNF'd all of the solves but one, as it still
feels very weird, but I did notice that on one solve I memorized the
EP and CP in 48 seconds (not including EO and CO). I also had one
complete memorization in 1:10 and the whole solve including memo in
2:02.xx. That solve was a DNF with a few pieces out of place, but hey
the DNF's show where my solves are headed. The successful solve was
2:40.98.

I'm going to keep practicing this, as I feel that I am memorizing much
faster, I just need to get my accuracy up seeing as how this feels
very weird to memorize this way right now.

I'll try to keep posting on how it goes.

Chris







942. Images memorization with eyes open
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Sep 2006 17:39:14 -0000

Hey everyone,

I just tried doing images with eyes open for 4x4x4 BLD and the results
are very awesome! My first solve was 8:10.57 but it was a DNF and was
off by 3 edges. The second solve with eyes open was a 8:22.58
successful solve with about 4:30.xx of memorization.

It is fairly rare for me to be able to do two sub-9's (even if one is
DNF) in a row with closing my eyes to cement each and every journey
location. I usually can get one, then all the other solves after it
are much slower.

I think this eyes open memorizing is the way to go, I'm going to work
on it for the 4x4x4 and also for the 5x5x5 as I think the most benefit
can come from memorizing eyes open for the bigger cubes.

I also want to work on eyes open images for the 3x3x3 too, as I think
I can at least get my images memorization to be faster and hopefully
closer in time to the rote memory stuff I use when not using images.

I'll try to keep posting about my progress, but so far eyes open is
now the only way I will try to memorize. I just still need to get
used to it as it still feels a bit weird to memorize this way right now.

Chris







943. Re: Images memorization with eyes open 3x3
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Sep 2006 18:24:06 -0000

Did some 3x3 solves using images with eyes open for memorization just
now as well.

2:33.64
DNF
2:14.27
DNF
2:37.40

My times seem to be around what I get when I memorize with my old
stuff. I need to work on my accuracy, and also it still feels weird
to memorize with eyes open, but I think I am getting more used to it.

I'll try to keep updating if I get any cool times or anything. Well,
at least this gives me renewed hope in using my images method for the
3x3x3 as a way to finally break out of this slump and finally be able
to improve my times again.

Chris






944. Re: Images memorization with eyes open
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 19 Sep 2006 22:26:03 -0000

Hey Chris, For what it's worth, I've always memorized with eyes open. I have a problem with distractions though. Visual, noise; both bother me. But I am most bothered by my wandering mind. Often I have a really hard time focusing on seeing my images for just a split second, as is usually recommended. Other things will just pop into my mind, like events of the day, etc., and right there I lose seconds from the memo phase. It's quite annoying; I'm rarely "in the zone" that is critical for making images quickly. I wish I knew how to block out all the other clutter from coming in. I also wonder about the age factor, and the ability to concentrate. I've been at this for over 4 yrs now, and while certain things have improved, the ability to block out distractions while memorizing still lingers. But for speed, I think that eyes open would be the way to go. My ramblings, -Dave O. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I just tried doing images with eyes open for 4x4x4 BLD and the results > are very awesome! My first solve was 8:10.57 but it was a DNF and was > off by 3 edges. The second solve with eyes open was a 8:22.58 > successful solve with about 4:30.xx of memorization. > > It is fairly rare for me to be able to do two sub-9's (even if one is > DNF) in a row with closing my eyes to cement each and every journey > location. I usually can get one, then all the other solves after it > are much slower. > > I think this eyes open memorizing is the way to go, I'm going to work > on it for the 4x4x4 and also for the 5x5x5 as I think the most benefit > can come from memorizing eyes open for the bigger cubes. > > I also want to work on eyes open images for the 3x3x3 too, as I think > I can at least get my images memorization to be faster and hopefully > closer in time to the rote memory stuff I use when not using images. > > I'll try to keep posting about my progress, but so far eyes open is > now the only way I will try to memorize. I just still need to get > used to it as it still feels a bit weird to memorize this way right now. > > Chris >
945. Re: Images memorization with eyes open
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Sep 2006 01:16:20 -0000

Hey Dave, That's good to know that memorizing with eyes open has helped you. I posted on the memory sports group about eyes open vs. eyes closed to cement images and I also got the "do with eyes open response" from there too. Yeah I am also worried about visual distractions with this new eyes open technique. There has always been a lot of visual noise when I was memorizing in competition, so I imagine if I feel overwhelmed I'll just close my eyes to cement a location and make sure I won't DNF because of a memorization error. I'd rather memorize slower but not DNF under pressure than try to go super fast and DNF all my solves, which I'm sick of doing in competition lol, I've done it enough times already. I'll probably start practicing in public more often now to see how I do with this eyes open technique in public. As for at home, I've already fallen in love with it. I did a 4x4x4 BLD solve just now, and almost beat my PB solve! The solve was slower than my pb by 0.02 second! The memorization took me 3:53.xx and the total time was 7:52.99! I'm going to go try a couple 5x5x5 solves now and see how it goes. I'm not sure if I'm ready for eyes open for 5x5, but I figure I'll try it anyway and either sink or swim lol. Thanks for the input though Dave, I respect your opinion on BLD related matters very much, especially with the times you put up as well as your crazy multiple cubes attempts. You really should try the bigger cubes too, they're so much more addicting ;-) Thanks Dave, hope things are well with you, Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, smoothcuber <no_reply@...> wrote: > > > Hey Chris, > > For what it's worth, I've always memorized with eyes open. 946. I feel sick
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Sep 2006 02:23:31 -0000

:'(

I just got a DNF on 5x5x5 BLD, but it would have been a really good
time :-(

The memorization time was 10:59.xx and the solve was off by two
+centers, everything else was perfect. The overall time was 19:53.26 :'(

That both motivates me so much more than any other solve I've ever
done on the 5x5x5, and also makes me so angry I could scream lol.

Alright, well at least my DNFs show the progress of where my solves
are headed. I'm at least glad to know that it's possible for me to
get sub-20 on the 5x5x5 assuming I concentrate harder during the
solve. But at the same time it sucks to get so close and yet be so
far. I think it was an execution error, I can see where I switched
one of my base pieces (the one that always starts the cycle) in one
case, and left two pieces unsolved at the end.

After I go scream into my pillow for a few seconds lol I'm going to go
try again. Ok so I'm not really that upset, but I'm close lol.

Alright, I hope to get a for real sub-20 soon. I memorized with eyes
open while doing this, and it's making it so much easier to memorize
quickly for the bigger cubes. I'm glad I discovered this change. I
only hope to be used to it enough to use it in competition at G-Wiz.

Chris

make it so much easier to get these superfast memorization times and
yet still be able to recall later. For some reason I can actually
picture my journey locations with the images in them much more clearly
when I keep my eyes open, so I hope to get better at this.

sub-10 memorization times for the 5x5.

949. GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Sep 2006 04:41:37 -0000

I've been really really busy with work and college, but I'm still
making the trip to Florida.

Less than a month now!

I plan to compete in every event that I have a puzzle for. This
means I have to restring my magic just in case that event comes into
play.
I need to reassemble my revenge. Are eastsheens allowed?!
I need to reassemble my 222 if possible.
I want to buy two DIYs, and resticker all my cubes.

This I have to do on my own. However, I was wondering if somebody
could help to explain 3-cycles for big BLD cubing. I'm a direct 2-
cycle solver for 333 bld.

I understand that I can use variations of R'FRB'R'F'RB and I can use
l2dRd'l2dR'd' and variations thereof for cycles, but the only way I
understand cubing is to permute 1 piece at time.

So could somebody please explain 3-cylces to me. Only for big
cubes. Like how would I easily set them up.

And could somebody give me some well shaped 3 or 5 cycles for big
cubes. I really want to compete beside Chris ... even if it's only
for like 20-30 minutes. I wanna try big cube BLD at GWiz so bad!

Later,
Daniel Beyer







950. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Sep 2006 15:18:36 -0000

Hey Daniel, I received your e-mail about the three cycles for the bigger cubes, I just hadn't typed up a response yet. I'll go ahead and respond here in case anyone else is interested too. I typed up a long post on the rubiks.has.it forum about how I mentally approach any three cycle for the bigger cubes. The link is http://tinyurl.com/pft5d That post is slightly outdated in that at the time I didn't memorize with journeys but with my older style of images that I've since given up on. So don't listen to anything in the part about "why I solve in the order I do" because all of that has changed. However, the section that describes what algs to use is still in date, only I've added a couple commutator types since then (Thank you Stefan!!) :-) The short version I'll type here though. Given any three pieces to three cycle you must meet three conditions before you can start: 1) You must have two pieces on one layer, and one piece off that layer 2) The two pieces in one layer must be interchangeable - meaning you can put on in the place of the other just by turning the layer they are both on 3) You must easily be able to place the one piece off that layer into the spot of one of your two pieces. I give names for these to make it easier. The two pieces in one layer are simply called your "two pieces". The third piece is called the "lone piece". You will use this for either the "lone edge" or the "lone center". To meet the last condition you have to look at both of your two pieces and see if you can place the lone piece into the layer, literally replacing one of your "two pieces" while affecting nothing else on that layer. Here is an example. I choose the three edge piece cycle lUB->uBL->bUL So let's see what we have. We do have two edges in one layer and one edge off that layer. I'll choose the two edges in one layer to be lUB and bUL which are both in the U layer. This means that the uBL edge is not in the U layer and so is called the "lone edge". So I have met condition 1. However I have not met condition 2, the two edges in one layer are not interchangeable. I cannot turn the U layer and put one edge in the location of the other. So I need a setup move in order to make sure that I meet conditions 1,2, and 3. The setup move I will choose is b' After b' I now have the cycle lUB->uBL->bUR So let's start over. Do I have two pieces in one layer and one piece off that layer? Yes I do, lUB and bUR are both in the U layer, and uBL is off that layer and is still my "lone edge". Now do we meet condition 2? Yes we do, I can put the lUB piece into the spot of the bUR piece simply by doing the turn U. I could also put the bUR piece into the spot of lUB simply by doing the turn U'. So condition 2 is met. Do we meet condition 3? Condition 3 is that I must easily be able to insert the lone edge into the U layer to replace either lUB or bUR. The piece I choose to replace, it's location, gets the name the "action spot", meaning this is where all the action is going to happen. The action spot here is going to be bUR. This is because it is very easy to insert uBL into the action spot without messing up anything else in the U layer, you just do R' u2 R. This move places the uBL piece into the bUR spot. But notice that after our setup move that our cycle is now lUB->uBL->bUR That means that the uBL pieces was supposed to go to bUR, so we're doing the cycle correctly. Now after placing the lone edge into the U layer, we have to interchange the two U layer edges. Do this with the move U, this will move the lUB edge to bUR which is the action spot. Now we have to place the action spot edge where the lone edge used to be. This is a commutator too, so make sure to do that in the exact reverse way that you first placed the lone edge into the action spot. So we'll actually do this with R' u2 R. Now we need to undo our U layer turn to complete the commutator, which we'll do with U'. Also remember that we started with the setup turn b' so we now have to undo that with the move b. Ok, so all in all we did the cycle lUB->uBL->bUL and we did this with the following commutator: b' R' u2 R U R' u2 R U' b Now I could have just given you the commutator for that particular case, but then I'd also have to give you the commutator for every other case, and to be honest there are too many to memorize. If you memorize this process for coming up with a commutator then you won't view these as algs, but just as types of commutators. And one type of commutator can have quite a lot of variations and just one "commutator type" can really turn out to be around 50 or more algs. So for the bigger cubes, don't memorize algs if you want to do three cycles. There are simply too many to memorize. Just learn the process for coming up with a commutator to fix your situation on the fly. Just my two cents, but I've found that knowing how to come up with commutators on the fly is very fast for me, and I don't see any reason to just memorize a bunch of algs when you can have a 100% total understand of how you are using commutators to move pieces around, and your blindfolded solve becomes an intuitive solve. That helps for noticing any errors, because you just get the feeling that "I didn't do something right" or "that didn't feel right" if you make a wrong move or use the wrong commutator. Hope that helps, and sorry for the slow response time, Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...> wrote: > > I've been really really busy with work and college, but I'm still > making the trip to Florida. > > Less than a month now! > > I plan to compete in every event that I have a puzzle for. This > means I have to restring my magic just in case that event comes into > play. > I need to reassemble my revenge. Are eastsheens allowed?! > I need to reassemble my 222 if possible. > I want to buy two DIYs, and resticker all my cubes. > > This I have to do on my own. However, I was wondering if somebody > could help to explain 3-cycles for big BLD cubing. I'm a direct 2- > cycle solver for 333 bld. > > I understand that I can use variations of R'FRB'R'F'RB and I can use > l2dRd'l2dR'd' and variations thereof for cycles, but the only way I > understand cubing is to permute 1 piece at time. > > So could somebody please explain 3-cylces to me. Only for big > cubes. Like how would I easily set them up. > > And could somebody give me some well shaped 3 or 5 cycles for big > cubes. I really want to compete beside Chris ... even if it's only > for like 20-30 minutes. I wanna try big cube BLD at GWiz so bad! > > Later, > Daniel Beyer >

954. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "agousev" <agousev@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Sep 2006 04:16:49 -0000

Chris,

I've had this question on my mind for a while. When doing 4x4x4 or
5x5x5 blindfolded, let's say you have to switch two sets of two edges
on the 4x4x4 or two wings on the 5x5x5. On the 3x3x3, this would be
relatively simple, as there's algs to do it, and the setup moves are
minimal. On the larger cubes, however, while there is the PLL parity
alg, I always use WAY too many setup moves. On the last 4x4x4
blindfold I attempted, i had to do 11 setup moves to switch two sets
of edges. Am I doing something horrendously wrong, or do I just need
more practice?

-Alexei Gousev







955. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Sep 2006 10:20:26 -0000

Hey Alexei, I would not say you're doing something wrong, I mean as long as a method works and solves your cube while you're blindfolded then it's a good method. I do think there is an easier way though. On the 4x4x4 or 5x5x5, assuming you keep the orientation of the cube fixed, there are (24 c 2) * (22 c 2) = 276 * 231 = 63756 ways to have 2 sets of two edges or wing edges to swap. Since there are so many I try not to memorize algs for those cases, because even if you memorize 100 algs you are still 63656 cases short of knowing all of them and you may still require a lot of setup moves. I do those 2 two swap cases as two three cycles, so I break it down to a problem needing 2 steps to solve rather than solving all 4 at once. I'll do this in permutation theory or notation or however you call it so that it will show how you solve any case. Say the 4 pieces I have unsolved are pieces A, B, C, and D. They are setup in two swaps like this: (A B) (C D) Which is to say that pieces A and B swap and pieces C and D swap. These could be any pieces on the cube. To solve this position I would first do the cycle: (A B C) = A -> B -> C -> A Let's see how this affects our starting point of (A B) (C D) Piece A needs to go to the spot that piece B is in. Notice in our cycle that we send piece A to the spot where piece B is (A -> B -> C). Piece B needs to go to the spot where piece A is, but we instead sent it to the spot where piece C was. So now the location where piece C started needs to go to the location where piece A started. So we have C->A necessary to solve our cube. Piece C we sent to the location where piece A started, but piece C needs to go to the location where piece D started. So we now have A- >D necessay to solve our cube. Also we never touched the D piece, so it still needs to go to C. So we have D->C Let's put all those pieces together to see what we have left: C->A; A->D; D->C And we see we have a three cycle: A->D->C->A or (A D C) So after the cycle (A B C) we then do the cycle (A D C) and we will have solved that two swap scenario. The way I remember how to do this during a solve is like this: Look at your 2 two swaps: (A B) (C D) and create a three cycle out of them in the order you memorized them. So for these I'll say I memorized the cycle that now ends with (A B) before the cycle that now ends with (C D). I could have also just started with 2 two swaps, and let's say if that happened that I still memorized (A B) before (C D). Now just read left to right creating a three cycle, so do (A B C) or A- >B->C By what we showed above we know that we will have solved location B, leaving only A, C, and D left to be solved. Now start with A again in your second cycle, but read the (C D) cycle backwards. So our second three cycle has to be (A D C). This is simply starting at A again, but solving the (C D) swap reading now right to left, so as D -> C. ------------ That was the long explanation of what we're doing, but the short of it is that if you have the 2 swap (A B) (C D) then do two three cycles, and do them in this order: 1) (A B C) 2) (A D C) And you will solve that two swap case. This is also nice because you don't have to memorize any algs, or often you don't even have to do any setup moves. Just break down this harder problem into 2 cases, rather than trying to do it in 1 step like for the 3x3x3. That's just my opinion, but personally I've found it to be faster than setup moves into a memorized case, and also faster than 2 applications of the parity alg to fix. Just my two cents, but I hope this helps. And good luck with your big cubes BLD! Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "agousev" <agousev@...> wrote: > > Chris, > > I've had this question on my mind for a while. When doing 4x4x4 or > 5x5x5 blindfolded, let's say you have to switch two sets of two edges > on the 4x4x4 or two wings on the 5x5x5. On the 3x3x3, this would be > relatively simple, as there's algs to do it, and the setup moves are > minimal. On the larger cubes, however, while there is the PLL parity > alg, I always use WAY too many setup moves. On the last 4x4x4 > blindfold I attempted, i had to do 11 setup moves to switch two sets > of edges. Am I doing something horrendously wrong, or do I just need > more practice? > > -Alexei Gousev >
956. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Sep 2006 11:22:16 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > On the 4x4x4 or 5x5x5, assuming you keep the orientation of the cube > fixed, there are (24 c 2) * (22 c 2) = 276 * 231 = 63756 ways to have > 2 sets of two edges or wing edges to swap. Wrong :-) Unless you care about the order of the two sets which seems unlikely since you don't care about the order of the two pieces in each set. Stefan

958. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>

Hey Stefan, I think I see the error, but now I'm a bit confused. Would it be (24 c 4)*(4 c 2)/2 = 31878 Also if I count like I did the first way I could do (24 c 2)*(22 c 2)/2 = 31878 Also in response to your other post I do want to gather all my posts about big cubes BLD onto one page on my site, just for clarity of trying to read it, rather than half of it being on this group and half at the rubiks.has.it forum. Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> wrote: > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" > <foozman17@> wrote: > > > > On the 4x4x4 or 5x5x5, assuming you keep the orientation of the cube > > fixed, there are (24 c 2) * (22 c 2) = 276 * 231 = 63756 ways to > have > > 2 sets of two edges or wing edges to swap. > > Wrong :-) > > Unless you care about the order of the two sets which seems unlikely > since you don't care about the order of the two pieces in each set. > > Stefan >
959. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Sep 2006 18:37:07 -0000

--- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Hey Stefan, I think I see the error, but now I'm a bit confused. > > Would it be (24 c 4)*(4 c 2)/2 = 31878 > > Also if I count like I did the first way I could do (24 c 2)*(22 c > 2)/2 = 31878 Yeah that's right. Your mistake was that you accepted (AB)(CD) as the same as (BA)(CD) but not as (CD)(AB). So you counted everything twice. Yet another way: 24C4 * 3 First you choose four, then you pair up the "prettiest" (your choice what that means) with one of the other three. Stefan
960. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "agousev" <agousev@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Sep 2006 06:20:38 -0000

Wow, that's so much easier. I never thought about it that way. Thanks for your help! Also, on the 5x5x5 blindfold, let's say you have to switch two corners. How, and at what point in the solve would you do this? To me, it would make most sense to wait until the end of the solve, and then do a T-perm, followed by the 4x4x4 PLL parity alg to fix the messed up wing edges. I've never actually had this situation come up yet, but I was wondering what would be the most efficient way to do it when it does happen. -Alexei Gousev --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Hey Alexei, > > I would not say you're doing something wrong, I mean as long as a > method works and solves your cube while you're blindfolded then it's a > good method. 961. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Sep 2006 02:25:27 -0000

Hey Alexei, Glad that helps, I actually had never thought to try that either until I posted on this group and someone said they did that case with two three cycles. I'm just glad to be able to help "cube it forward" a little bit ;-) As for when to swap the corners on a 4x4 or 5x5 I have been saving them until the very end of the solve, but after reading your post I realized that's not necessary. The most important thing to realize is that swapping two corners on a 5x5 (which also means 2 central edges need swapping) performs an odd permutation on the X centers of the cube. You can't see this on a regular 5x5x5 cube if it's close to solved, but on the physical pieces you do in fact perform an odd permutation on the Xcenters when you swap two edges and 2 corners, even if you can't see it. If you swap two corners on a 4x4 you have also performed an odd permutation on the Xcenters there too. I would say the easiest thing is to wait until after you have solved the centers, and then swap those two corners. This way the odd permutation on the Xcenters isn't noticed, because your centers are all solved, and most algs for the corner parity only affect the centers on a given face, and don't swap them between faces. I personally have been saving the corner swaps (and edges too for the 5x5) until the very end, but I just realized that this is unnecessary for the way I solve. When I first started big cubes BLD I solved the centers last, so I had to wait until the very, very end of the solve to swap the corners. Now I solve centers first, so if I have corner parity I'm going to start swapping the corners immediately after I finish centers rather than wait until the end of the solve. There's no need to remember that information for the whole solve just to follow the tradition of the way I started solving when I think it would be much more efficient as far as the memory is concerned to just solve them immediately after the centers. And also I would say the same as advice for when would be best for you to swap corners too. Swap them immediately after you have finished solving the centers, that way you can forget about them for the rest of the solve. If you solve centers last, then I would say your safest bet is to swap the corners if you have corner parity as the very final thing you do in a solve. Just my two cents, Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "agousev" <agousev@...> wrote: > > Wow, that's so much easier. I never thought about it that way. > Thanks for your help! > > Also, on the 5x5x5 blindfold, let's say you have to switch two > corners. How, and at what point in the solve would you do this? To > me, it would make most sense to wait until the end of the solve, and > then do a T-perm, followed by the 4x4x4 PLL parity alg to fix the > messed up wing edges. I've never actually had this situation come up > yet, but I was wondering what would be the most efficient way to do it > when it does happen. > > -Alexei Gousev
962. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: Daniel Beyer <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 22 Sep 2006 23:09:11 -0700 (PDT)

Chris, In working w/ big cube BLD. I would have to say that I'm most interested freedom. Freestyle commutators are awsome. But I do 2-cycle corners, so I'd seriously solve from the core outwards. Would it be possible to solve using a method like this. Ok, let's start simple, the 4x4x4 Look at the Buffer Edge pair, UR. Look at the fUR edge, then use a commutator to shoot the other cubie of the edge pair to bUR. the cycle would be x --> bUR --> lUB Then use a 2 cycle to permute the solved edge pair, bring in two unsolved edges. Continue pair up the second edge using commutators and 2-cycles to permute the edge pair. This would be done w/ centers solved first. Is this method feasible? cmhardw <foozman17@...> wrote: Hey Alexei, Glad that helps, I actually had never thought to try that either until I posted on this group and someone said they did that case with two three cycles. I'm just glad to be able to help "cube it forward" a little bit ;-) As for when to swap the corners on a 4x4 or 5x5 I have been saving them until the very end of the solve, but after reading your post I realized that's not necessary. The most important thing to realize is that swapping two corners on a 5x5 (which also means 2 central edges need swapping) performs an odd permutation on the X centers of the cube. You can't see this on a regular 5x5x5 cube if it's close to solved, but on the physical pieces you do in fact perform an odd permutation on the Xcenters when you swap two edges and 2 corners, even if you can't see it. If you swap two corners on a 4x4 you have also performed an odd permutation on the Xcenters there too. I would say the easiest thing is to wait until after you have solved the centers, and then swap those two corners. This way the odd permutation on the Xcenters isn't noticed, because your centers are all solved, and most algs for the corner parity only affect the centers on a given face, and don't swap them between faces. I personally have been saving the corner swaps (and edges too for the 5x5) until the very end, but I just realized that this is unnecessary for the way I solve. When I first started big cubes BLD I solved the centers last, so I had to wait until the very, very end of the solve to swap the corners. Now I solve centers first, so if I have corner parity I'm going to start swapping the corners immediately after I finish centers rather than wait until the end of the solve. There's no need to remember that information for the whole solve just to follow the tradition of the way I started solving when I think it would be much more efficient as far as the memory is concerned to just solve them immediately after the centers. And also I would say the same as advice for when would be best for you to swap corners too. Swap them immediately after you have finished solving the centers, that way you can forget about them for the rest of the solve. If you solve centers last, then I would say your safest bet is to swap the corners if you have corner parity as the very final thing you do in a solve. Just my two cents, Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "agousev" <agousev@...> wrote: > > Wow, that's so much easier. I never thought about it that way. > Thanks for your help! > > Also, on the 5x5x5 blindfold, let's say you have to switch two > corners. How, and at what point in the solve would you do this? To > me, it would make most sense to wait until the end of the solve, and > then do a T-perm, followed by the 4x4x4 PLL parity alg to fix the > messed up wing edges. I've never actually had this situation come up > yet, but I was wondering what would be the most efficient way to do it > when it does happen. > > -Alexei Gousev --------------------------------- Do you Yahoo!? 963. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Sep 2006 19:35:01 -0000

Hey Daniel,

I think your method would be feasible, the only thing that I would
wonder about would be how hard it would be to memorize. After you
pair up one edge pair, and then use a 2 cycle to move it to it's
correct location, make sure you remember how the unsolved edge pair
that you *do* move to UR is oriented when it gets to UR. Make sure
you don't swap which piece is in URf and which is in URb.

I think this will be more moves than freestyle commutators, but if it
turns out to be less thought, then you can execute your moves faster
than someone doing freestyle commutators, since those require a lot of
thought to setup each given cycle.

I like your idea to solve the centers first, otherwise you have to
keep track of how the center groups twist during your two cycles to
swap edge groups, which will perform an odd permutation on the X
centers (and +centers if on a 5x5x5).

I think it has potetential to be a good method, just make sure to be
careful about moving your unsolved edge group to UR and don't swap
which piece of the group ends up at fUR and which at bUR.

Just my thoughts, but I think it sounds like a good method.

Chris

> Chris,
>
> In working w/ big cube BLD. I would have to say that I'm most
interested freedom. Freestyle commutators are awsome. But I do
2-cycle corners, so I'd seriously solve from the core outwards.
>
> Would it be possible to solve using a method like this.
>
> Ok, let's start simple, the 4x4x4
>
> Look at the Buffer Edge pair, UR. Look at the fUR edge, then use
a commutator to shoot the other cubie of the edge pair to bUR.
> the cycle would be x --> bUR --> lUB
> Then use a 2 cycle to permute the solved edge pair, bring in two
unsolved edges. Continue pair up the second edge using commutators
and 2-cycles to permute the edge pair.
>
> This would be done w/ centers solved first.
>
> Is this method feasible?








964. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Sep 2006 19:41:03 -0000

Hey Alexei, I just tried swapping the two corners on a 4x4x4 right after solving the centers (my first step after corners) rather than saving them until the very end of the solve. To be honest, I like doing it this way MUCH better than saving them until the end. I was able to forget about the corners halfway through the solve, since I had solved all of them, rather than remember them throughout the entire solve. I would definitely recommend, no matter how you solve the bigger cubes blindfolded, for the 4x4x4 fix corner parity *immediately* after finishing the centers. For the 5x5x5 fix the corner and central edge parity *immediately* after solving all the centers. Technically you could even do this before finishing the centers, say immediately after the U layer center group is completely solved (which often happens before all the centers are solved if you memorize your cycles right). However, I think it would be better to finish centers completely rather than break them up with the corner or corner+central edge parity fix. That's just my personal opinion, but I think it would be better that way. My first solve trying to fix the corners immediately after centers was a successful solve with a total time of 8:12.46 minutes. The memorization took 4:05.xx and the solving took the rest, or about 4:07.xx Just my opinion, but already I love solving this way, as you can devote the entire rest of your solve to everything else and not even have to worry about corners anymore, rather than remember them throughout the entire solve. Definitely solve them after centers is my recommendation. If you do solve centers last, then I would say save them until last, don't break up your centers solve with the corner parity fix. Go ahead and finish everything, then fix the corner parity last would be my recommendation. Hope this helps, Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "agousev" <agousev@...> wrote: > > Wow, that's so much easier. I never thought about it that way. > Thanks for your help! > > Also, on the 5x5x5 blindfold, let's say you have to switch two > corners. How, and at what point in the solve would you do this? To > me, it would make most sense to wait until the end of the solve, and > then do a T-perm, followed by the 4x4x4 PLL parity alg to fix the > messed up wing edges. I've never actually had this situation come up > yet, but I was wondering what would be the most efficient way to do it > when it does happen. > > -Alexei Gousev
965. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Sep 2006 04:18:04 -0000

> Hey Alexei,
>
> I just tried swapping the two corners on a 4x4x4 right after solving
> the centers (my first step after corners) rather than saving them
> until the very end of the solve.
>
> To be honest, I like doing it this way MUCH better than saving them
> until the end. I was able to forget about the corners halfway through
> the solve, since I had solved all of them, rather than remember them
> throughout the entire solve.

Hey again Alexei, and also anyone else following this thread.

I just tried fixing the corner+central edge parity for 5x5x5 BLD
immediately after finish centers rather than saving it until the end.
The solve was a success and the time is my new personal fastest solve
for 5x5x5 BLD! The total time was 21 minutes 11.33 seconds, which
broke down into about 11:15 memorization and 9:55 solving.

The recall during edges, my very last step, felt so much faster. This
was because I knew I could just go break neck speed having already
finished the corner+central edge parity off right after the centers.
I usually pause at the end of my edges step to make absolutely for
certain that I am not forgetting the corner+central edge parity. This
time I knew I had already completed the parity fix right after the
centers and I just went break neck speed through the edges. A time of
roughly 9:55 for the solving phase is actually quite good for me, and
I attribute the fast time to the fact that I could more comfortably
speed through the edges knowing I didn't have to hold onto the
corner+central edge parity information and not forget it to fix at the
end. Knowing it was already fixed allowed me to comfortably speed
through the edges to end the solve.

So to answer your question, having tried the new way on the 4x4x4 and
5x5x5 I say fix the corner parity for 4x4x4 and corner+central edge
parity on 5x5x5 immediately after you have finished solving the
centers. It speeds up the rest of your solve so much if the centers
are not your last step to solve.

If the centers are your last step to solve then I still believe that
solving the corner parities are better after the centers are solved,
so either way I think it is the best option. Again that is just my
opinion, but after setting my new PB on the 5x5x5 BLD I think I am
definitely hooked on this new solving order!

Hope this helps!
Chris







966. Re: GWiz Competition Preparation
From: "agousev" <agousev@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Sep 2006 03:47:27 -0000

Chris, Great, thanks for your help! I don't have time right now to try a 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 blindfold, as it will take me at least an hour, if not more. Next time I do it however, I'll fix the parity immediately after solving centers. Thanks again! Big cube BLDing seems so much easier now... -Alexei --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > > Hey Alexei, > > > > I just tried swapping the two corners on a 4x4x4 right after solving > > the centers (my first step after corners) rather than saving them > > until the very end of the solve. > > > > To be honest, I like doing it this way MUCH better than saving them > > until the end. I was able to forget about the corners halfway through > > the solve, since I had solved all of them, rather than remember them > > throughout the entire solve. > > Hey again Alexei, and also anyone else following this thread. > > I just tried fixing the corner+central edge parity for 5x5x5 BLD > immediately after finish centers rather than saving it until the end. > The solve was a success and the time is my new personal fastest solve > for 5x5x5 BLD! The total time was 21 minutes 11.33 seconds, which > broke down into about 11:15 memorization and 9:55 solving. > > The recall during edges, my very last step, felt so much faster. This > was because I knew I could just go break neck speed having already > finished the corner+central edge parity off right after the centers. > I usually pause at the end of my edges step to make absolutely for > certain that I am not forgetting the corner+central edge parity. This > time I knew I had already completed the parity fix right after the > centers and I just went break neck speed through the edges. A time of > roughly 9:55 for the solving phase is actually quite good for me, and > I attribute the fast time to the fact that I could more comfortably > speed through the edges knowing I didn't have to hold onto the > corner+central edge parity information and not forget it to fix at the > end. Knowing it was already fixed allowed me to comfortably speed > through the edges to end the solve. > > So to answer your question, having tried the new way on the 4x4x4 and > 5x5x5 I say fix the corner parity for 4x4x4 and corner+central edge > parity on 5x5x5 immediately after you have finished solving the > centers. It speeds up the rest of your solve so much if the centers > are not your last step to solve. > > If the centers are your last step to solve then I still believe that > solving the corner parities are better after the centers are solved, > so either way I think it is the best option. Again that is just my > opinion, but after setting my new PB on the 5x5x5 BLD I think I am > definitely hooked on this new solving order! > > Hope this helps! > Chris >
967. New to Blindfold
From: "enguarde1234" <enguarde1234@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 Oct 2006 01:29:45 -0000

I understand the method, it's just hard to memorize all the cycles.
Are there any tricks to help me memorize and remember what I saw?

Rory

From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>

970. Re: New to Blindfold
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 01 Oct 2006 09:23:17 -0000

The edges are a greater problem for most in blindfold cubing, because there are more. So, perhaps, take the approach that I use. I look at my corner path first, I don't spend much time on it at all. Less than 15 seconds, maybe more if I have to make a bunch of decisions. Then I completely memorize the edges. Since I already have made decisions for the corners, I don't have to worry about losing memorization of the edges. I use a Buffer Based method. I try to visually memorize via shapes. I look at the cube as like a spiderweb. Your cycle is like the spider stringing its web. Metaphorically of course. There are some pretty patterns to notice. There are some times when you'll finish one layer of the webbing, then move onto the next string. Since I don't use Orientation as a step to my solving method. In a 2-cycle method for blindfold cubing, such as Pochmann's method, I feel that solving edges first is a lot faster, because the parity fix flows pretty nicely, because your are focusing on the edges still in a sense. Also, since I have very good recall on corners, I execute I feel I can do the corners last, even though I've spent a lot less time on them. If you are not using 2-cycles, I personally cannot give you any tips on nearly any part of your method. I've tried 3-cycles and do not understand the method. My memorization is an on the fly system. I count each piece of the cycle in the order that it comes, and I tap that piece. This recollection gives me fast recollection. At times during recall though, I do not even need to recall the finger taps, or the numbers, so I'm going to work on using the counting only, and use finger taps in case I need to reinforce a cycle. The benefit of counting is that I can keep track as to whether there is a parity or not, rather quickly, usually in less than 15s. Also, when scanning for cycles, I need to realize if there are permuted cubies, (orientation doesn't matter). So if I count 10, permuting my 10th edge, and I get the buffer cubie again for the edges, this tells me that there is a permuted cubie, so I check to see if it was oriented or not. If there are permuted cubies that have a twist I memorize that piece as n"O" || n, [1,11] suchthat N is from 1 to 11. If I start a new cycle say "skip" tapping the new edge to start a cycle on. So skips do not count as a number! In summary, Scan what ever you find easiest to memorize Then memorize the harder path. Then quickly memorize the easy path. Execute the hard path. Execute the easy path. One thing we just discussed recently was keeping your eyes open while memorizing. Trust me, it'll help a lot, so you're not losing site of the at all! This was a problem for Chris Hardwick, who uses images for his memo. He'd close his eyes to cement the images into his journey path, causing him to lose time scanning for the next pieces. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Rory Margraf <enguarde1234@...> wrote: > > You mean practicing a specific part until I can get it every time and then moving on? I'm gonna try that all this weekend. > > Thanks, > Rory > > Pedro <pedrosino1@...> wrote: > Try memorising the parts separately, at first. That's what I did and worked for me : ) > > Pedro > > enguarde1234 <enguarde1234@...> escreveu: > I understand the method, it's just hard to memorize all the cycles. > Are there any tricks to help me memorize and remember what I saw? > > Rory > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > Yahoo! Search > Música para ver e ouvir: You're Beautiful, do James Blunt > > > > > --------------------------------- > Get your email and more, right on the new Yahoo.com >
971. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] New to Blindfold
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 1 Oct 2006 10:39:23 -0300 (ART)

I mean...if you use a CO, EO, CP, EP method, memorise each of that parts alone and execute it. After some time, try to do 2 of the parts togheter, and so on Pedro Rory Margraf <enguarde1234@...> escreveu: You mean practicing a specific part until I can get it every time and then moving on? I'm gonna try that all this weekend. Thanks, Rory Pedro <pedrosino1@...> wrote: Try memorising the parts separately, at first. That's what I did and worked for me : ) Pedro enguarde1234 <enguarde1234@...> escreveu: I understand the method, it's just hard to memorize all the cycles. Are there any tricks to help me memorize and remember what I saw? Rory --------------------------------- Yahoo! Venha conferir!
972. How do you do it?
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Oct 2006 02:00:43 -0000

Alright I'm reaching a frustrated point where I cannot improve my 3x3
BLD times, and I have no idea what to do about it. I am literally
completely clueless as to how to procede, I've tried everything I can
think to do many times over so I wanted to ask and see if anyone had
any ideas.

I memorize the 3x3x3 in two very different ways, one of which is
dominant and much faster than the other. My fastest and currently
dominant way to memorize is completely visually. I will give names to
certain types of cycles. For example the cycle UB->FL->DR I call
"layers". This is because no matter which of the 3 dimensions I slice
the cube in I have one piece in each layer.

I also have certain positions for corners too UBL->UFR->DFL is called
"clockwise" things like that.

I have names for the orientations as well, but nothing as
sophisticated as what Marcus uses. UBR needing to rotate clockwise
and UFR needing to rotate counterclockwise I call "S" or "same". The
opposites twists I call "O" or "opposite".

I have peaked at around 2:10 overall average memorizing this way, but
I usually am more around 2:30 overall. I'd say I average 1:10-1:20
just to memorize, closer to 1:20 though.

I then got into big cube BLD cubing almost exactly a year ago and
learned my current images method about 6 months ago. So far with this
method I have memorized the 4x4x4 in 3 minutes many times on
successful solves, and the 5x5x5 in 10 minutes many times also on
successful solves. This includes memorizing the corners for 4x4x4 and
both corners and central edges on the 5x5 only with my usual visual
memory system that I use for the 3x3x3 (since it is my dominant and by
far fastest method).

I figure if I can memorize the 3x3x3 in 1:20 and the 4x4x4 in
3:00-4:00 minutes that my 3x3x3 memorization must be way too slow but
if you break it down into seconds per piece it's the other way around,
my 4x4x4 is way too slow also.

The 4x4x4 has 56 pieces that I need to memorize the permutation of (or
at least be aware when a piece is solved so I can know to ignore it).
I also have to know the orientation of 8 pieces.

That is essenitally 56+8=64 pieces of information. Memorizing in 3:30
means that I had to memorize 64 pieces of information in 210 seconds,
or 3.28 seconds per piece of information.

The 3x3x3 has 20 pieces where you need to know the permutation and 20
pieces where you need to know the orientation. So that's 40 pieces of
information. To memorize in 1:20 means that I had to memorize 40
pieces of info in 80 seconds. That's 2 seconds per piece of information.

Looking at it this way it seems that I in fact am memorizing the 4x4x4
way too slowly. I should probably be doing around 130-140 seconds for
the 4x4x4 or roughly 2:10-2:20.

2:10-2:20 seems very fast for the 4x4x4, but why does 1:20 not seem
very good on the 3x3x3 compared to the top level world wide?

Think about you sub-60 memorizers for the 3x3x3. Say you memorize in
40 seconds for the 3x3x3, this means that you could memorize 40 pieces
of information in 40 seconds. Using this logic you could memorize 64
pieces of information in 64 seconds, say 70 to be safe.

So the 4x4x4 could be memorized in 70 seconds if you superstar
3x3x3'ers would just give it a try.

I just don't understand how after a year of focusing on basically just
BLD solving, with enough practice to at least not be rusty on my other
puzzle categories, that I have improved my 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 BLD solving
so incredibly much, and yet my 3x3x3 times have improved by maybe 10
seconds, if that.

How do you 3x3x3 superstars average under 2 minutes for the whole
solve? I've been 3x3x3 BLD'ing for 3 solid years and hav broken 2
minutes on single solves maybe 5 times ever. Why do you superstars
not do the 4x4x4 where you could memorize in 70 seconds, solve in
3:30 and get times around 4:45 overall? I really am getting to the
point that I am frustrated with my brain's ability to memorize. I
don't understand what I am doing wrong, and it is really starting to
make me angry.

I at least feel like I can get to 2:10-2:20 for the 4x4x4 if I keep
practicing and get to where I know the personality and behavior of
every one of my images perfectly. But I think it is impossible, if
not nearly so, for me to get to 40 seconds for the 3x3x3, even though
they seem like equal feats of memory.

Why is the 3x3x3 so hard and the 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 so easy in
comparison? What am I doing wrong?!?!

Aaaaaah!! This really is driving me crazy and I really am getting
very frustrated with myself at not being able to improve. Does anyone
have any tips at all? I would very much appreciate it.

Thanks for any help,
Chris






973. Re: How do you do it?
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Oct 2006 02:15:45 -0000

Hey everyone, I just tried a 3x3x3 BLD solve after posting this. I was extremely frustrated, even a little angry, at not being able to speed up my 3x3x3 BLD. I had on some loud angry music and just did a solve. I actually got my new pb solve on the 3x3x3 for 3x3x3 BLD! I got a 1:45.13 with about 1:00 of memorization and 45 seconds of solving. So apparently the thing I hadn't tried was to just get extremely angry at myself before doing a solve :-( Seriously though, what can I do to make getting solves this fast more common? I'd rather not go around being pissed off all the time, I'd prefer to just be able to concentrate that well when I try a BLD solve. Also, even on my pb solve I could only memorize right at 1:00 (I saw the clock change on netcube to 1:00 and shortly after I put on the blindfold). That is still memorizing 40 pieces of information in 60 seconds, or 1.5 seconds per piece of information, which is still a far cry from 1.0 second per piece of information for 40 seconds of memorization. I am on the one hand extremely happy to break my PB (which has held since January 22 this year) but I'm also a little sad that to do it I had to get pissed off at myself for not being able to get faster. How can you just concentrate hard enough to get a solve that fast without having to get angry? I'm not an angry person, and I hate that I had to get angry to get a solve that fast. Thanks for any help, Chris --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Alright I'm reaching a frustrated point where I cannot improve my 3x3 > BLD times, and I have no idea what to do about it. 974. Re: How do you do it?
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 11 Oct 2006 06:52:13 -0000

Hardwick, What's up? umm ... how can you get faster without getting pissed? Well, when I was doing my best to BLD cube I would do a lot, I mean a lot of tedious or stressful things. Most were self inflicted. Such as pissing off my boss, or locking my keys in my car and then walking home. Now, like being angry all the time, why the hell would you want to do that?! Stressful events: 20 DNFs + 0 successes in one day Pissing off boss Car Breaking Down Locking Keys in car Eastsheen had it's revenge ... the 4x4x4 popped =P The point that my speedcubes have popped 8 million times I believe what caused the personal best to occur, was not anger, it was mental stress. The blindfold element of the rubik's cube is a mental thing. Memorization is mental. This can be very stressing, you become easily distracted, you don't want to BLD. When you encounter this real world stress, you immerse yourself into the cube, because you love it. It's like the cubezone as you've described before. Anger is a form of mental stress, I think part of the reason you were so successful, is because you were targeting your anger on the cube, because of the relationship you have with it. When angered your sense become dull, you are single minded. Minor distactions are insignificant. You will get the point across that you mean business. I feel living your daily life, is very stressful. Some read a book, so play games, some do drugs, we cube for that enjoyment, and removal from the world. Have you ever noticed this: Ok I feel great today, work was awsome, I just got my paychecks, my new cubes arrived, now let's BLD ... any you don't do so hot? It's not that you're having a bad day. It means you are not stressed, angered, or upset. And you do not know any other way to hone the focusing element of the BLD attempt. Another thing, do you listen to music while cubing? Music that you like?? Do you ever find yourself singing the words ... Seriously try several things. Start a solve. Turn on the music, television, a chat room (let the beep occur when somebody new enters) ... make sure you like everything that's on. If you stop to watch a segment of whatever's on tv, singing the words to the song, or in my case stopping to say hey when somebody pops into the chatroom. Stop the timer. See how long it took you to become distacted. Now something on the television that you've no interest in. Music that isn't exactly your favorite ... better yet, try something such as classical or music w/o words. Linkin Park's Session is a good example. The music can still help you relax. You are not as likely to start humming during your bld attempt. I think the point is, we've all tried avoid distractions. But why do we tempt ourselves with our favorite things? That's like trying to quit smoking then going and getting drunk, so you wanna light up cuz you always smoke when you drink. You want to avoid distractions, so you'll turn on your favorite music that you know every lyric to and you'll start singing without thinking. However that is a distaction! I don't know how they do it ... How I've made major improvements is practice. BLD is so amazing. How do you get so fast at blindfold cubing? I cut down my memo, execution, recall, and try to optimize algoritm execution. I'm going to go back to freeslice 2 Cycles. This is where instead of doing another 2-cycle alg to start the next cycle, I'll perform a move on the S slice. I'm also going to try Slice cycles for direct EP. I like my corner method, it'll take me a long time to break my 2-cycle CP unless I learn my adv 3-cycle CP, which I just found the flaw in :( Well Chris, good luck in your competitions. I'll see you in well 10 days from now!!!! Umm, I just read "I had on some loud angry music and just did a solve." Well that's fine, if that get's you pumped. Just don't be distracted by it! GL, HF, KA! Later, Daniel Beyer --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "cmhardw" <foozman17@...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > I just tried a 3x3x3 BLD solve after posting this.
