1091. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: A memory refresher.....
From: "PJK Sports Cards" <pjksportscards@...>
To: <blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 18 Dec 2006 21:28:10 -0700

Well, if you are using the T-perm for cycling, then all you need to do is setup so you don't move any corner/edge involved in the "T" swap other than the piece in the buffer position. To be honest, with using only the T-perm for cycling, I think sub-4 minute or even 3-minute average is possible, with practice. Here is Bill's guide using the T-Perm: http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/<http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh/> ----- Original Message ----- From: reusto<mailto:aruestow@...> To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, December 18, 2006 3:24 PM Subject: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: A memory refresher..... Yes, I mean moves that ruin orientation. I seem to remember that using setup moves such as F, R, B, and L; destroyed orientation. I also seem to remember that using F2, R2, B2, L2, U, D; were okay for preserving orientation. Is this correct? If I am not wording this properly please let me know and I will come up with an example. I appreciate your patience as I have spent about 2 years away from the cube, and I am just now starting to learn BLD. Thanks again, Andy --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com>, "Tyson Mao" <tyson.mao@...> wrote: > > You mean, that ruin orientation? > > Well, it depends how you define orientation... > > -Tyson > > On 12/18/06, reusto <aruestow@...> wrote: > > > > I could really use a simple memory refresher. It's been a while since > > I have cubed, and I am ready for some BLD, I plan on starting with a > > simple method, using a 2-flip for EO, the slow steady method for CO, > > and using T-perms for cycling. > > > > Could somebody please remind me which face turns I must avoid using as > > setup moves (ie. moves that ruin parity) > > > > Thanks very much, > > > > Andy > > > > > > >

1098. Sub80
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Dec 2006 02:13:10 -0000

To get past the 80 barrier, I think it's a matter of speeding up EP.
The rest of the cube can basically be done very quickly without any
memory hooks, but trying to do EP rotely is very difficult to do
quickly. I was able to cut times down to sub80 on many occasions
using a good EP system -- just this morning I was able to get 1:11. I
think it is possible to pass even the 60 barrier on a consistent basis
with enough work.

1100. 4x4x4 BLD average
From: "cmhardw" <foozman17@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 20 Dec 2006 19:00:56 -0000

Made it to sub-8 for a 4x4x4 BLD average:

1) 7:01.69
2) DNF
3) DNF
4) DNF
5) (8:11.31)
6) DNF
7) DNF
8) 7:18.85
9) 6:42.55
10) 6:42.38
11) DNF
12) 7:51.52
13) DNF
14) 7:25.34
15) 7:18.36
16) 7:47.42
17) 7:23.34
18) 7:44.60
19) (6:32.19)

7:19.61 is the average of the middle 10 solves.

It took me 19 solves to get an average of 12 so my accuracy is 12/19
or about 63%

Lately I have been trying to go very quickly for memorization and
absolutely break neck full speed for solving. I'm trying to get used
to going much faster than my comfortable pace so as to improve my
overall speed when trying to go more carefully. Once I get more used
to this speed I'm curious if I can get a sub-8 average with a high
accuracy like 80-90% - that's my goal now.

Still, right now I'm glad to just get a sub-8 average period :-D

Happy BLD cubing all,
Chris

1102. Re: Sub80
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 21 Dec 2006 03:35:39 -0000

EP takes the longest for me, so I can only speak for myself. Which part gives you the most trouble? --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Tyson Mao" <tyson.mao@...> wrote: > > But EP doesn't take that long. Even though there are 12-edges, the freedom > you have in setup moves makes it very fluid. > > On 12/19/06, kyuubree <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > > > To get past the 80 barrier, I think it's a matter of speeding up EP. > > The rest of the cube can basically be done very quickly without any > > memory hooks, but trying to do EP rotely is very difficult to do > > quickly. I was able to cut times down to sub80 on many occasions > > using a good EP system -- just this morning I was able to get 1:11. I > > think it is possible to pass even the 60 barrier on a consistent basis > > with enough work. > > > > > > >
1103. Sample EP
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Dec 2006 20:51:15 -0000

Hey,

I'm not good at cycle style. Here's a sample EP: Just do F2 D' B R
B L U' L' U B to setup.

Now I go to memorize. I start at UF and see that the cycle goes UF-
>DF->DR->DL, then ends, and I have to recall that I have two to swap
now.

Next my eyes go back up to my next spot, UL. I see that the cycle
goes UL->BR->UB->BL, then ends, and again I have to recall another
two to swap.

Next my eyes go up again to my next spot, UB, but I had UB in my last
cycle, so I skip it, and go to my next spot, UR. I see that the
cycle goes UR->FL->FR->DB, ends, and once again I have two to swap.

So I have now UF needs to swap with DL, UL with BL, and UR with DB.

I have not yet come up with a good way to memorize this situation,
nor do I have a good way to solve it.

Assuming that for a 1:20 solve I'd need to memorize this in at least
30 sec, I haven't been able to do it.

Unrelated note: What do you guys do when you have 10 edges to flip?

I hope no typos and no mistakes.

-Dave O.














1104. Re: Sample EP
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Dec 2006 21:42:05 -0000

Usually when I have a bunch of random edges to flip, I usually flip all 12 then flip the two I messed up. As for the cycles, when I have a bunch of doubles, I cycle them as normal, knowing that the FIRST edge of the next cycle will simply go to the back. So in your case you have (UF DF DR DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB). Cycle (UF DF DR) as normal and you now get (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB). Instead of "keeping UF DL in mind for later," go ahead and cycle (UF DL UL), knowing it'll drop DL and kick UL (the end of the first cycle) to the end of its own cycle. (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB) becomes (UF BR UB BL UL) (UR FL FR DB). The cool thing about this approach is that it doesn't disturb your memory much -- all it does is finish off the second element of cycle 1 and kick the start of cycle 2 to the end. All you need to remember is what the start of the second cycle was specifically -- and be able to kick it to the end. So in this case you'd do (UF BR UB) then (UF BL UL) to finish off that mutated second cycle. Then you got (UR FL FR DB) to reduce after doing (UR FL FR), in which case you then have (UR DB) and thus a parity error. I still haven't devised an easy way to deal with parities. I am thinking maybe Pochmann approach would be best here? Simple two cycle of corners and edges using T Perms... very mindless and easy to do. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, smoothcuber <no_reply@...> wrote: > > Hey, > > I'm not good at cycle style. Here's a sample EP: Just do F2 D' B R > B L U' L' U B to setup. > > Now I go to memorize. I start at UF and see that the cycle goes UF- > >DF->DR->DL, then ends, and I have to recall that I have two to swap > now. > > Next my eyes go back up to my next spot, UL. I see that the cycle > goes UL->BR->UB->BL, then ends, and again I have to recall another > two to swap. > > Next my eyes go up again to my next spot, UB, but I had UB in my last > cycle, so I skip it, and go to my next spot, UR. I see that the > cycle goes UR->FL->FR->DB, ends, and once again I have two to swap. > > So I have now UF needs to swap with DL, UL with BL, and UR with DB. > > I have not yet come up with a good way to memorize this situation, > nor do I have a good way to solve it. > > Assuming that for a 1:20 solve I'd need to memorize this in at least > 30 sec, I haven't been able to do it. > > Unrelated note: What do you guys do when you have 10 edges to flip? > > I hope no typos and no mistakes. > > -Dave O. >
1105. Re: Sample EP
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Dec 2006 21:47:52 -0000

In case I made any typos: In the case of (a b)(c d) where a, b, and c denote arbitrary singular pieces within a cycle and d denotes any number of edges within that cycle (could be as low as 0 or as high as 9): (a b)(c d) can be thought of as (a b c d c). Hope this helps. -Marcus Stuhr --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > Usually when I have a bunch of random edges to flip, I usually flip > all 12 then flip the two I messed up. > > As for the cycles, when I have a bunch of doubles, I cycle them as > normal, knowing that the FIRST edge of the next cycle will simply go > to the back. > > So in your case you have (UF DF DR DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB). > Cycle (UF DF DR) as normal and you now get (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR > FL FR DB). Instead of "keeping UF DL in mind for later," go ahead and > cycle (UF DL UL), knowing it'll drop DL and kick UL (the end of the > first cycle) to the end of its own cycle. > > (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB) becomes (UF BR UB BL UL) (UR FL FR > DB). The cool thing about this approach is that it doesn't disturb > your memory much -- all it does is finish off the second element of > cycle 1 and kick the start of cycle 2 to the end. All you need to > remember is what the start of the second cycle was specifically -- and > be able to kick it to the end. So in this case you'd do (UF BR UB) > then (UF BL UL) to finish off that mutated second cycle. Then you got > (UR FL FR DB) to reduce after doing (UR FL FR), in which case you then > have (UR DB) and thus a parity error. > > I still haven't devised an easy way to deal with parities. I am > thinking maybe Pochmann approach would be best here? Simple two cycle > of corners and edges using T Perms... very mindless and easy to do. > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, smoothcuber > <no_reply@> wrote: > > > > Hey, > > > > I'm not good at cycle style. Here's a sample EP: Just do F2 D' B R > > B L U' L' U B to setup. > > > > Now I go to memorize. I start at UF and see that the cycle goes UF- > > >DF->DR->DL, then ends, and I have to recall that I have two to swap > > now. > > > > Next my eyes go back up to my next spot, UL. I see that the cycle > > goes UL->BR->UB->BL, then ends, and again I have to recall another > > two to swap. > > > > Next my eyes go up again to my next spot, UB, but I had UB in my last > > cycle, so I skip it, and go to my next spot, UR. I see that the > > cycle goes UR->FL->FR->DB, ends, and once again I have two to swap. > > > > So I have now UF needs to swap with DL, UL with BL, and UR with DB. > > > > I have not yet come up with a good way to memorize this situation, > > nor do I have a good way to solve it. > > > > Assuming that for a 1:20 solve I'd need to memorize this in at least > > 30 sec, I haven't been able to do it. > > > > Unrelated note: What do you guys do when you have 10 edges to flip? > > > > I hope no typos and no mistakes. > > > > -Dave O. > > >
1106. Re: Sample EP
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 23 Dec 2006 21:53:08 -0000

God I typoed again. Obviously d is between 1 and 9, not 0 and 9. Doesn't make sense to apply the rule to (ab)(c) --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > In case I made any typos: > > In the case of (a b)(c d) where a, b, and c denote arbitrary singular > pieces within a cycle and d denotes any number of edges within that > cycle (could be as low as 0 or as high as 9): > > (a b)(c d) can be thought of as (a b c d c). > > Hope this helps. > > -Marcus Stuhr > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" > <agent_m80@> wrote: > > > > Usually when I have a bunch of random edges to flip, I usually flip > > all 12 then flip the two I messed up. > > > > As for the cycles, when I have a bunch of doubles, I cycle them as > > normal, knowing that the FIRST edge of the next cycle will simply go > > to the back. > > > > So in your case you have (UF DF DR DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB). > > Cycle (UF DF DR) as normal and you now get (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR > > FL FR DB). Instead of "keeping UF DL in mind for later," go ahead and > > cycle (UF DL UL), knowing it'll drop DL and kick UL (the end of the > > first cycle) to the end of its own cycle. > > > > (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB) becomes (UF BR UB BL UL) (UR FL FR > > DB). The cool thing about this approach is that it doesn't disturb > > your memory much -- all it does is finish off the second element of > > cycle 1 and kick the start of cycle 2 to the end. All you need to > > remember is what the start of the second cycle was specifically -- and > > be able to kick it to the end. So in this case you'd do (UF BR UB) > > then (UF BL UL) to finish off that mutated second cycle. Then you got > > (UR FL FR DB) to reduce after doing (UR FL FR), in which case you then > > have (UR DB) and thus a parity error. > > > > I still haven't devised an easy way to deal with parities. I am > > thinking maybe Pochmann approach would be best here? Simple two cycle > > of corners and edges using T Perms... very mindless and easy to do. > > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, smoothcuber > > <no_reply@> wrote: > > > > > > Hey, > > > > > > I'm not good at cycle style. Here's a sample EP: Just do F2 D' B R > > > B L U' L' U B to setup. > > > > > > Now I go to memorize. I start at UF and see that the cycle goes UF- > > > >DF->DR->DL, then ends, and I have to recall that I have two to swap > > > now. > > > > > > Next my eyes go back up to my next spot, UL. I see that the cycle > > > goes UL->BR->UB->BL, then ends, and again I have to recall another > > > two to swap. > > > > > > Next my eyes go up again to my next spot, UB, but I had UB in my last > > > cycle, so I skip it, and go to my next spot, UR. I see that the > > > cycle goes UR->FL->FR->DB, ends, and once again I have two to swap. > > > > > > So I have now UF needs to swap with DL, UL with BL, and UR with DB. > > > > > > I have not yet come up with a good way to memorize this situation, > > > nor do I have a good way to solve it. > > > > > > Assuming that for a 1:20 solve I'd need to memorize this in at least > > > 30 sec, I haven't been able to do it. > > > > > > Unrelated note: What do you guys do when you have 10 edges to flip? > > > > > > I hope no typos and no mistakes. > > > > > > -Dave O. > > > > > >
1107. Re: Sample EP
From: smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Dec 2006 00:56:37 -0000

Thanks a lot Marcus. I"ve been messing around with this and it is indeed cool and a valuable tip. I can see I have a lot to learn yet about cycling. I hope I'm not the only one that you've helped. Thanks again. -Dave O. In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > Usually when I have a bunch of random edges to flip, I usually flip > all 12 then flip the two I messed up. > > As for the cycles, when I have a bunch of doubles, I cycle them as > normal, knowing that the FIRST edge of the next cycle will simply go > to the back. > > So in your case you have (UF DF DR DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB). > Cycle (UF DF DR) as normal and you now get (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR > FL FR DB). Instead of "keeping UF DL in mind for later," go ahead and > cycle (UF DL UL), knowing it'll drop DL and kick UL (the end of the > first cycle) to the end of its own cycle. > > (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB) becomes (UF BR UB BL UL) (UR FL FR > DB). The cool thing about this approach is that it doesn't disturb > your memory much -- all it does is finish off the second element of > cycle 1 and kick the start of cycle 2 to the end. All you need to > remember is what the start of the second cycle was specifically -- and > be able to kick it to the end. So in this case you'd do (UF BR UB) > then (UF BL UL) to finish off that mutated second cycle. Then you got > (UR FL FR DB) to reduce after doing (UR FL FR), in which case you then > have (UR DB) and thus a parity error. > > I still haven't devised an easy way to deal with parities. I am > thinking maybe Pochmann approach would be best here? Simple two cycle > of corners and edges using T Perms... very mindless and easy to do. > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, smoothcuber > <no_reply@> wrote: > > > > Hey, > > > > I'm not good at cycle style. Here's a sample EP: Just do F2 D' B R > > B L U' L' U B to setup. > > > > Now I go to memorize. I start at UF and see that the cycle goes UF- > > >DF->DR->DL, then ends, and I have to recall that I have two to swap > > now. > > > > Next my eyes go back up to my next spot, UL. I see that the cycle > > goes UL->BR->UB->BL, then ends, and again I have to recall another > > two to swap. > > > > Next my eyes go up again to my next spot, UB, but I had UB in my last > > cycle, so I skip it, and go to my next spot, UR. I see that the > > cycle goes UR->FL->FR->DB, ends, and once again I have two to swap. > > > > So I have now UF needs to swap with DL, UL with BL, and UR with DB. > > > > I have not yet come up with a good way to memorize this situation, > > nor do I have a good way to solve it. > > > > Assuming that for a 1:20 solve I'd need to memorize this in at least > > 30 sec, I haven't been able to do it. > > > > Unrelated note: What do you guys do when you have 10 edges to flip? > > > > I hope no typos and no mistakes. > > > > -Dave O. > > >
1108. Success!!!
From: "reusto" <aruestow@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 03:21:58 -0000

After 3 DNF's I just completed my first successful BLD solve!!!

It was a great feeling to take off my winter hat and see the solved cube!

It was a pretty easy solve...

EO: 4 6 10 12
CO: (x221)(2111)
CP: (276)(141)
EP: (8,6,7,5,9,3,11,10,4,12)

Happy Boxing Day!! :-D

(xxxx) represent corners 1-4 on the top. 0 is solved, 1 is a cw turn away, 2 is a ccw turn away. ----- Original Message ----- From: Tyson Mao<mailto:tyson.mao@...> To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, December 27, 2006 10:28 AM Subject: Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Success!!! 1114. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Sample EP
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 16:29:26 -0300 (ART)

So...you memorise EP first...what about the rest? which order? I do CO EO CP EP, and solve the same way...I guess it's because that was the way I learned from Macky's site : ) and by 6 flip you mean (R B R' U)*5? or what? Pedro Tyson Mao <tyson.mao@...> escreveu: Uh... for a 1:20 solve, you don't have 30 seconds to memorize EP. You mean 30 seconds for the entire Rubik's Cube right? Typically, I have my EP memorized in under 20 seconds. I generally glance up at the timer after EP and use it as a benchmark to see how my memorization is going. A good EP I can memorize in about 12 seconds. The slow ones get closer to 20 and sometimes if I'm tired, maybe 22 seconds. For 10-edge flip, I generally do 6 + 4. The super-12-edge flip algorithm consists of two 6-flips for me, which takes time. I find it faster to do a 6 flip + a 4 flip because the 4 flip is so fast. Though, I rarely run across the case, so I haven't had much chance to practice. -Tyson On 12/24/06, smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: Thanks a lot Marcus. I"ve been messing around with this and it is indeed cool and a valuable tip. I can see I have a lot to learn yet about cycling. I hope I'm not the only one that you've helped. Thanks again. -Dave O. In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...> wrote: > > Usually when I have a bunch of random edges to flip, I usually flip > all 12 then flip the two I messed up. > > As for the cycles, when I have a bunch of doubles, I cycle them as > normal, knowing that the FIRST edge of the next cycle will simply go > to the back. > > So in your case you have (UF DF DR DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB). > Cycle (UF DF DR) as normal and you now get (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR > FL FR DB). Instead of "keeping UF DL in mind for later," go ahead and > cycle (UF DL UL), knowing it'll drop DL and kick UL (the end of the > first cycle) to the end of its own cycle. > > (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB) becomes (UF BR UB BL UL) (UR FL FR > DB). The cool thing about this approach is that it doesn't disturb > your memory much -- all it does is finish off the second element of > cycle 1 and kick the start of cycle 2 to the end. All you need to > remember is what the start of the second cycle was specifically -- and > be able to kick it to the end. So in this case you'd do (UF BR UB) > then (UF BL UL) to finish off that mutated second cycle. Then you got > (UR FL FR DB) to reduce after doing (UR FL FR), in which case you then > have (UR DB) and thus a parity error. > > I still haven't devised an easy way to deal with parities. I am > thinking maybe Pochmann approach would be best here? Simple two cycle > of corners and edges using T Perms... very mindless and easy to do. > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, smoothcuber > <no_reply@> wrote: > > > > Hey, > > > > I'm not good at cycle style. Here's a sample EP: Just do F2 D' B R > > B L U' L' U B to setup. > > > > Now I go to memorize. I start at UF and see that the cycle goes UF- > > >DF->DR->DL, then ends, and I have to recall that I have two to swap > > now. > > > > Next my eyes go back up to my next spot, UL. I see that the cycle > > goes UL->BR->UB->BL, then ends, and again I have to recall another > > two to swap. > > > > Next my eyes go up again to my next spot, UB, but I had UB in my last > > cycle, so I skip it, and go to my next spot, UR. I see that the > > cycle goes UR->FL->FR->DB, ends, and once again I have two to swap. > > > > So I have now UF needs to swap with DL, UL with BL, and UR with DB. > > > > I have not yet come up with a good way to memorize this situation, > > nor do I have a good way to solve it. > > > > Assuming that for a 1:20 solve I'd need to memorize this in at least > > 30 sec, I haven't been able to do it. > > > > Unrelated note: What do you guys do when you have 10 edges to flip? > > > > I hope no typos and no mistakes. > > > > -Dave O. > > > __________________________________________________ Fale com seus amigos de graÂ¤a com o novo Yahoo! represent corners 1-4 on the top. 0 is solved, 1 is a cw turn away, 2
is a ccw turn away."

The sum of the corner orientation is 10. This isn't a legal
orienation case.

1118. Re: Sample EP
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 19:55:35 -0000

I was wondering about your 3-cycle methods. Do you always use the Edge PLLs? Do you use 2-gen, or optimal face-turn-metric algs?? Does anybody use other 2-gen algs such as R'URU'R'U'R'U'RUR2 or RU'R'URURUR'U'R2? I think the EP system can be fast w/ a system like such, where you set the first cubie to the U layer, and the next cubie is setup by d move. Does anybody use this approach? -- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@...> wrote: > > So...you memorise EP first...what about the rest? which order? > I do CO EO CP EP, and solve the same way...I guess it's because that was the way I learned from Macky's site : ) > > and by 6 flip you mean (R B R' U)*5? or what? > > Pedro > > Tyson Mao <tyson.mao@...> escreveu: Uh... for a 1:20 solve, you don't have 30 seconds to memorize EP. You mean 30 seconds for the entire Rubik's Cube right? Typically, I have my EP memorized in under 20 seconds. I generally glance up at the timer after EP and use it as a benchmark to see how my memorization is going. A good EP I can memorize in about 12 seconds. The slow ones get closer to 20 and sometimes if I'm tired, maybe 22 seconds. > > For 10-edge flip, I generally do 6 + 4. The super-12-edge flip algorithm consists of two 6-flips for me, which takes time. I find it faster to do a 6 flip + a 4 flip because the 4 flip is so fast. Though, I rarely run across the case, so I haven't had much chance to practice. > > -Tyson > > > On 12/24/06, smoothcuber <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > Thanks a lot Marcus. I"ve been messing around with this and it is > indeed cool and a valuable tip. I can see I have a lot to learn yet > about cycling. I hope I'm not the only one that you've helped. > Thanks again. > > -Dave O. > > In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "kyuubree" > > <agent_m80@> wrote: > > > > Usually when I have a bunch of random edges to flip, I usually flip > > all 12 then flip the two I messed up. > > > > As for the cycles, when I have a bunch of doubles, I cycle them as > > normal, knowing that the FIRST edge of the next cycle will simply go > > to the back. > > > > So in your case you have (UF DF DR DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB). > > Cycle (UF DF DR) as normal and you now get (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR > > FL FR DB). Instead of "keeping UF DL in mind for later," go ahead > and > > cycle (UF DL UL), knowing it'll drop DL and kick UL (the end of the > > first cycle) to the end of its own cycle. > > > > (UF DL) (UL BR UB BL) (UR FL FR DB) becomes (UF BR UB BL UL) (UR FL > FR > > DB). The cool thing about this approach is that it doesn't disturb > > your memory much -- all it does is finish off the second element of > > cycle 1 and kick the start of cycle 2 to the end. All you need to > > remember is what the start of the second cycle was specifically -- > and > > be able to kick it to the end. So in this case you'd do (UF BR UB) > > then (UF BL UL) to finish off that mutated second cycle. Then you > got > > (UR FL FR DB) to reduce after doing (UR FL FR), in which case you > then > > have (UR DB) and thus a parity error. > > > > I still haven't devised an easy way to deal with parities. I am > > thinking maybe Pochmann approach would be best here? Simple two > cycle > > of corners and edges using T Perms... very mindless and easy to do. > > > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, smoothcuber > > <no_reply@> wrote: > > > > > > Hey, > > > > > > I'm not good at cycle style. Here's a sample EP: Just do F2 D' > B R > > > B L U' L' U B to setup. > > > > > > Now I go to memorize. I start at UF and see that the cycle goes > UF- > > > >DF->DR->DL, then ends, and I have to recall that I have two to > swap > > > now. > > > > > > Next my eyes go back up to my next spot, UL. I see that the > cycle > > > goes UL->BR->UB->BL, then ends, and again I have to recall > another > > > two to swap. > > > > > > Next my eyes go up again to my next spot, UB, but I had UB in my > last > > > cycle, so I skip it, and go to my next spot, UR. I see that the > > > cycle goes UR->FL->FR->DB, ends, and once again I have two to > swap. > > > > > > So I have now UF needs to swap with DL, UL with BL, and UR with > DB. > > > > > > I have not yet come up with a good way to memorize this > situation, > > > nor do I have a good way to solve it. > > > > > > Assuming that for a 1:20 solve I'd need to memorize this in at > least > > > 30 sec, I haven't been able to do it. > > > > > > Unrelated note: What do you guys do when you have 10 edges to > flip? > > > > > > I hope no typos and no mistakes. > > > > > > -Dave O. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________________________ > Fale com seus amigos de graça com o novo Yahoo! 1119. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Success!!!

1120. Re: Success!!!
From: "reusto" <aruestow@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 20:30:25 -0000

Tyson,

When I remember my corner orientation, I don't need to remember the
orientation of corner one (UFL), since the method I use is a bit
remedial and slow.

I move an improperly orientated corner into UFR and do ...
L D R' D' L' D R D' Z R' D' L D R D' L' D Z'

So by the time I fix corners 2-8, corner one has to take on the proper
orientation by default, its a 'slow but sure' method.

hope I explained it clearly.

~Andy

To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 12:46:56 -0800

[ Attachment content not displayed ]

1124. Re: Success!!!
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 21:42:02 -0000

My question is how you go about the CO memorization. I mean sometimes you don't have perfect groups of 2/3/4 on a given layer. Do you just pick out what you see at first glance and then use the residual with the other layer? --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, "Tyson Mao" <tyson.mao@...> wrote: > > The idea for corner orientation is you look at things in groups and not as > individual pieces. > > Types of groups are pairs, groups of 3, groups of 4, and if you're more > advanced, groups of 5. (5 can be considered as 2 + 3). > > If you see a pair, it's generally pretty clear on how to orient those two. > If they're next to each other, it's quite simple. If they're not next to > each other, it only takes one setup move to put them next to each other. > The setup move isn't necessary unless they're both in different layers. > > Groups of 3 are also pretty quick. Usually, they're all next to each > other. If not, you need a setup move. In a couple cases, you need two > setup moves. > > For a group of four, there's only two different patterns. One is 1 2 1 2 > and the other is 1 1 2 2. You simply learn to recognize these and execute > the correct algorithms. > > Does this help? > > -Tyson > > On 12/27/06, reusto <aruestow@...> wrote: > > > > I am not sure that what I do is easier either, I just learned this > > method from Bill site last week, and currently it is all that I know. > > > > Do you have any resources that describe your method? I would be very > > interested to learn more! > > > > Thanks very much, > > > > ~Andy > > > > > > >
1125. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Success!!!
From: "Tyson Mao" <tyson.mao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 13:49:12 -0800

1126. Re: Success!!!
From: "reusto" <aruestow@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 22:02:12 -0000

Yes that does make sense, it will take some time for me to become more
comfortable with these different methods.

It took me about 1 week to feel good with my setup moves, this has
been extremely fun to learn because there is always another deeper
layer to learn to help reduce times.

1127. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Success!!!
From: "PJK Sports Cards" <pjksportscards@...>
To: <blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 17:18:08 -0700

Yes, Bill teaches it so that you skip the first corner because you know that after all the others are done, it will be done. So in his case, every single corner was oriented wrong. ----- Original Message ----- From: Tyson Mao<mailto:tyson.mao@...> To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, December 27, 2006 1:34 PM Subject: Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Success!!! I had it explained to me just now. You go through and orient each corner, using the x-corner as a free one. When 7 corners are oriented, the last one is done as well. -Tyson On 12/27/06, Daniel Beyer <dbeyer816@...<mailto:dbeyer816@...>> wrote: Quote: "That is how Bill remembers his CO, and how he teaches it. (xxxx) represent corners 1-4 on the top. 0 is solved, 1 is a cw turn away, 2 is a ccw turn away." Then how is this right?! > > > CO: (x221)(2111) The sum of the corner orientation is 10. This isn't a legal orienation case. Later, Daniel Beyer
1128. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Success!!!
From: "PJK Sports Cards" <pjksportscards@...>
To: <blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 2006 19:51:29 -0700

What I do currently for CO is I remember it very last. This way I don't really remember anything, I just look at it, plan out the algs/setups I need for them, and then do that, then go back to what I remembered before. I have found it very quick to do it that way. I use the alg from Mackys site for CO: A = (R'D'RD)x2 Then, to flip UFL and UFR, I use U'AUA'. To flip 3 corners clockwise, just do A as I move each piece I want flipped into the position where I am doing the flipping, which is typically 2. If you do a z' move before you perform the alg, it goes very quick. I can usually have CO/memo of that done in about 15-30 seconds, which is by far the quickest piece for me. ----- Original Message ----- From: Tyson Mao<mailto:tyson.mao@...> To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com<mailto:blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, December 27, 2006 2:36 PM Subject: Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: Success!!! The idea for corner orientation is you look at things in groups and not as individual pieces. Types of groups are pairs, groups of 3, groups of 4, and if you're more advanced, groups of 5. (5 can be considered as 2 + 3). If you see a pair, it's generally pretty clear on how to orient those two. If they're next to each other, it's quite simple. If they're not next to each other, it only takes one setup move to put them next to each other. The setup move isn't necessary unless they're both in different layers. Groups of 3 are also pretty quick. Usually, they're all next to each other. If not, you need a setup move. In a couple cases, you need two setup moves. For a group of four, there's only two different patterns. One is 1 2 1 2 and the other is 1 1 2 2. You simply learn to recognize these and execute the correct algorithms. Does this help? -Tyson On 12/27/06, reusto <aruestow@...<mailto:aruestow@...u>> wrote: I am not sure that what I do is easier either, I just learned this method from Bill site last week, and currently it is all that I know. Do you have any resources that describe your method? I would be very interested to learn more! Thanks very much, ~Andy

Pochmann's method...

2 memorizing times: ?
3 solving times: ?

For me, 2 minutes + 3 minutes + 3 minutes --> 8 minutes

THANKS

1133. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: times with pochmann method ?
From: Daniel Beyer <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Dec 2006 13:38:16 -0800 (PST)

Ouch Tyson... that last general comment was harsh haha! Dude, I understand what you mean about analyzing then memorizing. I do the same. If I see multiple disoriented edges that are permuted, I'll think how can I set them up to do a 2-edge flip? Mind you I use Pochmann too. I try and make things as braindead as possible. This piece, ok that's how I solve it, and that's always how. One step in analysis I used to take was to take the chance to avoid the LU as a piece in the cycle. I found scanning for pieces is a lot slower than scanning over the locations. I am solving the 3x3 in about 160-170 at the moment, even when I think memo is attrocious! As for memorizing. I memorize visually. I count as I go along. I don't have UL, RF, and etc set as numbers, but I count as I go along. I'd have to say about 90 and 90 for each portion of the solve. This can be improved surely. Good luck man!! I am looking into a 3-cycle method where you orient all edges then set the first cubie to the U layer(2 move max), and then adjust the D and E slice w/ d turns so that you can solve the cycle with 2-gen. Setups are limited to {D,d,L,l} and a very fast alg system. I really hope to practice with it, however, big cube bld and work are taking prescedence. You can learn a lot from self exploration, don't always ask questions, find your own answers to your own problems. Not saying you shouldn't be asking right now, but you can learn a lot from independent study as well. Tyson Mao <tyson.mao@...> wrote: By no means am I belittling your abilities to solve the Rubik's Cube blindfolded. I was wondering how you distinguish between analyze and memorize? I ask this because when I started blindfold cubing, I approached it differently. I would memorize all the information first, and then analyze it later after I had put the blindfold on. The idea when I started was to have all the information committed to memory, and then go along and figure out what each cycle was. This method works all right if you have a fast memory, but it depends on your ability to "look ahead" while solving blindfolded. If you can analyze the next cycle while you perform the current cycle, then you're in good shape. For me now, since I've probably done every possible cycle on the cube, the analysis is pretty quick, so there isn't much delay as long as my memory is smooth. However, there are cases where I do "analyze" before I "memorize." Well, the idea is to analyze and memorize at the same time, or use your analyze as the memory. In certain cases, it's easier to memorize something during the analysis. An example... perhaps you notice that B2 + (R' F R F')x3 + B2 solves a certain corner parity. Instead of memorizing the positions of the cycles (or transpositions), I would analyze them while I was looking at the cube, and memorize the analysis, and not the cycle paths. I guess my input here is not to limit yourself to one method or another. Whichever way is easier for you to memorize the cube, you might as well go with it. In this manner, you will gain comfort with more ways to memorize and attack the cube, and you'll have more tools in your arsenal and have a greater ability to handle more complex mental tasks. So... don't always analyze, then memorize. Sometimes, it works, but in some situations, it might be faster to do it the other way around. Play around with it... Sorry if I sounded condescending. I don't mean to be. I just don't want to hear you (a general you, not you in particular) say that you average BLD solving in 30 seconds, but then have no idea of the OLL + U-perm for corner orientation. -Tyson On 12/28/06, cubix147 <cwoitte@...> wrote: My dear Tyson , I'm not as fast as you are in fact, I analyze and then I memorize , I can't do these two things in one... I search my way to solve and then I repeat it in my head to remember it... I know I am a beginner... __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around http://mail.yahoo.com
1134. Re: times with pochmann method ?
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Dec 2006 21:54:06 -0000

Yeah, not everyone knows the same algorithms, especially by name -- sometimes people like figuring out different algorithms that work better. I'd assume a fair number aren't entirely certain what an "OLL + UPerm" is (some may even say it's practical but not optimal in length), but can accomplish the same effect through other means. There are many ways to skin a cat (or blindfold-solve a cube). Daniel, what is your opinion on using Pochmann method for parity errors? Those things have always killed me... they add a sickening amount of wasted energy and time to my... well, times. Figuring out how to set up two corners and two edges into a reasonable position (preserving orientation) to execute a PLL algorithm is sometimes difficult (I still have not relearned all of PLL because I no longer have an interest in purely speedcubing, although one of these days I should just buck it up and relearn it all), and it requires a lot of disgusting manipulations for me. However, do you think it is possible, or even ultimately pragmatic to use Pochmann for this exception instead? How fast could a parity error be solved on average given two oriented corners and two oriented edges (which could be anywhere on the cube)? --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Daniel Beyer <dbeyer816@...> wrote: > > Ouch Tyson... that last general comment was harsh haha! > Dude, I understand what you mean about analyzing then memorizing. > I do the same. 1135. Re: times with pochmann method ?
From: "Daniel Beyer" <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Dec 2006 07:35:42 -0000


First, allow me to differentiate between two terms that I will use
often.
Setup: To use moves bring the target piece into a target area. [d'l']
would be the setup to move the RF to the UL
Conjugation: By true definition setups are conjugations. However, I
will refer to a conjugation as a setup move that cancels moves on the
algorithm.

FRU'R'U'RUR'F'RUR'U'R'FRF' is the standard Y permutation, Conjugated by
F' and a cube rotation, we get: [y'F']FRU'R'U'RUR'F'RUR'U'R'FRF'[Fy] ==
y'RU'R'U'RUR'F'RUR'U'R'FRy
Notice how the moves canceled out. And see that this setup alg:
[d'l']RUR'U'R'FR2U'R'U'RUR'F'[ld] has no canceling effect as the y perm
did.
[My approach to solving the cube blindfolded]
Solve edges one at a time
-3 PLL are used
-All three involve the UR and another U layer edge
-All three swap the UFR and URB
-No orientation phase is necassary, permutation and orientation are
solved by the proper setup
What is the parity?
-A parity occurs when I use an odd number of 2-cycles to solve the edges
-At this point, the UFR and URB are swapped
-To continue use a two cycle that swaps the UFR and URB, restoring
corner permuation
-I use LU'R'UL'U2RU'R'U2R, this swaps the two corners and the UR and UB
Is the parity really fixed? (The UR and UB are swapped afterall!)
-Yes, it is. The corners require an odd number of 2-cycles to be solved
as well
-Using Conjgated PLLs that swap the UR and UB, once the corners are
solved the edges will be restored
Solve the corners one at a time
-3 basic conjugations of the PLL are used to solve the corners
-All three swap the URB and a face on the DFL (that is the DFL, FLD, and
LDF)
-As said before the UR and UB are the corners being swapped
Pochmann uses 1 alg for corners, why use 3?
-I use 3 algs to reduce setup moves
-I actually use even more than 3, I have deeper conjugations of the PLL
-However 3 is the bare minimum to always use one face move per setup
-Through the use of PLL and Conjugations thereof, 12 corner cases can be
solved w/o setup
-Of the 9 left, only 3 require a face move that is 2 quarter turns

Examples of a deeper conjugation:
[y'R'F']FRU'R'U'RUR'F'RUR'U'R'FRF'[FRy] == y'U'R'U'RUR'F'RUR'U'R'FR2y
[y'R2F']FRU'R'U'RUR'F'RUR'U'R'FRF'[FR2y] == y'R'U'R'U'RUR'F'RUR'U'R'FR'y

A standard 2-cycle method, such as pochmanns or mine cannot be used
haphazardly with 3-cycles. A 2-cycle method has controlled areas in
which the cube is affected.
You want to use it so you can swap any two corners and any two edges.
However, Pochmann's method specifically swaps the same two edges and two
corners every solve.

I have a solution to your problem, you may not like it though, but you
definitely don't like your approach to parity fixing, so I'll discuss my
thoughts w/ you later. And yes, this will preserve EO and CO, however,
these two steps must be done before my concept is applied.

Later,
Daniel Beyer

A 2-cycle method has controlled areas in > which the cube is affected. > You want to use it so you can swap any two corners and any two edges. > However, Pochmann's method specifically swaps the same two edges and two > corners every solve. > > I have a solution to your problem, you may not like it though, but you > definitely don't like your approach to parity fixing, so I'll discuss my > thoughts w/ you later. And yes, this will preserve EO and CO, however, > these two steps must be done before my concept is applied. > > Later, > Daniel Beyer >

quite clearly. It's impossible to be a Fridrich speed solver and not
know these terms.

-Tyson

1139. Re: times with pochmann method ?
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Dec 2006 21:47:58 -0000

Well, I'll give you that much although not everyone uses names of internet algorithms (for instance I don't call things double/triple sune, I'd call it Spider and Cowskull), although a "UPerm" should still be pretty obvious. Regardless, we were referring to BLD, not speedsolving, and you can be fast at BLD without knowing a thing about Fridrich. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tyson.mao@...> wrote: > > I believe any sub-17 Fridrich user would understand this terminology > quite clearly. 1140. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: times with pochmann method ?
From: Daniel Beyer <dbeyer816@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Dec 2006 14:27:39 -0800 (PST)

Truly, this is all basically bashing marcus for his rediculously fast acclaimed times. Who cares anymore. As long as everybody learns from others and from theirselves, does it really matter how fast anybody is. If you want to get better, practice, if you want to prove yourself, compete. "Bragging, just isn't bragging if you can back it up." Also, to others that may be passively reading. Due to the immensity of memorizing and solving a rubik's revenge, or professor. Times can be sparatic, even if you are fast. You have good days and hellish ones too. I was averaging about 3:15 the night before rutgers, then I didn't do a single successful solve at rutgers in practice or competition. However, at G.wiz I was totally out of practice, and wasn't successfully solving the whole time in Florida, until about an hour before the Competition began. And I did fine while competing. People have off days, I know I've had mine and will continue to do so. Also, you can have sparatic leaps time cuts as well as increased increments. Both dramatic time cuts or increases in time are just as common as gradually shaving seconds off your times throughout the weeks of intense practice. Later, Daniel Beyer kyuubree <agent_m80@...> wrote: Well, I'll give you that much although not everyone uses names of internet algorithms (for instance I don't call things double/triple sune, I'd call it Spider and Cowskull), although a "UPerm" should still be pretty obvious. Regardless, we were referring to BLD, not speedsolving, and you can be fast at BLD without knowing a thing about Fridrich. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tyson.mao@...> wrote: > > I believe any sub-17 Fridrich user would understand this terminology > quite clearly. 1141. Re: times with pochmann method ?
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Dec 2006 22:58:36 -0000

No I'm not trying to get into some attack-war here -- I am just saying that it is very possible to solve a cube blindfolded quickly and not be entirely familiar with all the Fridrich algorithms, because you simply don't have to use explicit-Fridrich when you blindsolve. Just because you use an algorithm that permutes things while preserving orientation doesn't mean it's automatically considered Fridrich-style, and on the same note, it doesn't mean that knowledge of the whole Fridrich method is a prerequisite for blindfold-solving credibility. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Daniel Beyer <dbeyer816@...> wrote: > > Truly, this is all basically bashing marcus for his rediculously fast acclaimed times. Who cares anymore. As long as everybody learns from others and from theirselves, does it really matter how fast anybody is. If you want to get better, practice, if you want to prove yourself, compete. > > "Bragging, just isn't bragging if you can back it up." > > Also, to others that may be passively reading. Due to the immensity of memorizing and solving a rubik's revenge, or professor. Times can be sparatic, even if you are fast. You have good days and hellish ones too. I was averaging about 3:15 the night before rutgers, then I didn't do a single successful solve at rutgers in practice or competition. However, at G.wiz I was totally out of practice, and wasn't successfully solving the whole time in Florida, until about an hour before the Competition began. And I did fine while competing. People have off days, I know I've had mine and will continue to do so. Also, you can have sparatic leaps time cuts as well as increased increments. Both dramatic time cuts or increases in time are just as common as gradually shaving seconds off your times throughout the weeks of intense practice. > > Later, > Daniel Beyer > > kyuubree <agent_m80@...> wrote: > Well, I'll give you that much although not everyone uses names of > internet algorithms (for instance I don't call things double/triple > sune, I'd call it Spider and Cowskull), although a "UPerm" should > still be pretty obvious. Regardless, we were referring to BLD, not > speedsolving, and you can be fast at BLD without knowing a thing about > Fridrich. > > --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao > <tyson.mao@> wrote: > > > > I believe any sub-17 Fridrich user would understand this terminology > > quite clearly. It's impossible to be a Fridrich speed solver and not > > know these terms. > > > > -Tyson > > > > On Dec 28, 2006, at 1:54 PM, kyuubree wrote: > > > > > Yeah, not everyone knows the same algorithms, especially by name -- > > > sometimes people like figuring out different algorithms that work > > > better. I'd assume a fair number aren't entirely certain what an "OLL > > > + UPerm" is (some may even say it's practical but not optimal in > > > length), but can accomplish the same effect through other means. > > > There are many ways to skin a cat (or blindfold-solve a cube). > > > > > > > > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > http://mail.yahoo.com >
1142. Re: [blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube] Re: times with pochmann method ?
From: Tyson Mao <tyson.mao@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Dec 2006 15:15:22 -0800

With speed comes credibility. And people will listen to people who
post fast time.

I, unfortunately, know a cuber who'll probably never get beyond 19
seconds because he kept waiting for this magical "Waterman"
corners-first method. The method was never published. These algorithm
sets were never "released." The fast cuber who claimed this method
existed kept saying that it wasn't ready for release, that the public
wasn't ready for it yet.

And now what's he supposed to do? He dedicated over a year of his life
focusing on this method because someone said they could average
16.xx... and then he finds out later that it's all just a big scam.

That's the only reason why I care. Otherwise, I wouldn't. People can
say whatever they want, and until they beat me in competition, I don't
even have to throw them a glance. But seeing someone waste a year of
their life on a magical method that never existed because someone
claimed ridiculous times... that's why I care.

-Tyson

On Dec 29, 2006, at 2:27 PM, Daniel Beyer wrote:

> As long as everybody learns from others and from theirselves, does it
> really matter how fast anybody is.  If you want to get better,
> practice, if you want to prove yourself, compete.



1143. Re: times with pochmann method ?
From: "kyuubree" <agent_m80@...>
To: blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Dec 2006 00:24:32 -0000

That does raise some points though for consideration. If the method was never published, how did he waste a year? Did he just sit there and wait for a delivery? In the meantime it'd be better to become familiar with the workings of the cube or try out another fast method that will at least get you somewhat near the time you desire -- no one is ever doomed to be stuck at the 19 barrier. It's one's own decision as to what they choose to listen to and what they do not, and if an entire method is being withheld, odds are you're better off not listening. However, if a method's workings are revealed and it shows to facilitate, then, logically, there is no harm in listening if one chooses to. --- In blindfoldsolving-rubiks-cube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tyson.mao@...> wrote: > > With speed comes credibility. And people will listen to people who > post fast time. > > I, unfortunately, know a cuber who'll probably never get beyond 19 > seconds because he kept waiting for this magical "Waterman" > corners-first method. The method was never published. These algorithm > sets were never "released." The fast cuber who claimed this method > existed kept saying that it wasn't ready for release, that the public > wasn't ready for it yet. > > And now what's he supposed to do? He dedicated over a year of his life > focusing on this method because someone said they could average > 16.xx... and then he finds out later that it's all just a big scam. > > That's the only reason why I care. Otherwise, I wouldn't. People can > say whatever they want, and until they beat me in competition, I don't > even have to throw them a glance. But seeing someone waste a year of > their life on a magical method that never existed because someone > claimed ridiculous times... that's why I care. > > -Tyson > > On Dec 29, 2006, at 2:27 PM, Daniel Beyer wrote: > > > As long as everybody learns from others and from theirselves, does it > > really matter how fast anybody is. If you want to get better, > > practice, if you want to prove yourself, compete. >
